UgOhVGUOMfCPFt7AF5MWog.review_text: I've always wanted to be a pirate.  Thievery is sexy.  So is shiny treasure.  Men with boats?  Eye patches? daaaaaaaaammmnn.    Rum is pretty good too.  Unfortunately most people have had less a than favorable experience with Captain Morgan back in high school and have avoided the drink ever since.  Or Hurricane.  My bad experience was definitely with Hurricane...that blue hue still haunts me.  OK back to the point, that rum is GOOD.  Ever added some Malibu to your mimosa?  Well you should.  And if you want something else delicious, go to Smuggler's Cove.  Their selection of rums and rum cocktails is insane.  Just ask them what to get, because I don't think you can go wrong with anything.  These are seriously strong and delicious drinks.  AND they go perfectly with the pirate vibes of the whole bar.  There's 3 levels incase you feel the need to go below deck.  There's even a little waterfall to make you feel extra tropical.    Unfortunately my date cut me off after one drink, and I forget the name of it, so i should probably thank him for that?  I'll have to drag him back soon so I can do some more thorough taste testing.    The only bad part about this place is walking out and realizing you're not heading towards a deserted island.  Guess it's time to move to the Caribbean.

HoBQTRADVZ1QV75hK8mFgQ.review_text: First time here. Came with my mom and boyfriend (yes my mom is that cool and came with). Had terrible service here! The bartenders are rude and think they are the s****. Takes forever to get served, even when there is nobody else waiting for a drink. Had us pay for the drinks before we got them and were arrogant when we mentioned that we thought it was odd we had to pay for our drinks before they even made them. The icing on the cake was that they were more preoccupied with taking shots with each other than serving their customers. Great vibe and drinks, but service and attitude of the staff was terrible!! Can go elsewhere in the city for great drinks AND great service. Won't be back, this place doesn't deserve the service!

ItmZ_Y27bWpDx3E_nf6j2A.review_text: Smuggler's Cover is definitely worth a visit if you're in SF.  It's all about rum and the mysterious pirate theme.  The drinks are expensive and all based on rum...although I did see someone buy a beer (limited selection).  Beware that there's limited seating so you may have stand around with your group of friends.  If you're going with a large party arrive early and snag a seat downstairs or upstairs.  Otherwise, make this a place you go with a small group of 2 or 3.  I'm not a huge rum fan so I wouldn't go back for the drinks, but it's a fun place and can see it appealing to those rum enthusiasts.

mTLVb-viwKA2NJPuzHlE7A.review_text: Walking into Smugglers Cove is like entering into another world;  one full of adventure, rich history, pirates, and of course booze...lots of it. It's more of an experience than anything else, and once you do enter in from the nondescript entrance the outside hustle and bustle immediate melts away.   The ambiance is very "Pirates of the Caribbean (but in a tongue in cheek, classy way)." There are 3 floors to the bar, but their tiny and it still maintains a small and comfortably vibe. The decorations are unique, nautical, and you could tell that huge attention was put towards the details (the blowfish lamps are awesome!). Something that you need to experience for yourself.  The menu is extensive (77 carefully crafted drinks in all, plus 200 handpicked rums); and for the first timer a little intimidating. Although the staff is wonderful, really living proof to the term "bartender." Not just hastily throwing together a drink, but rather crafting each drink like putting together an ornate puzzle. They take their time, but in a good way, you can tell that the bartenders love their job and are passionate about what they do. And even if you don't know exactly what you want, they're there to steer you in the right direction (and I promise you that you can't go wrong with anything on that menu).   Favorite Drinks: Puka Punch, Calibogus, and of course the HOT BUTTERED RUM.  Smugglers Cove is by far my favorite bar in San Francisco (and it's perhaps the best rum bar you'll find in the US).   Stop by, relax, forget the troubles of the day, and enjoy!

tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ.review_text: 01.29.10  I miss this place when it was Jade Bar. I miss the $2 drink specials. I miss being able to walk in without waiting in line.  Ever.  Now that that's out of the way, Smuggler's Cove is a cute little place.  They redid the decor, so it's now super gaudy and tacky, just the way a tiki bar should be.  Drinks are complicated.  It takes a long time.  You need to have patience for a good drink.  The bartender sometimes has to look up a recipe halfway to finish the drink.  Patience, my friend.  Drinks with a barrel next to it indicate that they're strong.  Trust me on this.  The zombie = no bueno for the weak of heart.  The bottom level kind of smelled the night I was there.  Perhaps better ventilation is in order, especially for a rainy night?  The line outside keeps the atmosphere inside casual and does not make you feel like a sardine once you're in.  Appreciate.  Don't hate on the bouncer who has a hard enough job as it is.

XvdnBLZCJbde7S8iHq0kbw.review_text: I came here with a few friends on a Saturday night. There was a line outside but it went pretty quickly. I realized once inside, the room capacity was limited even with their three levels.  They have an extensive intriguing drink menu with fun & friendly battenders. They sure know how to make great drinks! mmm  ;) I loved the pirate theme and  atmosphere. I found the lower level louder than the ground & upper level. Pretty crowded..(expect your bubble to be invaded ;) bt nonetheless found everyone to be friendly and struck up conversions w/  strangers. It's a nice venue..ill definitely come back on a weekday when it's less busy

MYLhubAuR15MaOyJineCGQ.review_text: This place is to rum what places like Bourbon & Branch and American Oak are to whiskey. If you enjoy rum, join their Rumbustion Society, they have hundreds of rare and hard-to-find types in stock. If you like tiki drinks, be aware that these WILL be on the strong side, whether they're marked as such or not.

DKYOWSdNpTU8nJ4famV5nA.review_text: I'm not going to write a long review, you don't want that- really.  A great and varied cocktail menu. What I love most about it is that most Tiki bars specialize only in Rum drinks but if you'd like to go in another direction- say Gin, they'll have more than a few options for you. Additionally, they don't just have many concoction options, they have many different top shelf rums, whiskeys, gins et. al.   I will say the $10 and 10 minute wait for my drinks were worth it. Very worth it.

5eAc-EWo6rEpxXtj7W3cuA.review_text: Yo Ho...Yo Ho... Thanks to my #1 bestest brother for recommending this bar to me!!!    This is my second time back and I heart Smuggler's Cove!!!  This place is awesome and the drinks are off the charts!  It's definitely a hidden gem and the decor is sooooo very cool!!!  I love the extensive drink menu and I even got the "barrel" mug to take home to remind me of the fun times there!!!  Cheers to getting tipsy yelpers!!!

xYVN54PYHtqHxlVK8A2S2A.review_text: Looks like another building from outside but inside is a cool pirate ship theme bar. Not the biggest place but very cool. Three floors, bar on two floors seating on all three. Exotics drinks that you don't see at your normal bar. Get there early because it does it packed and of course parking sucks. Drinks are reasonable but good.

_gcDdPUVA9wwSynicxcpzw.review_text: Stopping in at Smuggler's Cove at 1am to cap off a Sat night was a PERFECT idea.   My crew ordered the flaming Volcano drink, with space for 4 straws and lit on fire by the cackling servant. I quickly became Captain F***yeah!, sitting on my straw throne, passing wise and strict judgement on all.

1XANyLruTMqMCYelC8qBig.review_text: By far the coolest bar I've ever been to!  I've never understood the Pirates vs Ninjas thing, but I'll give pirates a vote because of this place.  I'd read about it before and came in for a drink with the bf. I think the decor is absolutely spectacular; anywhere else that claims to be a pirate bar is just kidding themselves.   The drinks aren't cheap but $9-12 is fine. They are all rum based and even though I never order rum drinks by choice, I really liked the one I got....something like a mojito with pineapple.   We had to go meet friends later, but I will definitely be back. I think this place is so sooo cool.

0m29JLi3LUtZ2e1Fp_nPvA.review_text: I am in love.  As a tiki drink lover and a long time patron of Alameda's Forbidden Island, it takes a lot to impress me. Well this place did it and it was no surprise that the same creator of my East Bay love was also the creator of Smugglers Cover. But even if SC may be the younger of the two, don't let that fool you. They have an impressive rum list  and an even more impressive one that you can't even see until had enough of their beginner list (there is a fancier name for is but forgive me I was two cocktail deep when the bartender filled me in). The cocktail menu ranges from traditional to contemporary, offering something for everyone's taste, as well as torrence level. If you choose to booze it up on a Saturday I suggest arriving a little early, lets say before 10, this place gets packed. It's hard to get bored or impatient waiting for a drink when there is so much to look at but if you don't want to wait ten minutes show up before the rush. One thing that stood out on the menu  was that they had a cocktail with Akvavit, a Danish spirit.  I'm  partially Scandinavian so I had to give it a go. It was actually really good. Not really tiki but good just the same :)

qCA4T_fLCnwLhLHWvPUYYQ.review_text: If this place wasn't already so well - known, I'd almost feel bad about letting other people know about it. It almost seems like some kind of secret location, because it is so, SO easy to walk right by the front door without even knowing it's there, unless you come on a weekend, during which the line is known to snake around the block. Most of my friends and I are lucky (?) to be weekend workers, so we get to go to places like this on weekdays, which is definitely the best time to go.   The menu has chapters, where you can choose from all kinds of drinks, from old and classic, to new and trendy. They have a great rum selection, and apparently they make all of their fruit juices in house, so no fakey - tasting mixers here! No  My friend and I have gotten to try a good number of their cocktails, some of my personal favorites being the painkiller, and the Demerara Dry Float. They also have the tastiest Zombie that I've had anywhere.   The bartenders here are super friendly, and always down to make conversation and recommendations based on what you like, and when it gets busy, they can be personable and deal a lot of customers hella efficiently at the same time.  The atmosphere is without a doubt one of the biggest draws here, and rightfully so. As I said before, when there is no line outside, you can't even tell it's there. As soon as step inside through the blacked - out glass doors, you're instantly transported into not just the tropics, but the pirate - y tropics. The amount of pirate - ness of Smuggler's Cove is what sets it apart from all the other tropical bars I've been to, taking it to an almost "theme park" level of playfulness. The upstairs area (where you walk in) has its own bar, but there isn't really a lot of seating. The downstairs area is where you want to be. It looks like a cave, with a small waterfall under the stairs, and is very cozy and intimate. This place is great.

UMD3tXY7byF8JaOmpTUoDw.review_text: Hubby and I really like this bar! As a matter of fact, we are waiting for them to open now=) Fun atmosphere, interesting décor..drink are good and stiff (awesome!)

t6FE2zFmZ_9Go2fZ3klzng.review_text: Not impressed at all. I don't know where to start. There was a long line outside to get in. I don't know why but I guess it's just to control their numbers. What turns me off most is waiting for a place and coming out dissatisfied. I guess I'm not a fan of the pirate/ high seas theme.   I'm also partial to bars with music. (Where my hip hop heads at?). There was no music to be found. It might've fallen victim to Davy Jones' Locker. Forreal, maybe if it was 80's or 90's themed, then at least there'd be some excuse to play music. But pirates? No way Cap. Doesn't float my boat.  Although there are 3 levels, it was a hassle getting around. Despite the growing fear of claustrophobia, each floor is pretty tight and difficult to navigate. Imagine, 50+ people in a tight knit space, no ventilation, just straight body fumes. (YIKES).  Waiting for your drink kinda reminded me of waiting at the DMV. Even then, I wasn't satisfied with my order. I probably made the poor choice there.   I get the theme and it might work for some folks. It just doesn't work for me. Smuggler's Cove can walk the plank.

l5HDIE7PptNzMDukTBirDQ.review_text: I love the pirate-like theme to this bar -- very fun and unique.  I would definitely recommend checking it out at least once.  The only issues were the descriptions for the drinks were not very detailed...and the bartender recommended a drink that we all HATED -- so we asked him if we could get something else instead and he got upset and charged us for the new drink because he said "that's what you ordered."   Also, the space is extremely small...not enough room there -- so keep this in mind.

EkUj42L09b6utqiJZ18zaQ.review_text: The spirits selection and cocktail menu are unreal. The atmosphere is also great. If you are lucky enough to speak to Martin Cate, the owner, get ready to have your mind blown by his knowledge of rum.  Great place, we are so lucky to have this in SF:-)

zpmViTr7g_1Ig8jPO0VNSQ.review_text: As a single girl in the city and one partial to yelping new restaurants and venues in SF, I really enjoy when a young gentleman caller suggests a place I have yet to visit. On a recent Monday evening, I was asked to grab a drink and see if there was a chemistry for many more future drinks. Apparently the later didn't happen, but in the journey, I did discover a rad new cocktail lounge.  Smuggler's Cove has taken over the old Jade Bar and made many fantastic improvements. The most appreciated being removing the "coke-den" lighting and eliminating the scent of "oh-crap-someone-barfed-in-the-fountain-again". I guess you could say, they made it a little more refined...perhaps it's the huge increase in drink prices that did it...hence the minus one star.  As usual, I digress....this bar is rad. The menu is not only extensive, but is written in order of region of origin and chronilogical significance. So not only do you get a sweet buzz on, but a history lesson while you're at it!   We scored a spot right at the bar downstairs which made me happy because I could watch each of the handcrafted art pieces being made one by one. That''s right, each drink is hand made...no pre-made batches here and no bottled mixers. Everything is hand squeezed, crushed, muddled, twisted, stirred and shaken. This means waiting a little bit longer than usual, but you won't be disapointed. I ended up ordering their authentic mai-tai and another rum beverage called "the Millionaire." They both came beautifully garnished and carefully crafted by the highly experienced mixologists behind the bar. When I inquired from the bar back "How did you apply for this job?" All he could tell me was "You don't apply for a job here, you are chosen." And I see why...  The atmosphere is amazing, the drinks delicious and creative (I actually ate a candied hybiscus flower!), the staff friendly and knowledgeable and the crowd is grown and sexy.  So maybe the date didn't work out, but I intend on returning with good friends to share the wealth of my new find. Do yourself a favor and try it out soon.

mxsAnGKKh7cE2ZyDAyOjGg.review_text: Because sometimes you do need that Pirates of Penzance bulls@#t.  I love a good dive more than most people and one of the things that drew me to this city was it's abundance of seedy bars, but I acknowledge that this city needs more options. Where are our barcades and movie theaters that serve drinks? Come on SF, give us some alternatives to the alternative.  This place was actually a lot more fun than I expected. The exterior doesn't really suggest much and the actual bar resembles something closer to One-Eyed Willie's pirate ship (Goonies reference). There's a small upstairs room with a tropical theme and a downstairs that I didn't even make it to. The rum drinks are as pricey as you would expect but well made and strong.  The only drawback is that there was a line but I suppose if I got there earlier that wouldn't have been an issue.

pI15RINDqpXIk5492xx7PA.review_text: I dig, I dig.   You would never know 'the Cove' was there if it weren't for the lamps outside. Windows are blacked out in a way that you can't even see inside. At first I found myself wondering what sort of shenanigans were going on within.  Stepping inside, you find the decor is pretty awesome. 3 floors of straight up island/pirate/Caribbean style (bars on the main floor and in the basement). A caveat to the wise, the fountain downstairs is probably quite dangerous to be near if you've had too much to drink....  You should probably ask for the menu since the selection is extensive. Drinks can be a bit more expensive than the average cocktail but that's only because they're very elaborate and often quite large.  Can be crowded and loud so keep that in mind but otherwise a good spot for a tasty drink!

7TRexhGfCJtpSOHBHfrRvg.review_text: There isn't a sign out front; it's one of those places trying to actually look like a speakeasy.  $10 drinks.  They were really good, though--especially the Millionaire Martini, which I recommend if you like gin.  Yes, gin & rum together, in harmony.  The bartender last night in the downstairs area was friendly, organized and didn't need to look at recipes when she made drinks.  I agree with others that the bouncer was also friendly--not up his own ass.  I got there at 6:00 and didn't have to wait outside.  I can't imagine waiting outside for Smuggler's Cove, though.  It's just a silly bar.  I didn't like the layout of the space back when it was Jade, and I still don't like it; it feels awkward.    With the decorations being OTT, you feel corny being there, but it's a fun place to check out.  Once.  :)

48eqsALGsRWqj_JL6xThdg.review_text: I have a strange obsession with tiki bars. I probably have my childhood experience at Disneyland's Tiki Room to thank for this, or maybe it was all the Gilligan's Island reruns. I only found this place after a Yelp search of the tiki bars in SF.  I had never been here before but wanted to try it based on all the reviews I'd seen. My cousin's birthday seemed like an excellent excuse for giving it a shot. He and his girlfriend were impressed by the crazy fun pirate island adventure vibe. We sat downstairs where the water feature is most prominent. I love the attention to detail. Feels like the pirate's lair inside a wooden shipwreck. definitely a great place to set sail into rum-runner bliss.  For those who do not appreciate the burnt-sugary complexities of exotic rum based cocktails, there are plenty other inventive libations that employ any kind of poison your choosing. Bring an eye patch and a bag of doubloons because this voyage is not cheap.  Our punch bowl for 4 which in my opinion is really better suited for 2 people was about $32. Pricey as it may be, It's a great place to surprise an out of town guest. If you like taking a trip away from the everyday cityscape, you'll get what you pay for at this little oasis called Smuggler's Cove.

wEE-YMx5pmSuagLtNxMPKA.review_text: Arggggggg. I know, I'm giving a pirate bar 3 stars, I'm such a wench. But, seriously from waiting in line on a Sat night to get in, to waiting 20 minutes to order, then another 20 minutes for the drinks to get made, it was kind of a buzz kill. My maties and I were definitely sobering up by the time our drinks came.   We were lucky enough to snag a table at the top of the "ship". Yes, this bar is designed in the shape of a pirate ship. The 10 page menu of Tiki inspired drinks was over whelming especially when 30 people are trying to get up in ya, to order before you and all drinks were expensive (sheesh $15 is STEEP for a libation). From what my eyes could see all drinks were "sugary" in the sense that they were filled with fruit juices and lots of rum. I couldn't even finish my crazy concoction for the fear of onset diabetes.  Regardless, this hidden speakeasy is definitely a super cool and unique spot; definitely a conversation starter. And, I'd imagine on a Tuesday night, if no one is here and you're not waiting forever to get in and for drinks, this would definitely be a great stop by for a cocktail. Overall, I'm glad to have checked it off the list but, without music, and the super pricy drinks, this booty is explorin' more unchartered territories!

KPHGe3OvrH914nqL0RVbYQ.review_text: My favorite bar in SF  Amazingly delicious cocktails Terrific mixologists who are very friendly and helpful at choosing drinks A really large menu full of many different rum cocktails I've never found the place overcrowded because they don't let too many people in at once.  Which means on busy nights you might have to wait in line for a bit.  Recommendations: Get a seat at the bar so you can watch the mixologists work their magic.   Get a seat upstairs if you want a quieter atmosphere, but space up there is very limited. The Purple cocktail is my favorite Be careful not to drink too much, the drinks are really delicious, so it's easy to want one more!

saEUjebfkgXQKzNuD_0Pfg.review_text: They have great and expensive rums that are hard to find, and make excellent mixed drinks. The decor is over-the-top in a tragically kitschy way, but you're not going there for the ambiance, you're going to get blitzed on exotic rums!  The downside is that the place is ridiculously understaffed and it'll take 15-20 minutes to get your drink.  They also managed to lose my friend's credit card.  Ultimate suck, but they were profusely apologetic about it.

IBrL-6twlZmQBGLdV2DQiw.review_text: Actually, their menu grew since I went there last, or maybe I drank too many Three Dots last time.  Anyway, it's pretty long reading.  Luckily, they have little icons so you know which ones are their favorites and which ones will make you black out.  Handy!

AHz3sGxkZjAzv8uu0Q9hqg.review_text: Question:  What did the pirate say when he entered smuggler's cove?  Answer:  It's a fun BARRRRRGGGGH.  Okay, so I'm a little rusty on the pirate jokes and I lost my eye-patch and sword several years ago, but I dig smuggler's cove.  I like the 3 level tiki-action.    Another reason to swing on by is for the list of RUM...this place has lots and lots of rum.  If you don't love rum, then you should just walk the plank.  Seriously.    It is narrow, dark and with a metal stairwell (caution to ladies wearing HEELS) leading down to a bar opposite of a little cove with a fountain (hey, little hipsters, don't drop your iPhone while texting)...so throw a penny and make a wish (no worries, no fishies reside there)  Oh...and I love the whole communal drinks set on fire...(for all you pyros out there, this drink is for you!)

Xsh127u6Bx_1V5b8HjWITQ.review_text: A good friend was starting off her bday celebration here last night. This place was so freakin cute. Once you stepped through that front door, you stepped into another world. Like pirates of the Carribean but for adults only...haha..it was awesome!   "Ar Matey!"   I treated the bday girl to a Kona Cocktail...and I had some punch drink (forgot the name). It had a little barrel next to it...barrel = extra strong! The bartender took a while to make it but he was so precise and careful to make it taste delicious and look so beautiful! The wait was so worth it...one drink was enough for me! It was like he was creating a masterpiece!   The place started to get a little more crowded and I was certainly glad we had gotten out drinks in earlier! I would def come back here!

bKmLqpm3ukBfOzETXpNSYA.review_text: It's a freakin' pirate ship!  That's a plus.  Also, the drinks may sound girly, but they're actually pretty strong...or strong enough.  They staff is nice - they definitely know how to make you feel welcomed.  The only downfall is they close at 1:15.

FGBTSAcFcUBLztp5GMZVIw.review_text: Sometimes you're in the mood to visit Disneyland. And other times, the thought of donning mouse ears makes you want to head far away from Never Never Land.  Had I visited here when I was in the mood to be entertained in a swashbuckling Mickey Mouse kind of way, I think I would have liked Smuggler's Cove more. However, when you want a drink AND you want a good one, you don't care about all the fluff! The bartenders seem a bit on the newbie side, carefully measuring their expensive, but weak concoctions. When we finally got our drinks after a long wait, it was obvious that they tend to over-ice their drinks.  This bar is just a bit too much on the "cute" side for me. I'm not usually down with the girlie drinks--too sweet and its a sure hangover! Give me a Guiness and/or shot of Whiskey, and I'll be happy! To give them credit, Smuggler's Cove does have a light-hearted theme that they have mastered from decor to attire. Its strong thematic atmosphere is something I would expect along Fisherman's Wharf. If I had some out of town guests to entertain, this could be a fun place to visit. But, it's definitely not what I would call a good representation of authentic San Francisco style bars.

I2JXrApnU_YZ0es18gFI0A.review_text: It's like Pirates of the Caribbean up in here! This is a GREAT bar! And boy the drinks are YUMMY and STRONG! Me and a friend ordered the Top Notch Volcano. It's on FIRE! (literally!) It comes in a big ass bowl and they give you straws to drink it with. The drink is meant to serve 4 people but we managed to chug it all down between the 2 of us! After finishing our 1st bowl in less than 10 minutes we ordered the Arrac Punch next! The thing about these drinks is that they taste so damn good but you know there is a sh*tload of alcohol in there! It was only until I stood up did I realize how faded I already was! The drunker I get...the louder I get. Safe to say I was pretty damn loud by the end of the night!  PS - don't forget to ask the bartender to sign-off on all the cocktails you try! They will give you a piece of paper for this. Completing this will give you official proof of your BadAss-ness aka alcoholism.

sBQHJzPlQYVdwjEeqtvgrQ.review_text: This type of place belongs here in San Francisco. The unique pirate theme and local-feeling crowd really gives this place an exclusive-to-SF vibe. It's a one-of-a-kind, awesomely decorated, small, but lovely bar. The crowd of people that go here are diverse in age and personality. It's small, so there is limited seating when it gets crowded, but the drinks are definitely worth it.  I came here at around 8:30 pm on a Saturday. There was a line out the door, and we ended up waiting for about 30 minutes outside until they let us in - but once we got in, the experience was so worth it. It didn't take long to get a drink and because I'm a rum-lover, all the drinks sounded pretty damn good. I got 2 drinks (& btw I love how they point out which drinks are "strong") and the first one I had was some sort of punch, it was very good. The second drink wasn't as good, but still okay. Both were strong and both got the job done.  Though the drinks run about $13-15 on average each, the atmosphere and decor of the place is so worth it. I would definitely return, maybe earlier in the night to beat the crowd, but I'd love to see the fire show and sip on some rum goodness again!  I also liked the upstairs bartenders (there are 3 floors, 2 floors with bars) a lot more than the downstairs lady bartender - she didn't seem to like being there too much.

IWal1ziP1AlfcgDJj5CKFw.review_text: Great spot.  Despite being on 3 levels, it is small.  I wouldn't come with more than 4 folks.  The bar was slammed so it can be tough to get a beverage but when you do it is delicious.  They have an amazing list of over 200 different rums.  Wait til the type dies down and check it out in the new year.   No line when I strolled in at 730 one night last week.

Y9cpFtecVpAJ-L2LyP1QgA.review_text: Slipped in last night right at 5pm when they opened. You have to know it's here or a body could walk right by. Also, when I called info for the phone number they had no listing. It was happy hour and the drinks were cheaper. Ordered a Mai Tai that rivaled Tahiti Nui in Kauai. It was deeeeeeeelicious but had way too much ice. The bartender certainly knew what he was doing but had zero personality. As bland as a pet rock. We were sitting at the bar (downstairs) which is a way I like to assess a new bar and get a feeling for the place. This bartender did nothing to make me "happy". Barely acknowledged by existence and I was put off.   Biggest problem as I see it: NO FOOD. I mean not even a bowl of frikkin' nuts. Come on!!! When a drink can cost $13 shouldn't you at least have a macadamia to chew on.  Well shouldn't you? The website states that they have a Type 48 ABC liquor license which does not allow them to serve food, but they LIE. It actually is (as follows) that they do not have to serve food. Big difference. Show me the nuts!!!!  48 ON SALE GENERAL - PUBLIC PREMISES - (Bar, Night Club) Authorizes the sale of beer, wine and distilled spirits for consumption on the premises where sold. Authorizes the sale of beer and wine for consumption off the premises where sold. Minors are not allowed to enter and remain (see Section 25663.5 for exception, musicians). Food service is not required.

HoVOBhvoNnTC6wi1tvsV2A.review_text: This place lives up to the hype, y'all!  The ambiance and decor is legit (argg!), the drinks are delicious, and the bartenders are some of the most talented people in the city.  While it's not an everyday kind of bar, there is no doubt in my mind that this place worth the wait to get in and worth the crowds on the inside.

6CqjM5LYyumiaNnGU4M6dg.review_text: Bouncer was a dick - didn't let us in when it was empty. Flaming bowls are all show and really aren't strong. They ran out of long straws which was made it hard for everyone to drink at the same time - isn't that the point of the larger skull bowl? The servers aren't fun nor are they friendly. All in all. Super dissapointment to what I thought could be a fun environment and experience... Walk the plank!

buBxFGgxsAfvvyLeXp_EgA.review_text: I'm a fan of: Theme bars! Why do soooo many damn bars in SF have to be either standard dive bar, standard Irish pub, or standard "swank lounge" set-ups? I'm bored. Granted, when it comes to theme bars there's a fine line between cheese and cool, but I give props to Smuggler's Cove and Rickhouse for putting in some damn effort and doing something different- and they do pull it off sans too much fromage.  I'm not a fan of: This new trend of novel-sized drink menus full of labor-intensive drinks with 5,000 ingredients that take as long to make (and are as expensive as) a good meal at a restaurant. Yeah, yeah, "quality over quantity" and all that crap- I like a good drink as much as the next guy-  but we're talkin bout DRINKS and this is a BAR....not a 5-course French restaurant. Other reviews are right...it takes foooorrreeever and a day to get a drink here. It doesn't help that the bartenders are forced to use jiggers for every pour, and that the menu is so voluminous, and that every drink is more labor-intensive than a mojito....but besides all that the 'tenders are still slow..everyone likes a bartender with "personality," but when 12 people are waiting for their drinks, cut the chit-chat and pump 'em out dammit.   Plus 1 star for the chill, non power-trippin bouncer. Whatever they're paying him he deserves a raise. The owners are either completely paranoid about the fire code or they get off on having a line outside...either way there always seems to be a line outside of bitching patrons- even when it's not that crowded inside (Jade packed 'em in more)- and the bouncer handles this annoying mess with a good sense of humor and patience...a true rarity in the city.  Minus 1 star for charging $10 for a Jameson. I know, I know, it's a rum bar, but that's still disgusting.

3JgcaZf9MLt4Q5hbZ6Pwxw.review_text: When our friends suggested this place and when I first got there, my first impression was WTH!!  After adjusting to the small cozy venue and getting ourselves a table upstairs, we started to enjoy our drinks. I normally don't like rum or drinks with rum but the drinks here are yummy.  I really like the volcano drink where 4 people get to share this big cocktail made of rum, pineapple, etc.  This was very entertaining and yummy!  I also had another drink but I can't remember the name.  The drinks were all good and tended to be on the strong side. I really enjoyed my time here. I would definitely come here again.  Since we came on a Wednesday, the place was not as packed. I heard lines can be long on the weekends and it gets pretty busy.  You will totally miss this place walking pass it.  Luckily our cab driver knew where it was.

kcT1gFsIKjB638joUkAvtA.review_text: Visiting from NY and friends wanted to meet here before dinner (where we were eating was a $15 cab ride away (first thing that didn't make sense to me) I was told this was rated one of the best bars in the world, my expectation was that I'd get the most amazing drink, laugh and have fun and leave with a 20 something hot model, this was not one of the best bars in the world (I left with my wife) ;-) btw who is hotter than any 20 something model! Now the fun parts, what's all this crap about strong great drinks? The bartender was using a shot glass to measure pours, sure if you order a $14-16 dollar drink with 2 or 3 shots it's strong...wtf ? You wait way too long and the bartenders act like they're doing you a favor. Also I get it about the bouncer, if he's the guy with the bun of hair on the back of his head he'd better be a MMA fighter because he looked like he couldn't handle my 13 year old son. I guess he doesn't have to because the clientele is 20 something hipsters dressed in jeans and Gap attire.  The pirate motif is fun for a second then it's a bore and I'm not really an umbrella drink kinda guy. As an aside who would wait outside on line for 20 minutes + to get in, we were there at 7:30 and got right in. Won't be going back though. PS: It's located across the street from the projects, there was more noise coming from there than the line. I'd like to see Ms. Fancy Pants bouncer shut them up!

Tp-NCrYWElW_0QVg-KEr0w.review_text: Smuggler's Cove, for the rum enthusiast, is the best bar in San Francisco.  This bar is both tiny and 3 levels, but I exclusively sit on the lower level, which is where this place really shines.  Head down the flight of metal stairs as you enter, next to the (admittedly cheesy) waterfall and you end up in a little room, with enough seating for 5 moderately sized parties plus seating for 5-6 more at the bar.  The decor is some combination of carribean/nautical/pirates.  The seating is comfortable and consists of padded benches and a few movable chairs around low crate-like tables.  The bartender (whose name I never remember even though he always seems to remember which rums I've been served in previous trips) makes fantastic mixed drinks and also does recommendations on shots of rum if you so-desire.  As for the mixed drinks, all are meticulously crafted and well worth the price (about $10 or so per drink).  If its not too crowded and you're feeling adventurous, he's also not opposed to creating a new drink for you on the fly.  We requested a special drink with compari and got the most interesting cocktail I have ever tried (very complex flavors but not overpowering).  What brings me back to this bar, however is the collection of approximately 200 bottles of rum from all over the world.  When I first went here, I just asked for a recommendation and ended up with 3 really fantastic shots to try.  Even when this place is at capacity he will still take a moment to listen to what kind of rum I'm looking for and then describe the characteristics of what he has poured me.   I can't say enough nice things about this place -- anyone who wants a fantastic cocktail or wants to learn a little more about rum owes it to themselves to spend an evening here.

zOvWfHkLdbCQHBgv3wAc-A.review_text: this place is awesome! the atmosphere is great, bartenders are super nice and the drinks are AMAZING! dont pass this place up! i'll definitely be back again soon :)

o60yRcNLuy-oIjHfNlAEdA.review_text: I went here several months ago... Went there not realizing it was no longer Jade or whatever it used to be... but I was impressed with how far they went with the Pirates theme... They went all out with the decorations and the rum drinks... I was quite buzzed at the time, but I remember it being busy, but not packed.... it had a lively, fun atmosphere that didn't take itself too seriously...... tons of rum drink choices that were a bit pricy but also fun considering they serve a few in skulls.... I'd like to go again... just a fun place to go and be stupid I guess...

G_Qklq5MUZhLOUv6xoaS6w.review_text: Went on a Monday night, and it was pretty packed.   Scorpion bowl and Puka punch! This place serve's strong drinks. I'd recommend this place to others and return again. I like the scorpion bowl more than the one at Trader Sam's.   Be aware of street cleaning hours if you park around the neighborhood.

kZXJsLJvpWgZ_lFZg6732g.review_text: WOW. Drinks are so good. But be careful they are so strong without tasting like it!! I love the pirate theme and the dark Tiki atmosphere. Its good to go on off peek hours like during the weekdays because the drinks are labor intensive and if there are tons of people you will wait a long time.

X-ao_GLTWrMVhW0MIP9Pzg.review_text: I'm sorry, but this place kinda blows. We were there on opening night, so the long wait at the door, the bartender who had to look up recipes for half the drinks on the menu, the even longer wait for a drink once we got inside, and lack of any discernible system behind the bar can all be excused. Or at least chalked up to first-night jitters. I love pirates and I love rum even more, so I was willing to give them the benefit of the doubt.  What canNOT be excused is the shitty attitude the, ahem, bouncer gave us outside. Me and two of my lady pals were first in line waiting in the freezing cold to go in. Three people walked out, so my friend says to the bouncer guy, "hey, can we go in now?"   He whips around and goes, "do I come to YOUR job and tell you how to do it?" Then sighs a big asshole sigh.  Whoa. We were left speechless.   A few minutes later he deemed us worthy of entering. By that point it didn't matter. We waited 20 minutes at the bar and didn't even get close to getting a drink.  Sorry guys, you lost me.

8AqIUVxErDCsopqxmrxKbA.review_text: The two stars is for the drinks, which our entire company of mixed backgrounds felt pretty meh about.  Each averages $9-13 and very sweet.  Great if I were actually on an island, but on a chilly SF night, passion fruit and rum wasn't doing it for me.  Four stars for the bartenders, who are very friendly and not your typical late-20s handlebar hipsters.

fBdhA2Q1Y_lTR7_nje4PyA.review_text: Not impressed. I felt like I was trapped on a Disney ride. Plus, why does no one know how to make a good mojito? Every bartender needs to take a flight to Havana.

C469FeAyiATdaNmgXjZYWQ.review_text: A rum specialist bar with its own programme. That's program with an "e" because this place is on an entirely different level. Bartenders will either make the best drink with rum or sell you on the history of the drink itself.  Caution: smugglers cove is not exactly Hayes valley's best kept decret, so expect a line. My favorite thing to do is duck in at an early hour (5pm) on a Friday when the sun is still out (windows are tinted) and have a nice intimate cocktail with a friend or friends.

KRoCu_g3tiXhJANzo1J57A.review_text: I love the concept of this place! It's in a very nonchalant location, hidden behind some trees and a light pole.  The windows are dark and there's no sign outside.  The only way you can find this place is by going right in front and seeing a small wooden sign that says "Smugglers Cove" tacked onto a tree.  Once inside, I felt like I'd been transported to the pirate ship from the Goonies.  Service: although it gets pretty packed at night, the bartenders were still polite and very willing to hand out water at a moment's request.  We got the famous volcano bowl, shared between 5 people, which was not cheap at thirty six dollars.  I guess if you poured 4 drinks into a bowl, it would equal about the same amount anyways.  We were provided 2 foot long straws and when the guy took out the bowl, he had a spray can with him that made the flame blow up, so BE CAREFUL! Keep your eyebrows away from the bowl!  The cocktail itself wasn't bad; it was some kind of mixed rum drink that was decently strong.  My friend tried another one of their cocktails and it was frothy with flowers inside, which made it very appealing.  Would I come back? Yes.  Could I spend several hours here? Probably not.  The place was so cramped on a Saturday night that even though we found seats, I felt like we were circled and being watched by vultures, just waiting to pounce on our seats if we were to get up.

5jr96o5b9co_4TWAaZyChw.review_text: This place is top-notch.  A nice chill vibe and the best Tiki cocktails.  And the bartender, Steven, knows his spirits.  The man can not be stumped.  I like that the lighting is also very dim, which adds to the vibe.  No sunglasses or welder's mask needed...unless you get one of their flaming drinks.  Fun stuff.  My ultimate goal is to have every one of their cocktails.   Cheers...

8AjmaGfsVOcRkJ7qyXRZAw.review_text: Rum rum rum. Super discrete on the outside (windows are all completely blacked out), but if you're somehow able to get in, WOW.   TAKEAWAYS:  - Specialty drinks are all $10+. Prepare accordingly.  - There are three floors, but this place is super packed. Fortunately on the weeknights it's more tolerable, but brace yourselves during the weekends. It's a popular local watering hole.  - Drinks are strong (I mean it's rum, who are we kidding). Funsies.   Bottom line, I'd pay a drink just to sit here and bask in the glory of the bartenders making fun drinks. Pro tip: there's a "laguna" downstairs, grab the tables there for prime real estate and a more private talk.

Zqn2BG57OQLXOC57JPj8Ug.review_text: Great Tiki atmosphere. Drinks freshly made and yummy

D8JswSWcY-fznIm05Y3WZA.review_text: This is a MUST SEE while in San Francisco. Good cocktails but it's more for the experience and ambiance.

5JBUr02Eemexu4f3nVIRvA.review_text: When I think of Tiki-Bars I think of the most cheese-ball dive bar possible where creepy old dudes attempt to hit on twenty-somethings over poorly poured rum and cokes.  Not the case at Smuggler's Cove. As for the title, I guess if you're a smuggler you would want your cove well hidden. This bar follows suit. Within the walls and design look like something out of Disneyland. Outside it's just any old nondescript store front in San Francisco.  I suppose the rum and coke is an option here, but it's really not where your focus should be. This is a tiki-bar of the highest caliber where awesome cocktail creations will run you between $9-15+ dollars. Yes, that's out of a lot of folks price ranges. Keep your budget in mind before you walk in because the tastes will lure you into more and more orders and pretty soon you'll be in pretty deep, both in alcohol and greenbacks.  They offer one of those big bowls but I don't think it's worth the price tag. Outside of that I tried the Fogcutter, a drink I've been reading about recently in its original form. Smuggler's Cove makes theirs up as kind of a hybrid but they stay true with the mix to what that drink was meant to be. Some of the other drinks I tried were awesome as well, though I don't remember the names. All in all, I don't think you can go wrong with pretty much anything in here. Check it out. Cheesy island themed t-shirt optional.

QxtJv2pNWYchK45Ewk5F-A.review_text: Dear Mellisa,  Your cocktails were well crafted, and you were teaching magic to the barbacks.  You knew the solera method of Ron zapaca, and were delightful.  Thank you!

CKyoRam-vNQud1z1dJe3Eg.review_text: I really wanted to like this place. heard so much about it. Hangar One makes one of their rum - Elixir, previous owner of Forbidden Island now owns this place, the front of the building is so obscure that you feel like you're entering a secret place! You walk in and the decore is fabulous with 3 floors. I took a large party there after a birthday dinner and we hung out downstairs. I think the bartender was having a bad night because all of our drinks were horrible. The manager & staff were great and took care of us right away.  I will try it again and revise my review soon.

nElk0O0rcqChg4OCaXJm_A.review_text: I heard about this bar a few times and thought the pirate theme was cool.  The roommates and I decided to try it one night and found that it was actually close and convenient to our house.  Personally, I didn't think it was all that great.  Yes, it's a neat bar with a great theme and a convenient location, but the venue was small.  It wasn't particularly easy to get drinks at the bar, and the selection of drinks was limited (mostly rum base, but I guess goes with the pirate theme).  I don't know if it was an off night, but it wasn't very happening.  To top it off, rinks were not cheap, but also was not unreasonably expensive.  All in all for me, I would not choose to go there, but would go back if my friends wanted to see it.

bQyQnkp93Lwy61B-JEqvdw.review_text: I wind up staying here the entire night whenever I go to Smuggler's Cove. Why? The drinks are spectacular. I recommend the Smuggler's Rum Barrel if you're craving for a sweet drink. If you want something warm, try the Hot Buttered Rum. It tastes like a creamy, decadent desert. Enjoy watching the bar tenders. They make each dink like it's some sort of fine piece of art. (Much appreciated. ^.^)   If you want that large bowl of rum punch that they set on fire, you'll need to grab a table. I get a volcano every time I go, because I really like the  show.  If I'm going with more than ten people, I usually aim to arrive around 8:30.  If you get here after 9 on a weekend, expect a long wait. But no worries, the bouncers that work at Smugglers tend to be chattery and pretty funny once you strike up a conversation.

_BzeG2XsbHkZOFLZIie3ow.review_text: RACIST BAR!!! AVOID!! Not worth the hype!!! AVOID!!!   Sworn at by bouncer shortly after we asked why he was letting others in before us even tho we were waiting in line for 40mins. Bartender took forever and a day to get to us.. HUUGE jerk who has a god complex while wearing an orange Hawaiian shirt.  Seriously buddy? Check your ego.. You're not Kanye! It was so obvious that he avoided taking our drink orders for as long as he could.  The bar back was rude and randomly swore at us and again under his breath.  We kept getting dirty looks from everyone working there too.      Whole place is gimmicky and you pay extra for rudeness and a pink umbrella in your drink. Save your hard earned money and take it to another bar that actually EARNS your patronage and not expects it like this place.

3lWC0riFiQmnchl1BYZYKg.review_text: My childhood home is in Alameda a few blocks away from the Forbidden Island Tiki Lounge which was apparently started by the same person and I love both places!  The number of tropical drinks on the menu and the degree of service in this place is awesome.  Every drink is so well crafted to the point that I was having fun just watching them make my drink, let alone actually drinking it.  They have an awesome pirate boat theme that ranges from the hull downstairs to the deck when you walk in to the catwalk at the very top.    One of the biggest pros (a con if you arrive too late so get there early!) is that they really don't allow the place to get jam packed.  At no point did I feel shoulder to shoulder with anyone and there is enough seating for most of the bar but priority goes to those with one(or more) of the giant 4-person bowl drinks.    A couple of Aussies got mad(in good fun) when my girlfriend commented on how pretty their drinks were.  "These are man drinks!" They said as they sipped their flower fill goblets.  And the rest of the crowd was equally eclectic and fun spirited.

JBa0VrB4BQFxbprn28vxWQ.review_text: I just got home from the pre-opening party at Smuggler's Cove and I can say firsthand that this place is in a word perfect.  I have been to many peoples share of Tiki and Polynesian bars, and this is without a doubt one of the crown jewels.  Most Tiki bars are way over the top, but the Smuggler's Cove absolutely nails it..  Just the right blend of themed ambiance, excellent music selections and of course the finest collection of rums I have ever laid eyes on.  The menu start to finish, is both tempting and interesting, giving a short but often hilarious introduction to each drink.  There are even vast selections for the few poor souls that don''t care for rum.  I sampled a total of 5 drinks throughout the night and each was expertly prepared and served with a smile.  I even got a chance to meet the owner, Martin Cate, and spending just a few moments with him shows you where the real heart, soul and inspiration came from.  I look forward to working my way through the menu on many subsequent trips and suggest to anyone who is a fan of quality handcrafted cocktails to do themselves a favor and get to the Smuggler's Cove A.S.A.P.

4ilwcgAxGGMW2zbtreOTEQ.review_text: Went on Friday @ 7 and had to wait in line. Not really that big of a deal, and understandable considering they're new. Justin - the fellow outside, is very nice and accomodating for the people who have to wait in line. He gave us a menu, which was very helpful in being able to know what we wanted as soon as we got in. We joked and chatted, and he made the wait bearable. I'd rather wait (and subsequently have others wait) than to be in an over crowded bar with no room to walk, breathe, and talk. Because of this, there was a chair open at the bar downstairs where I sat while the fiance stood, and we got to really get a feel for the place.   The drinks- knock you on your backside strong. For our first round I ordered the Puka Punch, and the boy ordered a J. something rather. We got punch cards to start marking off the drinks we've had getting us that much closer to getting our names on Smugglers Cove manifest. The boy also started his punch card for the Rumbustion society. I like places that award you for trying new things. Especially when those new things involve booze.   Prices: Decent. About $8 and up. For 3 strong, delicious drinks, one rum straight, and one backyard rum flight (3 different types of rum) our total came to $51. Honestly not too bad.  Bartenders: friendly and focused. She was very busy behind the bar but still chatted with us while still being productive. A pet peeve of mine is when you're waiting for a drink and bartender is chatty and stops making drinks to talk. The other bartender (or barback- not totally sure) was also really cool.   Ambiance: the place itself is neat. Definitely, a lot went into it. Borderline disney-esque, but it's a tiki bar so it's an acceptable amount of kitsch, and it's really well done. Plus, I like Disneyland, so F off. We didn't really look around since it was kinda crowded, so I can't say how the upstairs is really.  I'm waiting to go back with a group and see how they do, for that last star.   But definitely check it out, and if there's a wait be thankful for it. It means in the case of a fire, your chances of making it out alive and not trampled are greatly increased. Plus you get time to peruse the menu and feel like a regular when you saddle up to the bar and already know what you want. ;)

mWovMFEZgWE40UVchWHlWA.review_text: Unreal rum-based drinks in a "nautically"-flavored tiki bar. A huge tip, get here EARLY as there WILL be a line of at least a dozen people in front any later! Hey, look for the owner and ask him about all those crazy stuff he sourced and mounted on the wall....with his heart an soul. I just loved the vibe here and again, the drinks are fantastic!!!

ZuCP8O71LHKl6tlXkS7Ziw.review_text: ive been wanting to come here since ive read about it in the 7x7 magazine back in december! and the hot buttered rum in the article was definitely intriguing. my friends and i actually tried coming here about two weeks ago but there was a long line outside and everyone was dressed up in pirates costumes. pirates themed party? felt a little out of place so we left, but some of us came back again this past weekend. luckily there was no line and it wasn't super crowded.  there's 3 stories at smuggler's cove. i didn't look at what's upstairs, but the main floor is just a bar and the downstairs has another bar and couple seating. we spent all our time by the bar with two really nice bartenders. im kinda surprised we never asked for their names because they were super nice! my girl friends and i love those big bowl drinks so we started off with the volcano bowl. it was a hugeeee drink! even with all the ice that was put in it. i liked it because it wasn't as sweet as other places and drinking too much sweet drinks gives me a headache the day after.   i was trying to convince some other people to order the hot buttered rum so i can try but they were all like "it does not sound good...." but a part of me still really wanted to try. i wondered outloud what it tasted like, and one of the bartenders gave us a sample of the housemade spice batter they make it with. completely convinced me to get it. it was delicious! warm, buttery, full of spice and flavor... just not too figure friendly :P the bartender also let us try ginger beer and bitters.  there are so many types of alcohol that i have absolutely no idea what it tastes like so it was kind of hard to order drinks, but we've tried several different rum drinks here and just by reading the description, it's not something i would normally order, but every drink i've had was really good. the bartenders don't just throw in syrup  but actually take the time to muddle the mint leaves, add in bitters, make sure the taste is right.   the drinks are a little pricey but it's definitely a cool place to check out.

wO1BEwXH0tIOT5KtsAWa4w.review_text: Sigh. I hate to leave this review with only 2 stars, as I did love the drinks and the atmosphere. BUT....  The door guy is a complete douche. And so are some of the cry-baby patrons.  My friend celebrated her 30th birthday recently, and decided she would like to make this our first stop of the night. We arrived promptly at 5pm to try and secure some space for our group - we were expecting around 20 people. We were told that we would note be able to save seats and/or space for people that were on their way. Fair enough - totally understandable! It's a small place. No issue there.   We parked ourselves upstairs, starting out with a small circle of chairs for those of us who were already there. We were sharing the upstairs with two other smaller groups of people. Over the course of the next few hours, the two smaller groups finished their drinks and exited. As our group increased in size, it worked out perfectly - we were able to snag their chairs to allow for the growth of our gang.  When the last of us arrived, we actually still had more people than chairs available, but we made due. All was well.   People would wander up the stairs, see that it was a full house, and wander back down to look for space elsewhere. No one seemed bothered. UNTIL...this woman and her man come upstairs. She saw one unoccupied space on a bench seat, and made a bee-line for it. We let her know, "sorry, that seat is taken - she is just down at the bar getting a drink." The woman said nothing, and went downstairs.   Shortly after, the door douche comes upstairs. He proceeds to tell us: "If I have to hear from ONE MORE person that you are turning people away and telling them this is a private party, you will be asked to leave. If someone comes up here, you'd best welcome them with open arms and make them feel comfortable."   Uhm, EXCUSE ME?? Oh uh-uh. Where the hell are people supposed to sit, genius? On my friggin LAP? On the floor in the middle of the room? No. Chairs. Left.  And no one ever called it a "private party." We called it FULL. No place to sit. None. Zip. Zilch.  Every single person in our group purchased multiple...no, NUMEROUS drinks! And at $11-$15 per drink, he should be thanking us for bringing such a large group in, not scolding us for not 'welcoming people' into our group. When some of us objected and tried to plead our case, he rolled his eyes, repeated his words, actually threw up a "talk to the hand" hand, and left.   We also left. And took our money with us. I'd rather spend $15 on a drink elsewhere, where my patronage is actually appreciated.   It's too bad. That Puka Punch was damn good. Not quite $14 good, but still good enough that I would have come back for another.

2hVJwjmDMok8nm05GgosEg.review_text: The only problem I have with Smuggler's Cove is that it is not within easy walking distance (or staggering home distance, depending on whether I'm coming or leaving). This may be a good thing, because if it were, say, right around the corner, I'd probably be there ALL THE TIME.   Their drinks are fantastic and the decor is excellent and their bartenders are of that super booze-geekery variety. You can have a 3 hour conversation with them about bitters; I know people who have done that very thing. Hell, I wasn't part of that conversation and *I* got excited about bitters.  If you've never been, you should go at least once. If you've been before, don't go again, because then it's just harder for ME to find a place to sit when I go.

20GL0Ff4wqmc02S0HyU8dA.review_text: Visited this place on a Tuesday night with a friend. Would've never found it without her, as the blacked out windows and tiny sign are easy to miss in the stormy SF darkness. We were able to go in right away, and though it was pretty much at capacity, people came and went so we were able to get seats at the main floor bar pretty easily. Good place for small groups (6 people max) if you get in at a not-too-busy time.  This is a rum bar. If you like rum, you will be happy. If you do not like rum, there are a few alternate choices, but I definitely love the rum, so I stuck with the house specialty. The menu is enjoyable and gives you quite a bit of information about what you're about to drink. It's fun to peruse even once you've chosen your drink.  The bartender was SUPERB and amazing to watch. The drinks came out with beautiful presentation in addition to tasting wonderful. My friend had a rum barrel to start off with, and i had the hot buttered rum, which was so delicious words fail me. If you have ever had a hot buttered rum before... this will surpass that experience by so much that you will never want to leave. Deliciousness! Some Tiki friends at the bar thought it was pretty sweet though, so if you aren't a fan of brown sugar in your warm rum... maybe this drink isn't for you. My friend enjoyed her rum barrel, which was a mix of multiple rums and juices. Sweet with a bit of bitter to it. Next round was a Perdido Mundo, which was nicely apple-flavored, and Dead Reckoning. Last round was Painkiller and another Buttered Rum for me. The Painkiller was a really interesting combination of sweet, creamy, and rum. Will probably order one for myself next time.  We sipped our drinks and talked, enjoying the ambiance and the company of Tiki enthusiasts at the bar. The bartender kept a good eye on us while also serving the decent number of people rotating into the bar or seated upstairs. He even made sure our seats didn't get overrun when we were talking with other people. Got to meet the owner of the bar, who was a real sweet and knowledgeable guy. Very accommodating and entertaining, bringing paper copies of the menu for some out-of-towners to take home and posing in pictures with various rums used in their drinks.  A wonderful, rum-filled experience. Strong but well-mixed and tasty drinks, a neat atmosphere, and good people. A well deserved 5 stars.

oKrct4Hc8hZNMYXecitLCw.review_text: The goal of my visit to Smugglers Cove was to learn more about rum.   Rum is a booze I really did not know that much about besides Bacardi, Malibu and Captain Morgan. I tried a variety of cocktails and tasted some of the premium rums my companion ordered. I now know I cannot go back to drinking the cheap stuff.  Very non-descriptive on the outside. Lots of decor on the inside. We were able to score seats at the bar. I love bar chairs with seat backs. It was entertaining watching the bartender mix drinks.  I loved looking at the quirky variety of bottles. Worldwide, global and international selection. I now know what Navy Rum and grog are.  I enjoyed my Puka Punch the best. I can't wait to come back and try some other cocktails.

uRtrQFRnOI33GwQ3PA1dVQ.review_text: Incredible drinks and atmosphere! It's like being in a secret pirate hide out.  It's pretty amazing to order a drink and watch the bartender go through so many steps to make it. Seems like much more work than what i'm used to seeing (generic alcohol +fountain flavored soda. Back off, I don't go to fancy bars very often!)   Watch out for the strong drinks, indicated on the menu. One of those gets me pretty darn hammered. Which in turns makes the price of the drink very much worth it.

UsDwIzzhc5Ty5c3m0rLQ2w.review_text: Maybe it was an off night, but all the 3 cocktails I tasted were oh, so sweet. Do pirates drink sugary drinks?  I miss Jade.

zokfv2tiS3NEaAl9IW-LiA.review_text: Ay Ay captain!  This will get you in the mood to watch Pirates of the Caribbean, I literally felt like I was on a Pirate Ship. What a fun place! Come early, this place is small and super packed.

G7hNQXTMtAt94GNU86NXHw.review_text: Also huge Forbidden Island (and-all-things-tiki) fan, Smuggler's Cove has surpassed my expectations in the Bay Area. We booked a hotel in Japantown and were able to walk to SC for our first visit on Dec 21st - Martin did not disappoint. The layout is great - tiki-poly/nautical/pirate all in one. The drink variety is fantastic with old school & modern tiki, old cubans and historical gems.  The bar-huggers were regulars and were very welcoming. There was a "hipster-choad" factor scattered throughout the upstairs/downstairs...but guess that's to be expected with the "all-the-rage" places. Difference is, I think SC has a great timelessness to it that when this crowd fades on to the next big thing, the bar will live on just fine. In my eyes, Tiki-Ti (in LA) is the end-all-be-all of my tiki/poly/pirate-oriented preference, Bourbon & Branch is my utimate in old-school mixology talent - Smuggler's Cove seems to hit somewhere in between in drinks.  It's too bad we had to move away from the area - I think this would have been a regular haunt.

BLdjU7aci4excf9LAd7mQw.review_text: I've come here a handful of times with friends and dates. I love the atmosphere and theme and the cocktails are stellar...if you can get one.   I think in all of the times I've been here, I've been able to get a seat twice, and that was after stalking tables that looked like they were getting ready to leave like asian moms do at the In N Out in Daly City. This place is tiny and always packed. I recommend getting here early if you want to even dream of getting a seat.

FtGEpYCF6DYwiBL4zFMfRA.review_text: Such a fun place. For a girl with a degree in wine and beverages, I am very much a lightweight. My date had to cut me off halfway through my first drink because I was getting more than a little tipsy.   But booze capacity aside, if you're a rum fan like me, Smuggler's Cove is probably as good as you can get in the area. They have all the classics done right, fun spectacle drinks, as well as some expertly crafted newfangled concoctions. Yes, it's an extremely small place, but then what in SF is huge? Just follow our example and go on a Wednesday night. Just do yourself a favor and don't order the lightweight the high octane Painkiller.

3lTgW6aoFiOzoadal2taWQ.review_text: Do you like rum?   If you do, you need to come to Smuggler's Cove.  Fuck it; even if you don't, you need to come to Smuggler's Cove.    Stepping into this place is like stepping into Pirates of the Caribbean at Disneyland, only they have alcohol.  Delicious, amazing, one-of-a-kind drinks you'll never find anywhere else.  The bartenders put a ton of detail and attention into each one; as a result, getting drinks can take a while and they're a bit more expensive than a "normal" bar.  Rest assured, the time and money are well spent.   There can also be quite a line outside.  It's a small place and they're very diligent about the capacity, which keeps the place crowded, but functional.  It's worth standing in line for.  Because the place is small, I do not recommend bringing more than 4-5 people.  You probably won't be able to get a table or an area to yourself.  Order a Jamaican Milk Punch and then tell me it's not one of the most amazing drinks you've ever had.  I dare you.

nInOgePZ3LbH5gSlol62wg.review_text: Amazing drinks! Amazing atmosphere! I ordered the Sorrel hibiscus cocktail and then Don's Own Grog. I am telling you, every drink was better then the last. My friends and I grogged our way to closing time and the polite doorman led us out.  Bartender (short brunette) was working her butt off muddling and shaking the drinks.  One highlight of the night was watching two girls decked out in sequins and hooker boots try to weasle their way in saying they had a friend inside with bottle services to bypass the line. The doorman came back informing them that this bar did not offer "bottle service." Suckers. The only reason this fine establishment does not receive 5 stars is due to the line out front. Bravo!

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: If you're looking for eyecandy, go elsewhere. You won't find it at Smuggler's Cove. Actually, I take that back. After a triple painkiller, dudes started looking like Channing Tatum and chicks started looking like Kate Upton. Ok, wishful thinking as I don't think any chick can top that beautiful rack. Sorry, silicon chin resters don't count. But yah, if you're looking for eyecandy, it's highly unlikely you'll find it here. The crowd kind of reminded me of Tonga Room on a Saturday night. Line included... BEFORE opening. Even though there's 3 levels with 2 bars, the pirates themed, tiki bar space is cramped and gets crowded fast. If you want seats, I highly recommend coming right when they open at 5 pm. With numerous accolades including being named one the "World's 50 Best Bars" by the prestigious Drinks International, it's ALL about the dranky dranks at Smuggler's Cove. They make all their mixes in-house and all the juices are freshly squeezed. None of that cheap sh*t that Tiki Haven, Trad'r Sam's and/or Tonga Room uses. The drink menu is overwhelmingly extensive; there are over 400 rums and over 70 cocktails on the menu (cocktails start at $8). Horrible for indecisive folks like myself. So what to do? Please don't be that douche holding up the line asking 21 questions. Tell the bartender exactly what kind of spirit and flavor(s) you like, and they'll whip up something fantastic for you. I like strong, coconutty, but not too sweet. The bartender suggested the Painkiller (rum, pineapple, oj, and coconut cream). It's was a Friday night and it's been THAT kinda week so when he asked, 2, 3, or 4 oz of rum, I said without hesitation, "4 OZ PLEASE!" He gave me that "slow ya roll, girl" look and suggested I start with 3 oz. Fine, a triple is just fine with me. The bartender asked what else I wanted. I asked him to make a good pineapple mocktail for Mr. NSS. Not only did he make a good one but he made a pretty b*tch one, complete with a girly orchid for him: bit.ly/1CweMil. The Painkiller was exactly what I asked for...strong, coconutty, but not too sweet. One of my gf's had the Batida, a passion fruit cocktail with condensed milk. It was like taking a sip of the tropics, it was absolutely delicious. If you're with a large group, try one of their Scorpion bowls. My other friends shared one and dayam it was strong. Like daaayaaaam, everyone be looking as fine as Channing Tatum and Kate Upton fine...sans the beautiful rack of course.

UzO_9SHVaCPsT3KZbbQ0gg.review_text: i have nothing but good things to say about this place, the decoration, the bartenders, the drinks, its like tiki^5 and don't mention pirates. ever.

awQhT121Pe0R33sukfTyuA.review_text: I really wanted to enjoy my experience here.  I really did like the establishment - 3 (I think?) story, townhouse.  We went downstairs first.  On a not so busy night (15-20 people in this room?), we had problems getting a menu.  Fine, 20 minutes for a menu can be looked over.  We ordered our drinks, and they were good.  Not great, but good.  I don't remember what we ordered, but it was something with Rum (it's a rum bar, right?)  The 3rd floor was reserved for a private party or some sort...  We then, headed to the main floor and sat at the bar. Chatting with the bartender - Well educated (liquorwise) man, wearing a scally cap and talked spirits, and the fun things you could do with them.  Pleasant guy, discussed some of the [legendary] places I've drank at.  Good times were had - Until I asked him to make a drink that a friend developed.  He decided that, there was no good reason to shake a part of the drink, because it was going to be strained into the glass anyway, that that would be unnecessary  and didn't do it - While it did not completely destroy the drink, it made it lesser than it should have been.  I feel like he was being lazy (I read the recipe right off my phone, as I got it via text) and made me feel like this bar disrespected me.  Hence the 2 star rating.  I'm pretty upset about the way the night ended...

ljr1ZSqMDHvWDbYIMjBdpA.review_text: I love this bar! It's pretty cheesy looking inside but that's what makes it awesome! It's like being in Hawaii but in the city. I saw this place on some show on tv and my fiance and I decided to give it a try.  The drink menu is huge and creative.  If you can manage a seat at the bar you can see the entire menu.  We tried four different cocktails and they were all delicious. One of our drinks came with a take home mug too.

Q8TGsARjdIfWsnXqgQYHhw.review_text: Smuggler's Cove is indeed a place to get a great drink.  It's also a great place for some premium rum.  Coming from a whiskey background, I cannot express how foreign the shelves looked to me.  Sure I knew a few good aged rums here and there but as a whole it was a huge learning experience.  The bartenders are quick and skilled and despite the bar being packed, you could still get a drink in a reasonable amount of time.  I definitely need to spend more time here and absolutely recommend it to anyone looking to get their rum on.

djxnI8Ux8ZYQJhiOQkrRhA.review_text: A pirate bar that only serves rum? Sold!   I would have probably been even more excited about Smuggler's Cove if I hadn't been hung over all day and going on less than 4 hours of sleep. The decor and vibe are definitely one-of-a-kind and I respect the fact that the only drinks you can get here are made with rum. Way to keep it real, boys! Pirate real.  The drinks themselves reminded me of being on vacation in Key West. And then it made me sad, because I wasn't on vacation in Key West.   I would love the chance to go back when my taste buds are intact and I'm able to keep my eyes open past 11 pm. Aye aye to that!

Bx1iLCgUyu4HPepkYut4Uw.review_text: This place is definitely somewhere you should go at least once. It really does feel like you're in a Smuggler's Cove in there. I love how the menus give you a bit of history as well. The drinks are really good and the bartenders are friendly. The crowd is also usually pretty fun - a lot of people go here for birthdays or other celebrations.   The only negative is the limited seating (btw, you can only get the Scorpion Bowl if you are seated at a table), however, the fact that it's a smaller place is part of its charm. You will also probably have to wait in line if you go on a weekend, but I've never had to wait for that long (worth it). The drinks are a bit more expensive than the standard SF bar (about $10 each), but since the drinks are creative and unique, I would say the price is on point.   Also, I have never seen so much rum in one place. If you're a rum lover, you will absolutely love Smuggler's Cove.

JsLpIoCJG06cs2SydT4nQw.review_text: Doesn't get much better than the decor in this bar. Literally, you're inside a pirate ship. The drinks were delicious, if a little pricey. Definitely don't go if you're hoping to get wasted b/c you'll end up spending $100. I've only been on a Sunday, so I'm not sure how crowded it would be during a busier time, but I assume it could get quite cozy in there considering the place is a little small. Great place though if you're looking for somewhere a little different to spend an evening....along with yummy sugary rum-filled creations.

Rqg9Rf5ybblqBZ0p5iPn7g.review_text: Smuggler's Cove has a very nondescript exterior - I literally walked by it twice the first time I came here.  But inside, it really looks like the inside of a pirate ship.  We're talking Disney-level theming.   The drinks here are pricy, but I think you get what you pay for.  You can choose from something like a ten page menu, which is filled with rum history and trivia.  My favorite so far is the Batida- condensed milk, passionfruit, blended with ice! Yummm  Be sure to get here either very early or very late - it is a very small space, and there will very likely be a line out the door between 11-1.

vcOtDqQ2Cc731kFjklFeBg.review_text: This was the perfect place to celebrate my 21st birthday!!!!!   I had zero plans and an old friend from high school suggested this place. We got off at Powell BART and walked around to kill time before midnight and then we walked all the way over to the bar from there. It was a quick walk but the bar is also close to Civic Center BART.   You have to wait in line to get in but it wasn't too bad for a Friday night. (My birthday was on a Saturday! How convenient). They let us in at 12:01! The timing couldn't have been more perfect. The bouncer was all confused since he was checking 4/29 all night and my birthday was 4/30. He wished me a happy birthday and we went in and someone told us our best bet to get a drink was to go downstairs.   The place was PACKED and extremely hot. It took a while to get a drink but it was perfect because you can't order the Volcano Bowl ($36) unless you have a table and we totally lucked out and got one!   I busted out my camera to take a video of the drink arriving and getting set on fire but little did I know, I was about to record the bartender getting the entire bar to sing me happy birthday! It was amazing!   The drink was STRONGGG but the three of us was easily able to polish it off. The table next to us got the same drink and was splitting it between 10 people!  I would definitely come back again. I didn't get a chance to check out all the awesome decor. This place is totally inconspicuous. You could easily walk right by it but if you spot the green and red light out front, you've made it.

NR6Y46Ni2JjQcj4vDbqKUA.review_text: SCORPION BOWL!!  It's a small place and can get pretty crowded/hot so don't come with a big group but make Smuggler's Cove your first stop of the night and the Scorpion Bowl your first drink and it'll be a good night :)

xJ7qQYYdeeegz0lKS2rP-g.review_text: My friend calls me up and says, "Lets go to a pirate bar". You don't have to be Miss Cleo to figure out what I said to that.  You could have called me Rob Bass, cause I come to get down. Instantly you know the place is happening, for better or worse. There's and indoor waterfall, pool (not people pool, just pool of water), pirate crap, and the whole nine. It's got the vibe, it's so cool.  Usually, when I go out, I get beer. It's not that I particularly favor beer, but it's usually something a bartender can't f*ck up. As a person that used to bartend myself, and considers himself a connoisseur of fine libations, I consider the bartenders in San Francisco some of the WORST!   F*uck off if you disagree, just go ask for a cocktail. I guarantee you won't be talking that mess after you're subjected to their bartending prowess. I'd say most bartenders in SF have about five drinks in their repertoire, and one of them is a draft beer.  P.S. just because a drink is strong, doesn't mean it's good. Mixing drinks is lot like cooking; some people consider it the same thing. If you like cake, you wouldn't dump a whole bag of sugar in it cause you liked sugar, would you? Then why would a bartender do that with a drink?   Ahoy, I spot the bartender and start looking over their drink menu. Now, this place specializes in rum drinks, and I love me some rum! It actually was a bit too much for my senses, but I settled on something, and was quite pleased with what I got. I should say I was more then pleased. Some of the best drinks I've had, most definitely in SF.  Their drinks cost a bit more than other places, but in their defense, the drink are delicious, strong, and huge...a bit like myself...ah ha :) Seriously, they're good. Take special note of drinks that have a small icon of a barrel by their name, it mean's they're filled with extra love (by love I mean alcohol).    Technically there are three floors, but the lay of the land is a bit odd. With all that space, the place feels smaller than it should. I don't think it's anything a good interior designer couldn't fix, but this a small complaint that doesn't detract from the awesome experience I had.   Hot girls Arrr, I'd plunder their booty any day. The weird seating makes it easier to get closer to them; you almost have no choice. I could think of worse things than being smushed between hot women.  You bet your arse I'm going back to this place.

tQJJtHShOujzml37qTX_4Q.review_text: Go when it's not busy. The space is small. There are three floors, all of which are very small and confining.   The door is easy to miss. Do not be afraid to push through that unmarked door...  The decorations are pretty impressive. The theme was planned out and consistent - so much so that I would say there is a vibe..  The drink menu is enormous and each drink has a lengthy description plus some history. It's fun to peruse as long as you have personal space and some extra lighting.   The bartenders are really into their craft.
