In addition to making good drinks, there is a fair bit of show: flourished mint slapping, orange peel swirling, pineapple leaf plucking and the strategic placing of paper umbrellas. I never knew a paper umbrella could be opened so deftly. This also means drink orders take awhile...  For those who like fruity drinks - this is the place for you. Don't like the taste of alcohol? Then head on over!

tH-o90F9XPyVvJ1sFP_rTA.review_text: super fun bar to hang out in. i don't get the people who rated this place one star. oh wait no dj playing hip hop and rap! thats it. most of the "disneyland" decor is actually authentic and looks cool. there is a bit of a wait for drinks but if you can drink one mixed drink every 20 mins for 2 hrs you will be crawling out of there.(the drinks are strong) plus each has to be put together right or it would taste like crap. all of my many drinks were perfect! we also had a designated driver and the bartender was making up  great tasting n/a drinks for him. show up early and get your drink on!

dOnGTPEjoqNe3_bAIUMLIw.review_text: This bar with its 400-plus rums and nautical decor transports you into a fascinating era and makes you think that being a pirate during the right era could have been the best life ever. Enough said! Drink this at Smuggler's Cove: The Tradewinds -- While hitting you hard it is a celebration of coconut that is lighter than a pina colada  with a combination of dark and white rum and apricot liqueur.

PA3lwNBQgEEFVjWiF2ryVw.review_text: I loved this place. My friends and I showed up at this wonderfully low key door, with a wonderfully man-bunned (apparently that is what many other yelpers are focused on) door man. He was sarcastic and funny in a quirky way. After some funny banter he informed us where the best seats were in the house and noted that "drinks you can get, but seats are hard to come by". We found 4 seats on the upstairs mezzanine that over looks the bar. If you work in the service industry then please watch the way these guys work. One guy taking orders, and One bartender busting out handcrafted concoctions faster than the speed of light. Each drink has its own character so once it comes time to garnish, the speed daemon slows down and carefully places each piece of decor strategically on its designated glass with utmost and precision.   The quirky sarcasm, the friendly banter, and the amazing drinks makes this bar well worth the visit.

4MzTss4Hn2sVvwb317xxpw.review_text: This place was pretty cool and had a dark, boat-like, tiki ambiance.  It was way expensive, though!  The drinks were totally delicious, but I would come here for probably one drink and then go elsewhere.  It's cramped inside and it's sort of a pain to come with a large group because there is really limited space, especially for seating.  I think it would probably be best to come on weekday night or some less busy time--I came on Friday night around 9pm.  My friend whose birthday it was had a lot of fun, but he wasn't paying for his drinks...

BdWtanx8M38CzsUOHVYiow.review_text: I like this spot but the rum cocktails are pricey. Came here on a Friday night and the experience was good. We stood outside for about 25 minutes before entering the speakeasy. It was cramped the entire time with our group of five. The crowd was pretty diverse and the bartenders were great.

VbE1LgUcOPxkeWZ8eS6OVA.review_text: I arrived on a Sat night at 10pm, I had to wait in line for about 5 min, not too bad. I had no idea that the crowd was REALLY yuppie that night, from the pictures it looks like its kind of a dive bar!   I had one drink (it SO was crowded that out of frustration my man and I left) and the one drink was REALLY good, they have a really great drink list and I would love to come back again and try some more. But next time I would go at 6pm and leave at 9, so I could really enjoy my Rum!  Go early, you will have a better experience!

VHdY6oG2JPVNjihWhOooAQ.review_text: I was just engaging in a work pod conversation about Smuggler's Cove and some pure genius just came from my lips. Such quality stuff  - that I just felt compelled to share it in a review update:  "Smuggler's Cove - soooo cute, that it just makes me want to drink."  That is all.  Trust.

L66VzwBsfbVDit0EgqOuhg.review_text: I never thought of myself as a rum drinker, but after one trip to this bar I am about start. Strongest drinks in SF, so be wary. Went for a friend's birthday and had a smashing good time.

irkRHMqg9oSt7lv3OSiNkA.review_text: My yelp buddy Roy N. told me about this wonderful place and I'm glad that I took his advice and checked the place out with my other yelp friend Maureen recently. The place has three levels to it. Downstairs there is a colored fountain in the corner and a full bar. The middle level has a bar and lots of interesting Caribbean and pirate decor around the area. Upstairs there are cushioned seats and a few tables and chairs. The view is great.   We mostly sat at the bar area and had a few strong fruity cocktails. I forgot what I had, but one of the drinks was a pina colada and one had passion fruit in it. The prices weren't bad at around $10.00 for a large drink. The bartender is cool and friendly. He helped me decide on a drink. Maureen wanted to try the Scorpion bowl at one point which was HUGE! It comes in a skull bowl and cost $35.00 I think. For some reason she changed her mind. That would've been great to try, lol!   After a couple of drinks we sat upstairs and another yelp buddy of mine, Tom R. joined us with a friend of his. He's really cool and friendly. He liked the place to and he's been to lots of bars so that says something. So if you like anything pirate or tropical themed, you'll love this little place! It's kind of hard to spot from the street. I almost walked past it. Maureen had to say, Sandy, it's here.

nfzdme1_TjrCHkQu3wV3lA.review_text: I came in for a couple of rounds during one weeknight.  While not quite dark outside, within, the Hut was near capacity and the Boathouse more than half-full. For this light a crowd I considered myself lucky: this place is already a legend among cocktail fans in general and of course rum enthusiasts specifically.    How does one even approach reviewing it with something new to say?  Since it was my first visit, I'll write down my impressions.  To start, the location is great. Even with its high profile, it's not exactly in the center of the city; I'm sure that helped keep the crowd lighter than it could be.  The atmosphere is first-rate: very dark with flowing water and nautical/piracy/tiki accents; having never been there or, really, having seen all many pictures, it looked almost exactly how I imagined it.  It took me a long time to select my drinks. Each selection meant sacrificing the opportunity to try something that sounded equally intriguing.  With a bar of this caliber I approached my cocktails as I would a meal.  I went with a special whose name I've since forgotten -- a lighter drink, finished with club soda -- as an appetizer and then a more traditional selection, a Daquiri #3 for my main course, playing to my fondness for the savory grapefruit and Hemmingways.   I drank slowly.  Both cocktails exceeded the fine reputation of the bar, with fresh fruit juices and secondary liquors blending lightly with the primary rum to the degree neither seemed dominated by the spirit, they only bring out elements you rarely notice.   As the Boathouse began to fill I left, fully satisfied with my experience.  A legend, and deservedly so. I doubt I'll ever visit the City without returning here.

dATCEFwZE_qezmonyMwfKw.review_text: Hello friends.  I've made a decision to go to Smuggler's Cove with work friends every Sunday night to help celebrate the end of my week (my Friday, I'm a chef) and generally just to go to this awesome bar. It's walking distance from my night job, so why not?  Smuggler's Cove is great. You walk up to the door and don't realize it's a bar until you see little letters on the plain-faced door that reads the name of the bar. I go there and the bouncer Charles already knows me by name and recognizes me when I come in, he's super awesome and informative (informative as in he'll ask around for the owner of the car parked across the street and tell them to move it or they'll get towed. Good looking out!). The atmosphere is crazy awesome. The place is a pirate ship: Blowfish lights, the maiden of the ship on the wall, the anchor on the celing, might as well call this place Shenanigans!  The drinks I've had there are wonderful so far. I'm not a big fan of rum, unfortunately, so I'm trying to break myself in by ordering what I know (anything gin-based) and sneaking sips of my friends' drinks and deciding for myself what I'd like to eventually try.  They have a list there that you can fill out of all their drinks on the menu, including drinks that you need multiple people to drink it with, and when you're done filling out the list, you're eligible for various prizes! What a cool incentive to drink your ass off!  I wish I had more thumbs to up with for this place. I'm making it a regular part of my week. SC rocks!

QBsKltossupN0_XQZFKcJg.review_text: Bartenders downstairs were great, but the bouncer closing down the bar was downright rude for no apparent reason.  Too bad, won't be back again.

GrktSJ7Bv9t37gwDLIlAwg.review_text: This is a good place to have a fun time and impress people. Maybe it's a little gimmicky, but tiki bars are pretty unique to the Bay Area and chances are that an out-of-towner has never been to one. The drinks aren't exactly the strongest, but it's definitely a fun place to be drinking in. The upstairs has the best view of all the pretty lights and decked out ceiling. The ground level is pretty much regulars. The den is equipped with another full bar and the most spacious. I advise going early or going late if you care about seating. Otherwise, this place can get pretty crowded. I'm not sure if I'd come with a group larger than 6 or 8. Another nice touch I like is that this place is unmarked, other than a beacon of light out front. It's kind of like walking into a tiki speakeasy. Hawaiian shirts are advisable. Warning: menu is large and lighting is dim.  The hot buttered rum is my favorite here. It's not just buttered, but butterscotched, more like. It's delicious and good for any night. It's got a stick of cinnamon and all. The queens park swizzle was okay, was overflowing with ice. The kona cocktail was strong. There are several serves-4 bowls: volcano, scorpion, and arrack punch. They have a variety of bowls so it's cool seeing which one you get. They'll bring it to you and do a mini fire show of it too.

9Zmk2oU8XmhO7nOEiAjzSQ.review_text: Loved Smuggler's Cove! The drinks are amazing, and the decor puts you in the rum-guzzling mood. Go early though, cuz it gets super busy. Remember, many of these unique cocktails take a bit longer than your everyday "rum & coke" type of order. So you gotta be patient, but the drinks are fantastic.

CBwPegIptHW0vwGsaxcfHQ.review_text: You would think a place that is all about rum and everything rum and is, of all things, rum... would know how to make a Mojito.  Well they don't... what a bummer.    Anywho.  Yes very impressive rum selection (200+, I think?)  But I am not the biggest rum person, unless I am on the beach somewhere tropical where I will drink rum like water and end up as a drunk dumbass, getting one hell of a sun burn because the rum made me forget to put on sun screen.    So yeah... although (IMHO) they can't make a Mojito worth a shit... they have all sorts of other mixed drinks - like hot buttered rum - that perhaps they are more keen at making.    Oh if you like beer, DO NOT COME HERE.  (Meaning, they have a piss poor selection).  The interior kinda reminded me of Rainforest Cafe meets Trader Vic's meets the Tiki Bar meets... you get the picture.

iLjMdZi0Tm7DQxX1C1_2dg.review_text: Hot. Buttered. Rum.  Call me in the morning.  #bestholidaydrinkever

ouyEldOJysLZhbSoD5O7wQ.review_text: I wonder how many women out there got pregnant as a direct result of this place? Seriously, some of the drinks are so strong they need to be served with a condom that fits over the top of the glass.   Get smug, stay smug.

KtufTH6tYN0wzQIsedXtFA.review_text: It's a really cute place that lives up to its name. The front door is discrete but once you walk in, there's no doubt you're in the right bar. The decor and lighting makes it feel very underwater-esque, but not in a tacky way.  Drinks:  Painkiller-I didn't have any because I'm allergic to pineapple, but my friend seemed to really like it.  Jamaican Milk Punch-I didn't have any because I'm lactose intolerant, but my friend seemed to also really like it.   **Pretty sure he ordered both those drinks so I wouldn't swoop some -___-  Hibiscus Rum Punch-Sweet and delicious! I definitely tasted the alcohol but if you're a big drinker, this might taste like tea to you.  Hot Butterscotch Rum-Warm, smooth, and comforting. They put a cinnamon stick in it which is adorable, but kind of annoying when it keeps hitting you in the face while you're trying to take a sip. Or maybe that's just me.   Tip: There is no food here. Like none. Prepare accordingly.   *Thumbs Up!*

-kjqzgbWnoUteHiNnWJ51w.review_text: I wanted to keep the Rummy Tropical Vacation going so we decided furlough from the chirrens would be at Smuggler's Cove.  Drinks- delicious, but lacking the desired garnish of small colorful umbrellas & chunks of fruit.  The flaming skull drink for 4 smelled like burning hair - not sure if it was the drink or the bartender.  Space- huge step down from "jade" (rip) - low rent version of Thunder Mountain- holes in ceiling covered over w black garbage bags- bright lighting unfortunately balances out the rum goggles, just in case you're on the make for a Snuggler at the Smuggler.  People- apparently the Younger Set interpret Tropical Drinks as "Pirate Bar" rather than "Polynesian Paradise". I was hoping for the latter. Smugglers Cove is the former.    Summation: The drinks are better than Tradr Sams or the ol'Caribbean Zone (RIP- totally showing my age), but the decor & garnishments were just not worth the price of the sitter.

8OShcUSeCEUejamJoeGmvw.review_text: Really funky, fun bar which emphasizes the great Tiki bar style of mid century. Drinks were potent and expertly made in front of us. Sunday night it was a busy place. Tiny footprint on three levels. Different. Worth the trip if you're a bar hopper or devotee. Be prepared for close quarters most nights. Lots of pride in what they do.

HAv257_IVJnQT0ZIL8Nn-Q.review_text: So ok I realized I sort of went on a tiki bar rampage this weekend. Went to both Trader Vic's and Smuggler's Cove (Ironically I think they might be affiliated with one another because some of their drinks are rather named the same). However I will say this place has much more character. The decor inside is totally decked out tiki island. All wood, thatch and mesh reeds lines the walls, cargo boxes and benches to sit at. Totally awesome.  Drinks range from potent to mmild and sweet to super sweet. I have had the painkiller, the grog and the fogcutter. I think the painkiller was probably my most potent and it wasn't too bad. A good balance of sweet with a little bit of a kick.  This place produces a fun crowd as well. I mean how can you be surly or angry at such a place.   There is a standard selection of beer and their special (which I think is Thirsty Bear's Vanilla ale) for those who want to stick to more traditional things.    There is little branding on the outside, just a black door with the words, "Smuggler's Cove" written kind of small. This is important if you get here early and you can't find it :)  Overall a fun place, not a regular stop but definitely a place to celebrate or at least try once :)

cqJ1s8WPm7asYW_I4tfXxg.review_text: This place is hilarious! It's like a tribute to Pirates of the Caribbean. The drinks are good and I adore rum. But the atmosphere is really kitschy, so if you're taking a date there make sure they know you're joking.

XcuwFBs8RN5MQeFVjQMHJg.review_text: My boyfriend and I started coming to Smuggler's Cove after we attended his office Christmas Party here a year ago.  He's a cocktail connoisseur extraordinaire, and after going in search of the perfect mai tai over the past year at places like "Trader Vic's" et. al. we decided the SC Mai Tai takes the cake!  The atmosphere is just the right blend of kitschy (not tacky) and glamorous; dimly lit and with walls lined with bamboo and Latin & Polynesian ephemera. It even boasts its own romantic "Pirates of The Caribbean"-style mini lagoon! It gets packed in this small space quite quickly though, so plan your visit ahead of time.  *So many* delicious and historic cocktails to choose from on the menu, as well as a few SC exclusives like "The Chadburn" which features house-made chocolate mole bitters (It's one of my all time favorites).

_JRfDp4rh_h2JjIFmM4_JA.review_text: I don't really drink much anymore, but I'm adamantly pro-pirate.  So when someone said, "Hey, let's go to the pirate bar!" I was all, "Okay."  And it's pretty sweet.  It kind of felt like being inside a Jimmy Buffet song except actually cool.  There are three floors, two bars, various implements of tikitude, a waterfall-fountain-thing, and a lot of booty hanging from the ceiling.  And it's all about the booty.  You should particularly go if you like rum.  So much rum.  Menus full of rum.  I got a dark and stormy (rum and ginger beer), squished myself into a corner seat, and talked with friends.  It was stiflingly crowded, but everyone was in such high spirits that I didn't really mind that I was close enough to see up their noses.  They were nice noses!  I can safely say that if I were the type of gal to frequent the bar scene, this is where I'd go when I wanted to be drunk and extra-silly.  Plus, if you take your friends here, you'll really impress them...provided your friends are pro-pirate.  But...if they're not pro-pirate, are they really friends?

pmx7I4YUau3RHczvKmXeeQ.review_text: Great drinks you won't find anywhere else in SF.  Nice bartenders.  Ship-shape!

a5QFVKKG8MV_dYIegIGVKg.review_text: Came here once on a Saturday night.  It was completely packed and there is a wait outside.  However the drinks were well worth the wait.  Had a zombie and a few others that I don't remember, but they were all great.  Would come again.

zz_N38dhBx6GaIlMXL3UTA.review_text: This is probably my favorite bar in the world. Its really that good.   Amazing Pirates of the Caribbean/tiki/tropical getaway fee withl some of  THE best mixology in the bay area. If you like a well-balanced drink and a spot with personality, this is the place for you.  The owner wants to take you on a tour through the history of rum through a menu of mostly rum based drinks. My personal favorites are the Jet Pilot (about 12 ingredients, including some spices like cinnamon that give it real character), the classic Mai-Tai (done right), and the Fog Cutter. Everything I've tried is unique and delicious, so you won't be disappointed.  There's also a rum tasting menu, I have yet to try, but it is really exhaustive. Something like 100+ rums. However I can recommend a snifter of the house rum, made exclusively for Smuggler's Cove. Just have it neat with a drink and you're good to go. Its hard to talk about this place and not want to go for a drink. As a matter of fact...........(door slams)

w7RP1MZad3YO7Vjgp3s3Dg.review_text: How do I begin to write my review about this place.. Lets say that I will never ever come back to this place again. It was 12:00 am, it was definitely not crowded inside, there was about 10 people outside waiting to get in, there were 12 people that just stepped out- WHY WON"T YOU LET US IN- TRAY/TREY???  What is the point of making us wait outside when it is definitely not crowded inside? Power trippin' maybe???  Finally at 12:30 am, we got in.   Ordered drinks which took 20 minutes to make - I respect that I know they make good drinks.   At 1:30 am, TRAY/TREY comes over and says you can finish your drink upstairs and so my friends did. But then he kept saying get out, get out and the bartenders were telling him specifically to let us finish the drink  but he kept on and on about how he wants us to leave. Finally my friend said that it is not fair that they are kicking us out when he specifically told us that he will let us finish our drinks upstairs. My friend said I will mention this to yelp , how  bad your customer service is.  Then finally TRAY" said that YELP is of no value to their place. He specifically said that "THEY DO NOT CARE ABOUT YELP!!"   WOW- I was appalled, flabbergasted by his remark. My head was spinning with outrage and anger when I heard this. I did not say a word, kept my cool, which most ELITE members do and instead jumped in a cab.   All I can say is that I hope Smuggler's cove management will reevaluate their employees performance, especially their bouncer Tray/Trey.    People of the ELITE YELP world-  I suggest to not come or even come back to this establishment.  THEY DO  NOT CARE ABOUT YELP.

ghkZQqPGd-p-VHhPDvmCJQ.review_text: Best place to go for happy hour!  Can't wait to go back.

6qfjiqFH9L-vYixEm1oADg.review_text: At first I felt really old here but then the group screaming about Spring Break left and I realized it was just that one loud, obnoxious group. The cocktail list was impressive but kinda overwhelming. The hot, stuffy interior makes you think you are in the Caribbean. All in all, I'd say it's just okay.

ywwTdqHQKbXyHa-gEFc4Sg.review_text: Who doesn't like anything themey. I think I just made up a word. Anyways, we rolled into this joint after our unfortunate dinner in the Marina. I love the Pirates of the Caribbean theme and wished Johnny Depp was nearby. There are three levels to this place, we decided to hang out downstairs. Please do not text while taking the stairs, your phone may just end up in their makeshift lagoon. (just sayin). it gets busy so you may want to come early and grab a seat. Seriously, the crowds aren't moving. My gfriend ordered a delicious hibiscus drink for me and loved every sip. I'll have to come back for their hot buttered rum drink.

4W1D-dUW7bC_CJYgslzUqA.review_text: Be sure you come with someone whose company you enjoy. Because the drinks can take forever and a half to make -- but they're good, I guess.

V5JmPxwEpuWGz_8INHfvdA.review_text: So much fun. Drinks are good atmosphere is awesome. Staff is friendly esp bartender Justin !! He's the best- thanks for so a fun evening

Aeo_Z1FwOjRs6UHdJ3NRHg.review_text: It's a pirate bar, so it's worth a visit just for the theme, but the novelty wears thin when you see the prices and taste the fare.  It's kind of like the restaurant on The Pirates of the Caribbean: once you've done it, you don't need to do it again.

QazKeBp4oLJfpl9N1PXoAQ.review_text: Very diverse menu and everything, not surprisingly, comes with rum. This is probably the first time I've seen a bartender move with such grace. Also, he worked by himself and managed to fill everyone's orders. He is very approachable if you wanted suggestions or just wanted to ask him a question. He definitely knows his alcohol.  The bowl drinks are pretty expensive, albeit really cool to gawk at. But I would go to Tradr Sam's for cheaper, and stronger bowl drinks.

hZxmfGMDiWEm81kYBaMWsQ.review_text: As a rum junkie, I had read about Smugglers Cove long before I ever knew I would be living in San Francisco. It sounded like an awesome place even from Washington, D.C. and I actually ripped out an article on it and saved it in my Places-To-Go-In-California folder (forgive me--I'm a bit of a travel dork). And then I moved within walking distance-yay!  I couldn't wait to get here so in my first week here I went by myself, sat at the bar, and read the menu like it was a novel.   While the concept of this place could easily go the way of an island themed TGIFridays in the wrong hands(think pieces of flair), here it's executed to perfection. They love rum and represent the places where its a major part of history so well. I feel like I'm learning something on every visit, while enjoying some of the best cocktails I've ever had.   Do I wish it was bigger? Yes. On my last visit it seemed like the ordering process was smoother--in times past its required a lot of patience to get a drink. As a result I haven't gone as often as I might otherwise--there's no way I would go on a Thurs-Sat. night, and their drinks are a little bit much for a weeknight tipple. That makes it more of a special occasion place, which keeps the mystique high.  I have a ways to go to drink through my cocktail list and get the fancy hat, but I'm enjoying the pursuit...

NSIsTiFU9mVmmwxQk2JBYA.review_text: A pirate's life it is!  This little hole in the wall is a great place to meet friends, as long as you don't have that many of them.  The reason I give it four stars instead of five is despite being three stories, there really isn't much room to sit/stand.  But if you do find a spot, wow.  The atmosphere is great and menu extensive.  I highly recommend telling the bar tender what you are in the mood for and let him guide you.  I didn't go wrong using this method.  Enjoy!

dJA-57J_ZdzMVA5O-jn63w.review_text: We had drinks here before dinner on a Tuesday around 6PM.  We went here because I saw a cocktail attributed to this bar in an article in the Wall Street Journal a while back.  OK, so this is a pirate/tiki themed bar, corney, but that's what you're going there for, right?  The evening we were there there was an event going on upstairs for someone who had drank through their rum list, so we sat at the bar downstairs.  It is a bit dark and kinda cold and very themey, but it is what it is.    We looked through the menu and aked the bartender a few questions (I adore rum, but hate sweet drinks).  He knew the menu inside and out and made a couple great recommendations (albeit, one with 151 rum that was pretty powerful)..  The drinks were great.  They are craft-made, so it does take a little time, but our bartender was well versed in the menu and worked quickly.  When things got busy it did take a little while to get your next round with one guy making all the drinks.  Over the course of an hour and a half, the place did start to fill up, so getting there early was a good idea.  They have a huge selection of great rums, I look forward to gong back to try a couple of them (a lot of people were sippiing them like you would a great scoth.  Definitely worth the trip, although we were a little tipsy for our dinner reservations later that night.

CDZWiihsmtiP-cgBRSSljA.review_text: Went here for happy hour after getting a haircut from the lovely Alissa at Oxenrose, and she reminded me about it - I had heard about this place, but didn't know it took Jade's old place.  Jade had a killer happy hour, but I didn't know Jade took over their place.  Smuggler's Cove can trace its origins back to Forbidden Island in Alameda - same owners - and that's some good heritage.  Get here early - the drinks take a while to prepare, and when it's packed, you'll wait.  A worthwhile wait, but a wait nonetheless.  We only stayed for one drink, since it got pretty packed by 5:30 or 6pm or so.  Gorgeous decor, and the tri-level layout and waterfall inherited from Jade only adds to the tiki mystery.  A fine addition to Hayes Valley, and I'm sure I'll stop by again.  It's not my favorite tiki bar - that would have to be in Vegas, but I'm hoping there's a genuine tiki room in Hawaii that I've yet to discover.  Check out Smuggler's Cove if you're in Hayes Valley - and no, you won't find any Smuggler's Blues here.  (yeah, I had to leave you with a Glenn Frey/Miami Vice reference.  And oh yeah, the H is O.)

0S8CfLtHDM2IOoDxsHN-eg.review_text: This place is pretty much a split between good and bad. It's good once you go in because the decor is nice and drinks are abundant.  This place is bad because it takes forever to get in. So much that it's not even worth the wait in the cold cold San Francisco summer.  I'm pretty sure I got sick from this place.

BdLNljl87KXDyluzk7YBlg.review_text: Met a friend for drinks, and had a blast.  I'm not a rum drinker, normally it's just Jameson's and Guinness, but the bartender (Tall Brunette working on a Thursday night on the middle level) set me up with a tasting and her class was exceptional.    I look forward to stumbling home from this place often...

9aZJMOox-6E0W_pBnaVZlA.review_text: Ugh. I HATE this place. Hatred. Hate.   I get that it's supposed to be kitschy and Disneyland-esque in design and yeah, it reminds me of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride, but seriously, this bar sucks. It takes about 15 minutes to get the bartenders to get to you and after that, another minimum 10 min for them to actually make the drinks.   Credit card? Good luck. Add another five minutes minimum.  All the drinks are extremely sugary. Read: hangover.   The crowd is really weird too. There were a bunch of tourists last time I was there and they had all brought their gigantic suitcases.   I can't think of a bar I hate in SF more than this one. Big thumbs down.

jntRt0kG_jk_hS78baaTnA.review_text: It's totally kitschy, reminded me a lot of Disneyland or what I imagine Disneyland to be like only because it's been years since I've gone there.  I wouldn't say that's a bad thing it adds to the whole tiki experience.  They're technically opening on Dec 8th, but in the meantime they have several preview parties.  I was lucky enough to attend one of these previews thanks to a friend of mine.    The drink menu is impressive; it has a lot of fun information about rum, etc.  Take time to read through it it's worth it.  The drinks do take a while to make, but good things come to those who wait.  I had the Mary Pickford which ended up being a little too citrusy for my taste, but I wouldn't fault the bar for that just my own fickleness. Next I had the Tradewinds which had just the right amount of coconut and wasn't overly sweet.  My favorite was my friend's Smuggler's Rum Barrel.  If you're only going to get one drink I highly suggest getting the Smuggler's Rum Barrel.    I'll definitely be back maybe post the initial rush of people after the official opening.

PGoR29MCe3chANls8sTfhg.review_text: Get there right at 5pm to be sure to get a seat at the bar.  Tiki-bar atmosphere is fun, but the real excitement is learning about all of the different rums and sampling some truly terrific tastes.  Great time! Can't wait to return.

U2VIrx1x9nGZGBuftjqkCg.review_text: Before I found this gem, I had always thought that $10 for a watered down bottom shelf was the norm in the city.  That is no longer the case.  Captain Sparrow would hail in from the Caribbean if he was alive (or real).   The drinks from this place are made to perfection.  It may take them 5 minutes to make a drink, but it's well worth the wait.  Warning: they are dangerously yummy. The taste of alcohol may be masked by the delicious ingredients but the drinks are strong.  If you're driving into the city, stop after the second drink or else... If you are taking the cab, have at least 5!  Although you may not be coherent after the third or remember your name after the fifth.  I must have tried every drink on the menu (beside the ones made without rum) and not one of them was remotely bad.  The Sidewinder's Fang is my absolute favorite, but the Scorpion is the ultimate party drink.     Ambiance is great!  Drinks aside, the decorations alone are worth a visit.  This is a tiny hole-in-the-wall tiki bar, so don't plan on getting tables or seats unless you're here on a Tuesday.

pn1c8hAuneMQT5a9qz2NmA.review_text: Great rum bar with top notch decor. Great place to unwind and be transported to a different world... if you can get in, that is.  Pros: -Huge selection of rum -The decor is a spectacle in itself, probably not as impressive you're not a fan of "theme bars"  Cons: -Place is tiny so it can't fit a lot of people. Space will be cramped and wait times will be long -A bit on the pricier side, especially since the bartenders measure all the alcohol

icjBMlxwCcMJQqwy1APntA.review_text: Not worth it. Bouncer is a total jerk. The space is so tiny. There are so many other places to go in SF that I wouldn't waste my time getting harassed or treated poorly here.

VEOD6Y-w1UoRnxzJZjTI1g.review_text: Great place- fun pirate interior, try the spiced buttered rum!

L-DgxkfGNFe6KFdI7kIznw.review_text: Stopped in here as soon as they opened (5pm) on a Saturday.  The drinks are excellent, though keep in mind that 95% of them are rum-based.  That said, we sampled gin and tequila-based drinks as well, and all were quite good.    The prices seemed to be $9-11 for most of the drinks, with $2 off during happy hour (I believe 5-6pm).  The drinks take a bit of time to make, so I can imagine that it might be hard to get a drink when (/if) this place gets crowded.  But there is both an upstairs and downstairs bar (with additional room on a top floor) so I imagine they do a decent job of keeping up.  The ambiance is wacky and entertaining and overall it was a fun place to spend a couple hours.

EiwxlbR8fb68lMgEXhcWKA.review_text: This is possibly a drunken post, possibly. I have seriously never had such good cocktails as I had at Smuggler's Cove.  I would have never known about this little gem of a place had it not been for an awesome Gilt City rum tasting certificate that I picked up a few months ago. Redemption ends on Wednesday so I had to take the opportunity to check it out.   I'm not a rum fan, in fact I am by FAR not a rum fan at all, but the tasting was a good learning experience and the bartender Bill made it fun. He explained the origins and why the tasting is setup the way that it is as well as what we should be looking out for when tasting. It was almost like wine, except much, much stronger.  Afterwards, inebriated, we continued on their amazing list of rum based cocktails all of which were delicious (like the Zombie and Puka Punch) and enjoyed the many folks who were getting volcanos being lit up at the bar. This is such a fun spot because it's not too big to be commercial but not too small to be cramped. It's just intimate enough to be fully decorated in Pirate and shipwrecks to be a great time.

MjlNTynslY_aLDTfGODuIg.review_text: a pirate ship themed bar with 3 levels each representing a different level on the ship.  friendly bar tenders, pays attention to detail, crafts drinks artistically, extremely friendly  strong drinks, very strong, the volcano is something a sight to behold, especially when he does the evil laugh while sprinkling cinnamon to create flame balls  did i say strong drinks?

DlwexC7z88ymAzu45skODw.review_text: This is one of my all time favorite bars in SF. They've blacked out the windows and there's pretty much no signage out front, so stepping through the front door is a bit like stepping into a whole new world, which is exactly what they want.  Step past the front curtains and the friendly bouncer, and you're suddenly in the hold of a pirate ship. It's dark in here, but there's three levels to explore, and the menu is a lesson in Tiki culture. This is a rum bar, and you can tell they have a passion for serving fantastic specialty rum drinks.  I always get the Volcano if I'm bringing friends- it's a fun one :-)  Unrelated but I'll share anyway: I used to come here all the time back when it was called Jade. My friend lived in an apartment above the bar, so we'd hang out here all the time. Anyone else miss the Jade cocktail?

yTQ7uqpl3LTShnhmyJBD9A.review_text: 3 1/2 stars  Being someone that doesn't like rum, I wasn't all that excited about checking this place out. Having said that, it was all the talk so I figured I should see what all the hype is about. On the one hand, I was happily surprised how good the drinks were. I went with a little group and we all tried different drinks. All of them were pretty tasty. It has a cool vibe and I like the 3 floors. I was a bit turned off by the wait outside though. It's a Wednesday. Really? It's not that cool of a place for there to be a line outside.   I say wait till all the cool kids find another new up and coming bar, before you stop by the Smuggler's Cove.

15H7TA0QXggx7UgVJrU8Dg.review_text: Rum! Amazing rum! Go here to get rum. ARRRRRRR!  Best mixed drinks in the city, best ambiance in the city, friendliest staff. All around epic. I've had so much on the menu, I can't remember. I like creamier drinks so there's a few that work for me. Jamaican milk punch, painkiller #4, tradewind... Everything on the menu is great, and it's so diverse there really is something for everyone. Even non-rum drinkers.  Oh, and if you think Bacardi is a good rum, you might not like this place. In fact, maybe you should do yourself a favour and just stay at home drinking your Bacardi. Maybe mix it with Coca-Cola. Why don't you just go marry Bacardi if you love it so much?

rNNcUshDXFaHDZeFwAkaOw.review_text: Long list of very interesting and strong cocktails. Good stuff with some exotic rums. Place is 3-levels and very small but it's really cool. Kinda feels like you're inside an old wooden ship! This place gets busy fast so plan to show up early or stand in line for a long time.

wJ1KEqvUASdFfis-KsVDxA.review_text: When we arrived at 9PM on a Friday night, I almost walked right past the entrance - the nondescript front door looks like a side entrance to a boring, blacked out office building. We stepped through the door and right into a Pirates of the Caribbean set. Some may think the decor is overkill, but it's fun :)  The place is pretty cozy, despite the three different levels. Both the main floor and basement bars were crowded - especially downstairs, with the extra seating. One caveat: be prepared to wait a good amount of time for your drink (definitely worth the wait, though!). That night, there was only one bartender per bar - and most drinks have about 15 - 20 different ingredients that need to be blended into magical rum-bliss-inducing concoctions. Props to the main floor bartender - at one point, he was making 14 drinks at the same time. I swear, his hands were a nonstop flurry of movement, as everyone huddled around the bar gazed in awe.  We found some seats on the top floor above the main level, so we ordered the Top Notch Volcano for the three of us girls. It comes in a cool porcelain (aka not drunk-proof) tiki punch bowl, and they light it on fire when presenting it to you! Since it's served with long straws, it's difficult to portion how much you drink (especially when you're sitting down).  Case in point: After drinking my "share", I headed downstairs to use the facilities. Upon entering the bathroom, I saw someone to my right and apologized for getting in her way... and then realized I was talking to my own reflection in the full-length mirror on the wall. Yeah. Thankfully, there were no witnesses. (And yes, Jessica W. is referring to me). That punch is potent stuff.  I would definitely come back to try out some of the other mixed drinks on the menu - there's definitely no shortage in selection!

JIXHS_SddRfTjG9JEqazYg.review_text: Let me preface my review by admitting my reluctance to write it. Not that I don't want to heap praise on this fine establishment. Quite the contrary. I'm just reluctant to hip any more people to this place. Because I love it. But it's small. Very small.   Now, I could be a jerk and give one less star for that, but I won't. The intimacy is actually a good thing. If it's not packed. It's a conundrum. I know. You see where I'm going with this?  I'd love to let everyone know that they can drink delicious and potent artisan rum concoctions in a terrificly realized atmosphere straight out of the Goonies with friendly, knowledgeable bartenders and great tunes. I could tell it to the mountains about how you're going to have a ton of fun, even in the bathroom (seriously). But, sadly, that might mean that I can't get in on Friday as this is probably the only bar in San Francisco with a velvet rope line.   But, alas, I can't keep it a secret, nor would I want to. By all means, visit Smuggler's Cove. Have a drink or two then GET OUT! It's cold out here.

bSY04kIrbB3J9cyNBiKfcQ.review_text: I came here with a friend who knows the owner and is a member of their drinking club (for lack of better words).  He told us about the painkiller drinks along with the very long menu of drinks and about the numerous rums they carry in stock.  We cabbed it over here after dinner and walked up to some random looking door but it was actually a bar.  Reading the text on the door on the way in, it did say Smugglers Cove so I knew we were there.  We went upstairs to hang out as our friend ordered some drinks and lo and behold, I had a painkiller #3 in hand.  It was really good with a complex mix of flavors and shaved nutmeg on top that added to the flavor of the drink.  We were here on a Wednesday night so it was slower but I can imagine how packed they can get on the weekend.  If I'm in the area, I'd definitely come back.  Oh, and the waterfall that leads to the basement area is a nice touch.

HLPkPv3C1ZUg9TIhAownCA.review_text: The bartender recommended the "good stuff" to a myself and a few friends, everything was amazing.. Definitely recommend the Volcano Drink (make sure you bring a few friends though)! Atmosphere was fun and original.. A hole in the wall bar to remember!

0dwddoD9iFETVKXZXZko3g.review_text: Smuggler's Cove is one of the best bars in the City. If you want Disneyland, go somewhere else. This place is a class act with amazing bartenders, drinks, and ambiance.

ygh1FAM5zmfWFeKsV6wJRg.review_text: Damn pirates! Well, damn rule makers.   Here's the story: Arrive around 11:15pm on a Friday night.  There is ONE other girl standing in line.  I go to show my ID, thinking that the girl is just outside taking an air break.  Wrong.  The bouncer goes, "sorry, we're not letting anyone in."   I try to look pathetic and plead, because my friends are waiting for me inside.  He doesn't relent.  I ask the other girl how long she's been waiting, and she tells me 5 minutes.  So here we are, outside--2 girls standing alone, just waiting to go in and meet our friends! I text my friend and explain the situation, growing more agitated by the second.  A few people trickle out and he doesn't let us in.  His rationale--sorry, I'm following my orders.  If that's the case, I guess he's just doing his job, but whoever is making those orders needs to open his/her eyes to how business works. If you want to generate a huge line at your club to make it look like an awesome place to get in, don't make 2 girls who came by themselves to meet friends wait outside in the cold. My friend comes out and starts pleading with the bouncer, and he still says no--despite the fact that 2 of our other friends are already inside and have ordered drinks for all of us--read: giving the bar business! Finally, some others come out and start making sarcastic remarks about whether they'd be able to get back in.  I guess we weren't the first ones to experience this arbitrary waiting system. Exasperated, the bouncer finally lets us in, after a growing group of people become annoyed that they can't get 1 or 2 more friends inside, when the rest of the group is already in. Good thing the rum was able to wash the bitter taste of that scenario out of my mouth (I couldn't take away more stars because the drinks *are* pretty good and I'm a sucker for pirate-themed places), but you'd be hard pressed to find me coming back here on a weekend...unless whoever's in charge changes the bouncer rules. I leave you with this--rules and regulations are put in place for a reason, but some reevaluation and thinking never hurt anyone: huffingtonpost.com/2010/…

hWsFeJtDYhLxXmjK8-t8_Q.review_text: It's always amazed me that in a hard-drinking city like San Francisco, the only tiki bar option is the notoriously touristy and octogenarian Tonga Room. There is, of course, The Forbidden Island in Alameda (which I love), but getting there from the city is complicated if one doesn't want to worry about driving. (And when I'm tipping back Zombies, I definitely don't want to have to worry about driving.) So when I heard that one of the founders of The Forbidden Island was opening his very own tiki bar in San Francisco, I was very excited. Unfortunately, my experience at Smuggler's Cove did not live up to my excitement.  My first clue that something was amiss was the velvet (OK, vinyl) rope next to the doorman. A rope? On a Tuesday night? Over the holidays when bars and restaurants are always quiet? Seriously? The doorman was friendly enough, though, and there was no line, so we walked right in.  I have to admit that the owners did a great job with the 3-level space that Jade used to occupy. They obviously sank a lot of money into the place, and it shows. The decor is over the top, as is should be, but stops just short of being tacky. It's not a large space by any means, but the two-story ceiling on the main floor manages to make the small room seem positively airy. The upstairs area features a much lower ceiling, but because it overlooks the bar, as well as an impressive assortment of kitschy objet d'art, it feels more West-Indies treehouse than secondary seating area.  Sadly, my favorite feature of the old Jade bar, the very disconcerting one-way mirror over the bar that allows patrons of the men's bathroom to see out into the crowd in the main room, is gone. (Sigh.)  As annoying as the vinyl rope outside the front door was, it was nothing compared to what we experienced when we got inside and tried to order drinks. After we secured a table upstairs and had a look at the extensive drink menu, my boyfriend went to order for us. A full 15 minutes later, I went down to check on him. He was standing among a group of people who were looking longingly at the one bartender behind the bar. It turns out that after a reasonable 5-minute wait, the bartender took my boyfriend's order, along with those of the 3 people waiting in front of him. That would have been fine, except that there were still drink orders to be filled for several other people who'd ordered before my boyfriend's group. We gave it another few minutes, then left. We would have canceled our drink order, but we were unable to get the attention of the bartender or the other person behind the bar, who was simply standing there, totally oblivious.   Incidentally, when I mentioned my experience to a friend, she responded by saying, "I had the same experience. About 20 sets of eyes staring at one bartender who never looks up. 20 minutes later a good drink, but then you are done and can't bear to wait another 20 minutes."  On the way out, I noticed that there was a line queuing up behind the aforementioned vinyl rope, even though the bar was not crowded inside. This, in my opinion, is a bar/club mortal sin. (Come on, guys. Really? Shouldn't you be above this kind of thing?)  As we were walking over to Paul K for a round of their gorgeous (and efficiently-served) martinis, my boyfriend joked that it would have taken less time for us to hop in a cab and grab drinks at The Forbidden Island in Alameda. In hindsight, I realize he wasn't joking.  I'm really tempted to give Smuggler's Cove one star, but in all fairness, I can't. They have a great space, and a pretty great drink menu (though I can't really attest to how good the drink actually are). I understand and appreciate that the bar/restaurant business is tough one, but they really do need to get it together as far as service goes. Smuggler's Cove's website offers an explanation as to why their bartenders are so slow ("... do not want to compromise on quality... exotic recipes... as many as 8-11 ingredients... finely balanced"), but I don't buy it. The bartenders at Beretta in The Mission and Blackbird in the Castro have been turning out superb, complex cocktails at dizzying speed ever since they both opened. True, both establishments have much larger bars than does Smuggler's Cove, but I've watched their bartenders in action on numerous occasions; they know what they're doing, and they know how to do it *quickly*.  As Smuggler's Cove has just opened, I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and try them again when they've (hopefully) gotten into their groove. But not if I have to wait behind the vinyl rope.

qrVmy8EceZKisJf_l1O8Hw.review_text: Other's have commented on the theme, but if you don't like that sort of thing, why go to a place called Smuggler's Cove?  Clearly the owner has poured good money into the decor, so let me focus on the obvious failing with this place: it's hard to get a drink.  First find a seat among the three levels: no bar up top, main bar at street level, small bar in the basement.  Comfortable seating is secondary to decorations.  After you and your date choose from the wordy menu, you head to the bar to order.  But because each drink is elaborately hand crafted, the queue becomes quite lengthy.  Meanwhile your date sits without you, since they have no wait staff.  The drinks were good, but after such a bother to retrieve, we were ready to leave after one round.

P6-rV466DvpjGOaxwEinTw.review_text: Totally a hidden gem in Sf, and one of my favorite places to go out for drinks, they are absolutely delish. And to the VOLCANO god who makes the volcano erupt we appreciate your service and your hairless arms, you made our experience that much more pleasurable.

soe9jdnUf9by3FE0WfenLw.review_text: Small bar, but cozy atmosphere. They have two bars, so the lines usually go by fast. Besides watching them do their magic is half the experience.  This is definitely a spot you should check out, have a drink there after your dinner or something. It is not a place to hang all night, although we had a fun time staying for a while, trying out different drinks!  Rum, Rum & Rum. They do have a few alternatives, but I stuck to rumy drinks, since that is what they specialize in :)

OgYi5x02MBukfxPNFe1ePg.review_text: Arrrrrrgghhhh yelpies! If you ever find yourself lookin' for a low-key, chill, dope bar to mingle in while in San Fran, be sure to head here!  I have to begin with walking up to the place...we were shushed upon our arrival at the door and I was so thrown off! Apparently in San Fran there are noise constraints that need to be met as a ton of bars have apt homes above them, crazy! The windows to the bar were even tinted and you could not see a thing - so weird when I am used to Orlando having everything open, no noise constraints and loud people on the streets.  We entered and I immediately was reminded of the Swiss family Robinson tree in Disney's Magic Kingdom. There was such an immediate transition from SF street to Pirate boat! The constraints were small but there were immediate steps leading upstairs or down to different levels. I chose to stay on the main floor and order from the bar in the middle. I was handed a huge menu of options which is not normal for bars I frequent - however, this place obviously being themed after Pirates highlighted Rum! After ordering some fancy drink and tasting various others choices I immediately learned that I am only a fan of Rum in Mojitos :) lesson learned! I bet they had some ahhhhmazing mojitos too, grrrr, maybe I will revisit in 2 weeks when I'm back in San Fran!  Overall, totally dug this place and wish we had a cool find like this in Orlando! 2 things I would suggest:  #1 - adding music #2 - not letting douche boys in who ask you rude questions to make themselves sound cool and talk your ear off about how amazing they are at golf and how great they think they are at life #malefail

7cZXErbtp0wzMh9JGOurVg.review_text: Oh, to hell with you people who only want a beer or to "do shots".   You want something that dull, go get it out of a friggen vending machine, or go to ANY of the other bars in this city.   Leave me with my crazy mixologists at Smuggler's Cove. When I drink, I do it for quality, not quantity, and I love the huge variety of quality rums (and a few other surprises, if you scan the shelves) and the faithful, historical rum cocktail recipes and variations.  You'll find things here that aren't even released yet from St. George's Spirits (the makers of Hangar One), and things that you will never see again, either. (Eurydice Rum, etc)   The menu's a bit of a fun read and a history lesson.   Don't order your drink and then walk off - half the fun is watching the work that goes into the drink's creation. I felt slightly guilty when ordering a Pupule and the bartender peeled an entire orange for it, but oh god that was delicious.  I can't blame the people who work here for being annoyed at the clueless "uhm, so like, do you have beer?" ones who wander in. That's like walking into a fancy Italian restaurant and bitching that "why don't y'all have somethin' normal, like a burger or some shit?" I want to dump a Jack and Coke on your head, too - it's not just the bartender who's fed up.    And if you know your stuff, and it's not too busy.... work with your mixologist, they have more than a few interesting drinks up their sleeves, beyond the menu. :)

tRyZ7RnmHi6rKFO0hRXZ6g.review_text: If you are a rum enthusiast, you would be a complete fool to pass up this bar. Oh, it's also PIRATE THEMED. Outside of drinking on the deck of the Black Pearl with Cpt. Jack Sparrow, this is as good as it gets.  The drinks here are expensive... and worth every penny. I have never seen bartenders craft drinks with the speed and precision of the people working here. I recommend the Pukka Punch.   If you come here with a group, get a Scorpion Bowl or a Volcano and prepare to have a wild night.

uSLYegkfWVQqufUJTQccFQ.review_text: Crowded, dark and expensive. If that's your thing, you'll love it.

SzANwTg5VIfUQW2t5ru6SA.review_text: What a great bar.  Rum intense so if you dont like it, go elsewhere.  You half expect Johnny Depp to pop out of a corner but the atmosphere is fun.  Had one of the better mojitos I've ever had and when its done well, it's one of the best drinks out there.  Also went with a reserve rum tasting.  Incredible.

HLHWgca6EbelhOpxcyRMwQ.review_text: WOW I had no idea what I was walking into when I approached the blank exterior.  The inside of this place is hilarious.  It's tacky, but without looking cheap (if that is possible).  I was here on a Thursday with a large group of friends.  The bartenders said we were lucky and came on a slow night, so no one had to wait in line outside.  The drinks did take FOREVER, but that is to be expected.  They tasted great, so I'm not complaining!  We sat in the up-most level, which was nice and quite.  I hate when you go to a bar and can't hear the people you came to meet and catch up with!  All in all, we had a great time, didn't feel cramped, and had great drinks.

hgrhfiO4CYGbLVuQESjDDQ.review_text: Met friends here for cocktails - stood in line for quite a while, only to be led downstairs to a pretty overcrowded, small room. Isn't the line for crowd control or are you just trying to make your bar seem cooler than it actually is? Drinks, while pricey & taking forflippingever to actually get, were tasty. Aaaasnd thennnnn the place filled up with douchebags. Backwards baseball caps (I counted at least 3...what??) & a total jocky/frat vibe that made you pretty sure you'd be date-raped if you went to the bathroom alone. They're oblivious to anyone but themselves & you get run into. Repeatedly. A lot. And then shit-faced skanks are leaning on you and sloshing their drinks all over you. Oy. I know that's par for the course in a bar, but it seemed excessive. A couple of sailors knots & a jinky pirate theme (when is that pirate shit gonna die down anyway? It's seriously like the overkill of rockabilly in the late 90s) is not worth it for me. I hear it's better during the week, but mixing with the Bridge & Tunnel amateurs on a Saturday night is no bueno.

szu3ClyRcQvDdqjNr_1mOA.review_text: The drinks here R O C K!  But I have two issues: 1) the bartenders are slow.  I know they are making fancy drinks but they make they same kind of drinks at 15 Romolo twice as fast.  2) They don't have the Bushwacker on the menu which is much better than the Pain Killer and hands down the best drink in BVI.  In short, check out this bar.  The drinks are pricey but totally worth it.  You might have to wait to get it but again totally worth it.    FYI, I've got a soft spot for good rum and I just got back from this place so take it all with a grain of salt.

tYisuXsfvdnybOwivYwNxg.review_text: I checked this place out with 3 girlfriends - and loved it! The line was long to get in, but it was worth it. I'd describe it as a casual Trader Vic's type place. I had something with rum and coconut that was terrific.

bLLpAJ5ia_Bq170E0jZdOQ.review_text: The Old "Jade", Smuggler's Cove is the "new" Rum house located near Hayes Valley.   Specializing in drinks from the "Caribbean"-aka: RUM Smuggler's Cove mixes some pretty mean drinks within a very cool decor.  That's the good stuff, now hears the bad.   First, due to City Fire Regulations, if you have a group of more than 10 people you should expect that not all of you are going to get in due to space limitations.   Second, and the biggest problem, the service is slooooooooooow. On my visit it was taking bartenders about 25-30 minutes to get my group drink orders. Might I add we only had about two to three drinks per order. Seriously. One of my friends came late to the party and went to the bar to order a drink-we didn't see him for 35 minutes as he waited for the bartender to make his drink. Not good.   Third, there is no Happy Hour. This can be a good thing or a bad thing depending on your demeanor. However, the drinks are expensive. Tasty and well made, but you should expect to spend no less than $10 a drink.

Cv-zk_Rjzx_4GYv9lwypVg.review_text: No, no seriously, that's right, it's a pirate bar!  And it's as awesome as it sounds, maybe more so.  Expected perhaps a few drunken scallywags but got hip, well-dressed 21-35 crowd, with fun attitudes (again, it's a pirate bar).    Do your crew a favor and get your drink in a skull, with plenty o' straws to go around!  Lots of birthday parties and special days being had here, along with a few scattered dates.  The different levels facilitate whatever vibe you're after.  Get here early, as they don't allow overcrowding, so the line gets long and slow fast.  Good news for those inside, not so good for those who haven't made it in yet.  Arr, feast ye eyes on a briny bottle ah rum with yer mates ere and have ya a merry ol time, mateys, arrr! (Sorry couldn't resist).

ok9BkiAeT12Qh-qDb7R6cA.review_text: Went ti this place on a tuesday after several recommendations. I am a rum fan so my expectations were very hight. It took me 1 hour to get my first drink, not because the place was packed but because the bartender was more interested in talking to girls and sharing free shots with them than serving anyone. I managed to get one drink, which wasnt anything special and went back to the bar to get the special barrel drink with fire. This time it took me again a while to get the bartenders attention, he did at least three shots and was substantially drunk at this point. When i ordered he told me to go back to my table (upstairs) and that they will bring the drinks in no time. After waiting upstairs for 30 min I went down to ask what what the status of my drink, the bartender didnt remember at all my order and after i told him about it he told me that he had no more barrels and that there was nothing he could do. When I ask to speak with the manager he got upset, told me that i would have to wait for a while because he was busy. I decided to leave at that moment but he still had my card. Trying to show his power he refused to give me my card, he said "you wanted to speak with the manager, now you are going to wait for the manager" and went back to continue serving new free shots to hot girls. This guy was considerably drunk, we got into a big argument, i was kicked out of the place (still without my card) and that is when the manager showed up. After two hours in this place i got 1 drink for me and my girlfriend, spend 1 hour total trying to get a second one and had to deal with a drunk, unprofessional, trying to be cool with the girls bartender. So much for date night. This is the type of place that will get one tome customer based on their fame and can keep going without repeated customers. Stay in your local bar and tell your friends to stay away of this tourist trap. You will save yourself an awful night.

nbfyMmgqnxXIp7EDqTmkqw.review_text: Super awesome bar, reminds me of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland. Menu is extensive, drinks are strong (slightly expensive) and very sugary. Fun times but be prepared for a hangover

x2YSA4-oG8x7ORWAlT_uCA.review_text: This place used to be my favorite nightcap bar, with a friendly staff and one of the coolest bouncers. Unfortunately, they seemingly had to cut costs and hired the world's most ridiculous bouncer and have lost all my respect, and business.   Another reviewer referred to him as Shia LaBeouf, because of his man bun and angst for mankind, and it's clear he is high on the powerful position he holds... as doorman... at a Pirate Bar.   I had not even made eye contact or spoken to Shia before he let me know I was too drunk to enter the bar, and my friends could not enter either. When asked to explain what I had done to give him that idea he said he watched my group and I cross the street. Two fun facts: I did not cross the street to get to the bar, I rounded a corner AND he was talking with someone else as we approached the bar, so not sure what sort of weird sixth sense this guy thinks he has but it was unfounded. While he was letting me know that their "drinks" were very "strong" and they had a standard to uphold, some drunk middle-aged white man stumbled out of the bar giving us all high fives and acting like a fool, which really drove Shia's point home.   Either way, I am glad he told me that I was too drunk to enter the bar because I was drunk enough to think spending $20.00 on some crap drink that takes 38 minutes to make and drinking it while surrounded by a bunch of drunk, middle-aged, overweight men was a good idea. Great job Shia, keep it up and that promotion to Mall Security Guard will surely come your way soon.  As for my husband, my friends and I, we went to Sugar and had an amazing time with reasonably priced drinks, friendly staff and a young, good looking crowd. If you want to waste your time and money while being insulted, Smuggler's Cove is the place for you!

T-y9XDQHryztHL5NpcimWA.review_text: Fun (If not over blown) decorations: CHECK.  Good drinks made with fresh ingredients:  CHECK.  The beef I had with this Island Get away was that the bar tenders took 15-20 minutes to make a Scorpion Bowl, a Tiki staple.  I have heard this length-of-time-it-takes-to-get-served complaint from others.  It might have had something to do with the Bar Tender having to look up all the drinks he made.  If I were at the helm of this bar, I would hire two more bar tenders and have two bartenders at each bar BECAUSE the drinks do take time to make if done well.  As for the Crowd, Let me say it was a less than stellar experience.  My friend and I got there before there was a line, got our drink and sat at a table.  We decided, after a nice buzz and having fun wrangling the sweet nectar out of those long straws they give with the drink, that a cigarette was in order.  We came back to someone sitting in our seats and our half full drink cleared.  We had left a to-go container and all of our jackets there, what we thought was a universal sign that we were coming back.  Well, from now on we will place police tape around our still warm seats.  The person that took our seats refused to get up, but that does not speak to the bar.  The fact that the bar cleared our drink does.  The bar tender was understandably under pressure and therefore had no time for chit chat. Rack em and Stack em was the sense I got. Any who.  I hope they hire more folks and that you have a better experience than I did.

VrMoY2B2zYNCKC_YRpuzRQ.review_text: One of the best and most interesting bars in San Francisco I have been to since my time in this fabulous city. Great theme, decor and atmosphere. Smaller size bar but great place to sit back and have a cola and rum with some friends, or with new Contiki friends. Be sure to have your passport or ID on you because they do check at the door. Then make way downstairs, is where the theme and atmosphere really takes off.

ZDB07FSq6tdo3A5XdK1GrA.review_text: The bartenders here have got some serious skills. I really appreciate the show I got when my drink was made.  The drinks were $$$ but they are made with so much enthusiasm and precision. I had the Cove rum barrel and it was so freakin yummy!! Also tried the hot buttered Rum. This batter they have concocted is homemade and damn would I pay for the recipe. Very fun vibe and must see for the full San Francisco bar scene experience.   Totally feels like you're in a pirate ship and this place is so well hidden! Want to feel like you're on a Caribbean island vacation in the middle of San Francisco? Go here! Great place to take friends who visit here.

xz81pPXEuon4-7yRg2ptDQ.review_text: First time coming here, we came to celebrate a couple of birthdays, the theme was awesome and the line moved quickly. All three floors were crowded and it took a while to get drinks but at least the drinks were beautiful and refreshing :)  **they do not accommodate requests for additional shots because they like to keep true to their recipes

3qMnJT5k3sSA565d7N4r6A.review_text: I have only been here once, and maybe it was a particularly bad night, but I can honestly say it was the most crowded bar I have ever been in, in San Francisco -- and it was a Thursday night around 9 PM!  My boyfriend and I waited about 20 minutes in line outside before we got it.  The wait was fine with me because I assumed it meant they were keeping the crowd at a reasonable size.    WRONG.  Once we got in we quickly realized that there was pretty much no where for us to go.  We quickly skimmed the menu - which looked great! but we didn't get to spend proper time reading it because I was getting jostled by everyone and their mother while waiting by the bar.  Once we got our drinks, we headed downstairs in the hopes of finding somewhere less sardine-like.  Wish not granted - I made it about 2 minutes before my boyfriend and I had to rotate the way we were standing so he could shield me from the people shoving their way around.    On a positive note, I liked our drinks and the decor was cool.    I had heard so many great things about this place and I really want to like it.  Maybe if you go at 5 PM on a Tuesday it's fun but I don't think I have the courage to go back there anytime after 7 PM.

PauNerg-kHRpoqLwB6F5CQ.review_text: Fun! This bar very much has the atmosphere of walking into a secret treasure cave, and that's what it is. With well over 50 rums available, and an equal number of specialty rum cocktails, the bartenders can easily steer you to something that'll have you shouting "Yo Ho Ho!" If the stools at the bar are full, check out the tables upstairs in the crow's nest, or follow the lighted water features down into the hold where you'll find seating, restrooms, and another bar. Drink up, me hearties!

fP5-u5yZ683B0Mdd7Zjb6A.review_text: Pirates, look no further. This place is rumalicious. Food: What do you get when you mix bananas, pineapples, mangos, rum, and sweet liquers? Unbelievable drinks! I was cheap and went for the banana daquiri (yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0…). This thing was so delicious that I downed in it less than 10 minutes. Other members of our party tried more exotic selections which I was privy to sample. The Tradewinds (yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0…) had a great description on the menu, but turned out to be way too strong for me (my alcoholic friend on the other hand finished if off and wanted more). Not sure what this was, but it was super good and had a lovely orchid as a garnish (yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0…). Also, we witnessed another party ordering one of the flaming bowls (yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0…). This thing was enormous and sported strategically placed holes on each side. People were given straws that they could poke through the openings for a sip. I so wanted that... Atmosphere: Like Disneyland for alcoholics, this place is dripping with seafaring memorabilia and even has a two story tropical fountain and pond. There are blowfish stuffed with colorful lights, ropes, and nets covering the ceiling. The lower level is much more subdued than the top level (yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0…). They should do something about that. Also, even though we came here super early, there was still a crowd. Don't be late or you'll have to wait in line and may not get in. Service: Excellent. These guys know their booze and are willing to share their expertise. Even the menu is full of history on both the rum itself and on the creation of Smuggler's Cove (yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0…). Synopsis: If you are rumthusiast or just love something tasty and fun, stop by Smuggler's Cove.

XgOIcjoWXRH8ogRbWkrX2w.review_text: theme parties yes...theme bars...could go wrong very easily but loved this place.  there was a short line but we waited about 5 minutes, the bouncer was super nice and told us how to get drinks quickly (place was packed), found us seats and overally super sweet.  bartender is great about taking orders and makes fantastic drinks - the exotic drinks are good and strong.  the space is split into three levels with a 2nd floor overlooking the main area.  great for groups of friends (not for meeting new people).

muWo0gd3xEZHpq7Xty1-Dw.review_text: allow me to start my review with a statement that may make you completely de-value my comments: i don't like rum.  that being said, walking into smuggler's cove feel's like walking right into the black pearl, and you expect captain jack sparrow to check your ID.  i love the ambiance and the owners' obvious investment in making smuggler's cove a true theme bar.  however, although the space boast 3 floors, none of the 3 floors is very spacious at all.  the cove offers a pretty expansive menu of rum cocktails.  but for us non-rum drinkers, they have two full bars (on two of their 3 levels) also.  drinks are priced like a club though (which i hate)...  so, is the davey jones' locker feel of the cove enough to make me spend a few bucks more to get as drunk as a sailor?  eh, maybe once in a while, but i definitely won't be a regular.

64o6vJrByaGTStMvvU45JQ.review_text: Smuggler's cove has hands down the best rum selection in the city. The place is a nautically themed tiki bar. Maybe it's a little over the top, but all tiki bars over the top. Though I do wish it was a bit more wear on the surfaces to really bring out the boatiness of it all.  Now, I didn't try any of their cocktails, though by appearance they did make a proper painkiller. I sat down, signed up for the Rumbustion Society and got down to the business of working my way through their 200 types of rums 1 oz at a time. I didn't quite make it, but I did enjoy some exceptional rums.  If you've never had a fine sipping rum before, just order a glass of Pyrat Cask 23 neat. I guarantee it will be like nothing you've had before, but be warned, at $35 it is an expensive habit to form. Otherwise get yourself a glass of Zacapa 23 or maybe Diplomático Blanco if you like white rum.  A word of note: if you're looking for a bar where you that will make drinks quickly in plastic cups and give you change for your $10 bill, the Mission is but a stones throw away.

58ZGUbmRpf8_lEHdE47upQ.review_text: The rum......will never be gone.  I don't know where to begin. Somewhere between entering and the bar you step onto a pirate ship and a spell is cast on you to order a hand crafted specialized drink from their extensive and tempting menu.   The bartenders will craft you up a drink stiffer than the wind and you'll sit and converse with your mates as if you try to pay attention.  Why? Because one, your sea legs will be tested with the amount of booze in your goblet, and two because the entire place--down to the daintiest detail----is worthy of a movie set.  If the movie contained a lot of rum and pirates.  Go here. Drinks are a pegged leg and a half. But worth it.

HshIhF76Uea0-2ht_KUisw.review_text: A pirate-themed rum bar in the middle of San Francisco?   Sadly, dreams of escaping to a Caribbean oasis whilst clanking coconuts and singing old maritime jingles with rosy-cheeked patrons quickly vanished upon visiting Smuggler's Cove this past Friday.  First indicator of douchiness:  the line outside.  I understand lines when a.) it's a *club* in which a DJ or some other event is taking place or b.) when the venue is at capacity and people on the inside have to leave in order to make room for people on the outside.   Sweater-vest-clad bouncer, however, let people in based on - I don't know, his benevolence? - and not at all according to people leaving the bar.  Once we actually got in, the place was quiet.  No merriment to be seen or heard.  Ladies in cocktail dresses and gentlemen in blazers sat cross-legged sipping drinks, quietly chatting with pinkies up.    I guess I just don't get it.  I felt like I was in the Redwood Room... if the Clift hotel decided to suddenly redecorate with fake seaweed and drift wood.

il64P3G-9k2-8r0UPgzXCQ.review_text: HOLY CRAP. so happy the place i was having dinner was right by this amazing pirate ship/tiki bar.  yes i agree with reviews that it is cramped, but the decor is pretty amazing. the attention to detail! the flaming drinks!!!!  it was definitely crowded, but a group of us managed to sit at the bar (which i think is the best place to sit). downstairs was dark, upstairs was fun but still a little cramped. i had an aku aku, tried the hot buttered rum, and 2 other drinks that were beautifully done. will definitely be back next time i am in town!

h3Yg3OE9uD6XEAPyEm3qEQ.review_text: Indoor pirate ship? Check.  Gigantic fancy drink menu? Check.  Rum rum rum? Check.  Can you come in everyday for a year and try all the rums and get your name on a plaque on the wall? Check.   Just remember, these are PIRATE drinks, not boat drinks, so there's nothing frozen here - which in my opinion is a wonderful thing.   Now, if only there was only a Smuggler's Cove for tequila...

TvFoBhHrqQ743m9ch5b_9w.review_text: Just perfect specialty rhum cocktails. Period.

XMeRHjiLhA9cv3BsSOazCA.review_text: I love this place, but the current bouncer is a real buzz kill. So, only 4 stars.  I showed up last night (a Thursday) around 9:30PM with 2 male friends and 2 female friends, ready for some rum. There were no customers standing outside, entering, or leaving. And the city and hood were pretty much dead.  We walked up and said hi to the bouncer and got reprimanded right away for entering the velvet rope from the wrong side. Even though, again, no one was there.  The bouncer then made us wait while ignoring our questions and staring at his cell phone, mumbling to himself. So, we left without entering.  Is this intentional? New York-esque vibe, and artificially implied crowdedness? Weak stuff, Smuggler's.

BFNVTFyGZZ_IzzWCRpPrbg.review_text: Having dinner in the hayes? Need somewhere fun to go after? Look no further than Smugglers Cove. A tiki bar with two levels. Drinks are great here taste good and lots of choices, sort of similar to a trader vics.   Very laid back here and just a fun time overall, only problem i have with it is that it is too small, if it gets crowded there is no room to order drinks or even walk around. But other than that it is a must experience.   Just be prepared and know that it is difficult to move and get drinks when it's packed and there is normally a line.

Y65zJtK5wAUQQcSvWWKAQg.review_text: I had really high hopes for this place, that were slightly crushed upon spending a few hours inside.   Ok first off, the guy who works the door earned the two stars for the whole place. He was courteous, polite and gave us menus to read and an umbrella because we had to wait outside in the rain, due to the low occupancy of 49 people. He made us laugh and seemed to be pretty knowledgable about the drinks.  We got inside and immediately were faced with a huge crowd, no place to sit and a long line at both bars. After braving the lines we ordered drinks from the bartender downstairs. She seemed to have no interest in what she was doing. I guess I expected a little pizazz in the drink making...maybe a description of the ingredients some parlor tricks perhaps,? Nope..just some mystery liquids, crushed ice , fruit and umbrellas...and a hand waiting for our money.  The drink I ordered was very sour. It was a popule? I dont know...I never finished it. I'm a beer drinker. Their house beer "Smugglers brew" was acceptable but by no means delicious.  The crowd is a mix of yuppies, drunken frat boy types and a few cool kids scattered here and there.  No music playing or very low music in the backgound equals a pirate bar with no vibe.  Its definitely lacking in character. It takes more than cool decorations and an anchor on your wall to create ambiance, but at least the door guy was cool.

RfjWiiBRO5uorrxzfwdBYQ.review_text: My previous co-worker worships and adores Smuggler's Cove, and that was enough for me!  I love the hardcore tiki decor, which is incredibly done and must have been a labor of love.  You really don't feel like you're in SF at all.  The drinks are wonderful, but don't expect the usual bar and club fare here.  It's all about an experience...one where the drinks are craftily made and created.  It's truly an art form to watch them make these elaborately delicious drinks.  They're amazing!  And strong!  I really like the Grog, and the Navy Grog and Captain's Grog are outstanding.  Speaking of standing, only 2 of these and you'll be lucky to still be standing.  The Zombie is a thriller and a killer as well.  The aromas and flavors imparted into the drinks are so specific and unique.  You don't get drinks like these anywhere else in SF.    Don't expect to whiz by and grab a drink and run; stop in, take your time, and enjoy this gem in SF.

n8zo_DJYs9jgxqbX6pMbbg.review_text: To be fair I have only gone here on weekdays but it is my new favorite bar. Why? Delicious rums, prizes for drinking your way through the menu and the best decor and music you can ask for. I've had a mixed drink and tastes of two bowls and they were fantastic. If you're a straight up kind of guy I recommend the rum flight "The Backyard" made up of local distilleries.

v4SKLl-nN77kIzg0OJkakA.review_text: cool place , I usually don't drink cocktails or prepared drinks,  and these place has some good ones I really liked. The decoration is awesome, felt like inside a pirate boat :)
