I appreciate the original drink menu that was obviously well thought through, but because each drink has 7+ ingredients, the bartenders can only work so fast. The combination of the small space and the long wait for drinks did not make for a great experience. Maybe I'll check out this spot on a weekday to see if it's more manageable.

4gzvD779lat8hT1TyKLCgQ.review_text: This place is a sweet little piece of drinkers Disney Land! Yep I said it, Disney Land, just with much much better drinks!

Df8CtbrZWQBYcrGv3dZW-Q.review_text: Fantastic tiki / rum bar. A bit hard to find -- the black glass (?) wall on the street doesn't belie the nautically-themed bar inside. Good service -- the bartenders are quite impressive to watch -- and fantastic drinks. One of my favorite bars in the city.

js4wjUqfNu4xJBu27KZKhg.review_text: Back when Don Beach and Vic Bergeron were opening their eponymous tropical theme dining establishments, around WWII, fine dining in America was French, L'Escoffier style, with several heavy courses rich in fat and salt, and liberally doused with heart-hostile sauces.  The minor folk ran towards diners, lunch counters and neighborhood cafes.  The bar scene was just as stratified, with clubs like the Stork and 21, and neighborhood taverns for the rest.    Power brokers drank Martinis made with gin and vermouth; scotch on the rocks; with soda; or bourbon.  Everyone else made do with beer, local wine, and rot gut.  Rum was for sailors.  Thus, Trader Vics (which, admittedly, catered more towards the high end of the dining and drinking spectrum) and Don The Beachcomber were something new, an informal take on dining, with cocktails even "ladies" could like; sweet and fruity.   People did wear suits, they wore them everywhere, but the experience was meant to be informal and relaxing; fun.  Nobody took the food seriously and the cocktails were a diversion, men especially would order their "usual" poison from the drier spirits, and the bartenders wouldn't think of passing judgement.  So, it's rather ironic, and sad, really, that we get a bang-up reincarnation of a good old theme bar that is also a temple of rum.  The last part I had presumed to be a focus more than a religion.  Churches and Bars differ in that churches demand that you come to them, and arrive willing to accept their worldview, whereas bars hope to attract your business and adapt their worldview to your tastes.  And that's the way it seemed to work, until a recent monday evening when I met up  with my cousin at Smuggler's Cove, and ran into the bartender from Hell.    Kansas, I suspect, but Hell will do.  I should say that I've never been good with spirits.  A few too many and my mind goes to bed while my body is still at the bar.  But now, with gout, I have even more pressing reasons to avoid spirits, and beer, and so I drink only wine, and Smuggler's Cove has a rather quaffable vintage, especially given the swill most bars pass off as the nectar.  So, I started my night with a Arrogant Bastard, gin and juice and gingerbeer--a fine drink, expertly made, and then switched to wine.  After about four glasses and a couple of hours, I was surprised that the partner was ready to leave (my cousin already had, leaving her husband and his brother behind) and so I ordered a shot of rum to close out the night, when the parsimonious twit replied, before I could even ask for him to recommend something, "I'll just get your check".  I've done some asking around and apparently, the pudgy little transplant from the bible-belt is known for his rum snobbery.  "Rum snobbery", isn't that funny?  Sort of like a whore getting particular about who she hangs out with.  Still, a tropical bar is supposed to be about getting loose, and getting away from the uptight, not adding to it, but when we live in an era of casual fridays amidst non-formal everydays, maybe things have gone crazy.  I can't go back.  I don't want the unpleasant experience of running into that twit again. I go out to have fun, to get away from my miserable job and the dreadful people I have to deal with.  Who wants to go into a bar and find the village vicar is tending, and passing judgement at the same time?  He makes good cocktails, but that's no excuse for his abominable square-state prissyness.

Tvx_0sVkHK05ZuNx4nt1ng.review_text: We had a really fun time here. Awesome atmosphere! We all loved the pirate ship theme. My husband and I came with a friend on a Saturday night when they opened at 5pm. Wasn't too busy and we found a table right away. We loved their extensive menu and drinks. So goooooood. Before we knew it, it was 7:15pm. By that time it was a bit busier and people were trying to find tables. I would recommend going earlier. We will definitely be back.

OaRk-RwFEzfOtc45ff0fGA.review_text: A tiki bar practically run like a restaurant - they keep the crowds under control, there's a drink menu, and though the drinks may take a while, they are well crafted and worth the wait.  A fun starter for a night of more raucous partying, or a place to have a few drinks and hangout before turning in a low-key evening.  Just an overall fun little unsuspecting place to get your tiki cocktail on.

DJ07cHGm7e4WwxYSo0928w.review_text: I am, in general, a beer drinker.  However, these delicious and meticulously crafted cocktails were delicious and well worth the somewhat higher cost (8-10$ ish).  The atmosphere was small, dark, and intimate.  It is not an ideal location if you are looking to go out, be loud, and drink too much.

YlJNqoHqIssCHP25h2sUFA.review_text: Yo ho,  yo ho, a pirate's life for me!  Yes my friends, I finally made it to Smuggler's Cove. I'm not sure what took so long. It could have been my sadness over Jade closing or the huge hype this place had when it opened. But I decided to check it out, on Halloween weekend! And I was really happy with what I saw.  First of all, I love the decor. I seriously felt like I was walking into Pirates of the Caribbean at Disneyland. Not sure if that's what they were going for, but I loved it. And also, for their selection of tasty drinks. I often find it difficult to find a cocktail that I'll actually like at places like Rye, Bourbon and Branch, etc. The reason being, they tend to veer away from vodka and rum (clearly too plebeian for them) and go with bourbon, whiskey, and gin - all liquors I don't really care for. So it's nice to come to a bar where most (if not all) of their cocktails are made with a liquor I can get behind!  We sat upstairs at the main bar and we were lucky to get there early enough so that it was not crowded. The bartenders were super friendly and very fast! I always thought cocktails took a long time to prepare but these guys have got it down to a science.  It was such a fun experience, I have no doubt I'll be back. And to boot, I like it better than I liked Jade! Who woulda thunk it?!

Xki-AgOlTBlK8XFw8tgLSg.review_text: I had a recent trip to SF and Smugglers Cove was on my list to check out. It was named one of the best bars in the world, along with another SF bar Trick Dog. My party and I arrived a little around 11:00 pm on a Saturday night. The line was short so I didn't think the wait would be long. The bouncer made his way over to us and told us that they have neighbors and everyone needs to keep their voices down. Okay great. Well not even five minutes later, and we were talking at a normal volume, the bouncer rushed over to us and yelled "that's it, everyone out of the line, you aren't allowed to go in!" Shocked I said that we were sorry, we were just talking and I will make sure to keep everyone quiet. To which he replies "No, get out!" and then walk away. I was completely disappointed in this place. The rude and angry bouncer totally ruined my excitement of this place and frankly after that experience I will not be returning in the future. His attitude was completely unnecessary and he really needs to check himself.  As a comparison, I went to the other SF bar on the top 50 in the world list, Trick Dog, the night after and had a completely different experience. Trick Dog was friendly, nice and not at all rude like Smugglers Cove. Skip Smugglers Cove and check out Trick Dog instead.

wIR0nQNrCU7O-91xHAWjLg.review_text: What is there more to say about this place? Dane you're an awesome bartender thank you for being a true bartender and not pretentious.  Drinks are delicious, what i would say is if trader vic's got modernize and, used only fresh ingredients then there wouldn't be a need for smugglers cove. Good thing they don't do that and we have a wonderful place like this.

NywsHjAzNXXiI2rQRTUN1g.review_text: I would love to rate this place higher based solely on the conversations with Carlos at the front door. But, alas, I cannot. The drinks were good, sweet and strong. We had Zombies and Hawaiian Sunsets. Zombies were strong as Hulk Hulgan on steroids and the Hawaiian Sunset was as sweet as my 6 year old niece. A little pricey but I can't complain about that. Marco is the main bartender. He was recently ranked as one of the top 4 bartenders in the US and he acts like it. He is fast and good and that's great. But he can be a little standoffish and if anyone throws off his rhythm he doesn't respond well. There is maybe 14 chairs in this entire spot. Basically standing room. Still a good spot though.

yC20xWWmtB7nEHvE7vThaA.review_text: Ummmmmm....I'm still not quite sure what to make of this place. I went last weekend for a friend's birthday in an attempt to avoid the bridge and tunnel crowd that infultrates the city's night life every weekend.Wihle I think that we successfully avoided the B&T scene which was our main objective, I have never seen a more random bar crowd before in my life. I get that it is a tiki bar, but some people took the pirate theme a bit too far...it was pretty camp. And it was crowded as a MOTHA in that place....I mean, rediculously crowded. This is def a very casual spot, so if you don't feel like putting on your Jack Sparrow ensamble, you can just put on some jeans and flip flops and still fit right in. I will certainly leave my Geren Ford at home the next time I visit this place, in lieu of some more fitting...like a pirate hat and an eye patch maybe???? A+ for the friendly door guy and solid drinks!

RjhZjVzcAcVjgPMITgox2g.review_text: Wahwahweewah!!  Did you guys know this was rated the number 16 bar in the world by Forbes?  Google the top 50 bars in the world and you can see the list.  Right before I found out this tidbit of information, I actually had just commented to my friend that I already liked this bar even without getting my drink yet.  It was something about the atmosphere that just hit it right.  Just before getting in, there was a small line of patrons outside and we had to wait about 20 minutes, no big deal. When we got in we settled at the basement, and ordered our drinks. Let me paint you a picture: the place seemed like a moored pirate ship, complete with rope netting, pirate things and a small pool/fountain.  The drinks:  some of the best I have ever had.  They had many unique combinations of various delicious liquors mixed with fancy tropical fruit juices with other really odd delectables.  And yes, this is one of those places that take a while to make your drink because they really do care.  Just the freshest of ingredients and really nice bartenders.  Reasonably priced, too! About $10 to $13 for a pretty tall and stiff drink. The crowd:  classy, fun and down to have a good time.  Always a plus is the sheer number of fiery candles in tiki bowls full of well thought out libations that some of the tables ordered.  You won't be disappointed here!

nMvd0T2l4CdRCd8KlYc_sg.review_text: I went here at 9PM on a Saturday night because one of my friends decided to have a birthday here (bad idea) and I sat in the basement level. This is the busiest night of the week so avoid it if you can. And the bouncer (tall skinny white guy) was nice and friendly to me and my date so I don't know why other reviewers had beef with him.  GOOD: - Someone at the door gave me and my date a free shot of rum each to warm us up because we had waited outside so long. The rum was good and it was a nice gesture. +1 star for that. - The Smuggler's Rum Barrel (2nd to last page of the menu) was very good and full of spice. - The place is kind of cute I guess with its waterfall and pirate ship theme. My date said that the overall structure is the same as Jade Bar, the former bar that used to inhabit this space. - The crowd is pretty laid back and not pretentious. This isn't really a pick up scene and they don't blast music so people aren't loud and obnoxious.   JUST OKAY: - The Batida (milkshake) was tasty but not great. It is basically cachacha, condensed milk, coconut cream, and passion fruit juice. It was a little too heavy on the coconut cream so that is all you really taste. - The Grog (2nd page of the menu) was disappointing because I had high expectations for drinking grog, the drink made famous from pirate movies or tv shows. It was just rum and lime juice basically. Nothing really special at all.  BAD: - The Chadburn (2nd to last page of the menu) was gross (tasted kind like a weird licorice). It was a mix of rum, port, chocolate mole bitters and something else but both my date and I thought it was gross.  - The wait to get inside was ridiculous because the place is small (max capacity of 49 people). The line when we got there was about 12-15 people long and we waited 40 minutes to get inside. If it wasn't for my friend's birthday, I would NOT have waited this long. Unless you absolutely must drink rum or have a birthday to attend, I would not wait more than 2 minutes to get into this place.  - The wait to get a drink is also ridiculous. There are 3 floors but the top floor is just for seating. There is a bar on the ground level and basement level, each staffed by ONE bartender. The capacity is 49 people so each bartender has to handle roughly 25 customers. If the bartender takes 2 minutes (conservative estimate) to make 1 drink and half the floor (12 people) are ahead of you, you are going to wait about 25 minutes before you get your drink. This happened to me on my 2nd round and I was sitting at the bar (which only had room for 4 seats).   - They used crushed ice in their drinks. This is a cheap tactic for mixed drinks because they can fit more ice into their glasses and the ice melts faster thus allowing them to make smaller drinks. Other reviewers claim that this place is a fancy bar but a real high-end bar would use large ice cubes, preferably chipped from a block of ice because their is less surface area on the ice and it will melt slower.  - I didn't come here expecting amazing mixologists but other reviewers seem to have over-hyped the bartenders here. It would be a stretch to say that the bartenders are well-trained mixologists creating amazing masterpieces. The bartender frequently referred to drink recipes on an LCD screen (shouldn't they know these by heart?) and they would sloppily let ingredients spill over their measures from frantic imprecise pouring. If you want to see a true mixologist, I recommend Thad Volger, who I think is at Heaven's Dog now (formerly at Jardiniere, Bourbon & Branch, and Beretta). The drinks themselves taste fine and I would leave it at that but I don't want readers to get false expectations from other reviewers who gush about their drink making abilities (maybe they are friends of the owner or the bartender upstairs was better? I don't know).  CONCLUSION: Smuggler's Cove is a quaint and casual tiki bar with some tasty drinks. Unless you must have rum, avoid this place on weekends because the drinks/scene is not worth waiting in line for and when it is busy, you will wait even more to get your drink because there is only one bartender on each floor. I would come back if there was no line.

SM0PfEGYoH5z1z2TWWWhgA.review_text: I would give this bar zero stars. On my birthday they were extremely rude to me while serving me. All because I am allergic to cinnamon, and I asked for a drink without it. That is not something within my control. The second time I went, I felt really sick to my stomach because of a long  car ride, I get carsick  and it's  not  weird for me to pop in the bathroom and just puke a tiny bit. Well, they kicked me out of the bar in a very bad manner, so disrespectful. I will not be coming back here ever!

I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg.review_text: Ahoy, all aboard on a Pirate Ship, Mate!    I hear ye callin' for some rum?!  We surely got it smuggled here!  Yarr, in this Smuggler's Cove!    Get their rum barrel so ye can keep the cup as a souvenir!  Avast, if ye dare to highlight the dark night, get their Volcano and they shall blast fire the cinnamon and cause an uproar!   Aye!  I say come early before 10, so ye don't have to stand, but leisurely sit awhile.  Ye need a table, if ye are betting on the scorpion bowls!  Beware on what ye thirst for!  Have a ruckas!  Arrr!

JyG_WzNGJUkv_o_sjf99ag.review_text: I tried last Friday night, and enjoyed it very much. This doesn't look like a bar from outside, but inside is fully decorated between tiki bar and pirate's tavern or boat. The drinks are good, strong and the atmosphere is fun.  My favorite the Capitain 's Grog, or the volcano to share at a table. If you can go early in the evening, because there may be a queue to enter later when the place is packed.

wBITBGxo4T0vf3oi5q-nfQ.review_text: Best tiki bar on the planet. Unmatched drinks, service, and atmosphere. It also smells like pirate burps.

BelCqypSxv-45Cosc6ZINw.review_text: I've been here a few times, and this is one of the best places for a libation I've ever been to.    Now, this is different from a drink that is slammed together as fast as possible.  No no!  A highly trained mixologist will be making your Painkiller #5 (it's on the secret menu) in painstaking and loving manner.   The first taste will certainly be an eye opener.  It was for me.  The complex flavors balanced just right dance on your tongue.    Each time I've been here, it's been around 5:30 in the afternoon and getting a seat at the bar was tough.  I can't even imagine this place on a Friday night at 11pm.

pMqZqilV2_EoPW4HGYCdZQ.review_text: This place might give you an impression as laid back, home away in the Caribbean but its anything but. It's cheesy, expensive, awfully pretentious and the customer service is the worst In the city. Lot other great bars in Hayes. This is not worth it.

DPzFUR-u_RBxK3KlZCwMlQ.review_text: Whoa, the drink menu here is AWESOME!  The place rocks with the pirate/seafaring theme (amazing decor) and the drinks are simply superb!  We kept ordering drinks until the last call, trying different kinds of rum cocktails, and they were all excellent.  This is one place I want to come back to for sure!

IcShovp4fE-FQQ-0H5MHCA.review_text: DON'T COME HERE. Giving this place 1 star is generous. This was definitely the WORST SERVICE I have ever received at a business. Wow, who knew Smuggler's Cove would be operated by a bunch of arrogant douchebags? From the doorman to the bartender and the waiters, the entire staff was unbelievably disrespectful. And I'm pretty sure they're slightly racist towards Asians.  My group of 12 (yes, we were a fairly large party) arrived on a Friday night at 10:30pm. We waited over an hour before we actually got in. When we neared the door, the doorman originally said he was going to let 5 of us in first then the 7 right after in a few mins. However, he let 5 of us in... and then proceeded to tell us we'd have to stagger the last few ppl. My friend obviously let out a jaded comment of "Wow, really...?" When we reminded him of the fact that he told us he'd let the rest of us in together, he blatantly said, "Well, this place is small. It's a Friday night; how do you expect to come in with a F***ING group of 13 people at 11pm? Don't be sarcastic with me." WTF. Who said it was ok to drop the f-bomb to customers? We told him we'd been waiting since 10:30pm, and he continued to insinuate that we were being sarcastic. Yes, we were definitely antsy to get in, but we did NOT swear at all or give that much attitude. When he finally let us in, we were being somewhat cooperative and asked, "All of us?" And he responded with a snooty remark, "Well if you want, 3 of you can come in and the rest of you can continue waiting if you want." WOW... and you were saying WE were being sarcastic? STRIKE ONE.  So onwards into the bar that we've been waiting an hour for... Got to admit, the place does look pretty cool. A pirate ship and tiki bar all in one place. Small seating area upstairs, bar on the entrance floor, and another seating/bar area on the bottom floor. But yes, I can see how they try to limit the amount of patrons here since it's not that large. Still doesn't explain the doorman's attitude though. We started ordering drinks, and the bf ordered a Scorpion ($36) that's supposed to be big enough for 4 people. The bartender insisted that we needed to have a table to be able to order it. We assured him we did since our friends were saving a table for us. But he kept questioning (2-3x), "You guys have a physical table? Why are you down here if you have a table?" Ummm... maybe it's because you don't often take drink orders upstairs? And of course I have a physical table... did you think I was referring to an intangible table?  He eventually gave it to us, but that was definitely STRIKE TWO.   And STRIKE THREE. We were about to leave when my friend accidentally dropped his keys off the railing of the top floor near the bartender's bottles. We were trying to carefully fish it out, but another friend unfortunately knocked over a bottle in the process. Ok, definitely our bad cause we could have hit the bartender, but luckily, it was pretty far from him. We definitely apologized, but a waiter ran up and shouted, "WHAT THE F**K ARE YOU GUYS DOING?" We said we were sorry, but he wasn't having any of it and told us to get the f**k out of there. (They actually said the f-words too.) We were on the way out of the bar, my friend retrieved the keys, and the bartender simply tossed the keys over rudely and said, "Don't come back." Hey! Great idea, I wasn't planning on it anyways!  AND... YOU'RE OUT. Wow, what a HORRENDOUS HORRENDOUS experience. Yes, the last part was bad on our part, but totally an accident, which we sincerely apologized for. Smuggler's Cove, that gives you NO RIGHT to swear and cuss at us numerous times throughout a 3 hour period. The drinks were ok, but the service and overall experience I had here were SO BAD to make up for anything even slightly positive.  I am definitely going to share my horrible experience with others, and this will not be a place I ever come back to. I never knew a business could treat its patrons so poorly, but guess everything is possible with Smuggler's Cove!

VlVx6clfF7iZfO_idvuMfA.review_text: I have mixed feelings about this place...  We have wanted to come forever, but were put off by the rumors of LONG waits.   We ended up being in the city earlier than normal, (picking up a friend for an extended layover from SFO) Since we had time to kill (our dinner res wasn't for awhile and was nearby.), perfect opportunity to check this place out. We had been told if we go there when they opened we wouldn't be stuck outside in line.  We got there at 5:15, they open at 5. There was no line, but it was  PACKED.  We ended up in the downstairs bar, and snagged some seats by the pond. I had to fight to save the hubby's sear while he went and ordered for the 3 of us.  The menu is HUGE. Since the place is slammed, I wasn't about to ask a bartender  any questions about the drinks. Wasn't a fan of the set-up, it's run like a dive bar, but clearly isn't. Most cocktail places we've been, with big lists (or in this case a book) and high prices, you also get some service and the opportunity to get some info on the drinks. Obviously, whatever they're doing is working for them, it just wasn't my preference.  We all loved our drinks, and would have ordered another round , but didn't have another 40 mins to wait for it.  We also felt a little hot and claustrophobic packed in as we were, Yes, the wait for drinks is LONG. I get that they're craft cocktails, but 1 bartender for hordes of people? Yikes, would not want to be him.  Glad we finally went, and if the buzz  about this place ever normalizes, I'd go back.  Although, seeing the droves of people lined up when we left, can't imagine that will happen.

y0cCcyxKUsOBjyN10qtkZg.review_text: this place is rather surreal. one second you're on the street outside of what almost looks like a office building. the next you're in the god damn pirates of the caribbean. complete with skeletons, rum crates, waterfall, cheesy lighting and pirate weaponry adorning the walls. minutes after that you're drinking 10 kinds of liquor from a flaming bowl.

clsUcSMUxmlpdcvnVPLeoQ.review_text: Wait in a heck of long line just to come into an empty place?!?!  What the H. It was one of my you got me f'ed up moments.  Nice and low-key atmosphere but why the heck did we wait in line if there were barely any people inside? Makes no sense. The bouncer's response, "you have to wait out here so you don't wait in line at the bar."  Umm, ok. HINT: Hire more bartenders!!!  Upon ordering my drink the bartender was a total jerk about the situation of my order. It wasn't that busy nor loud so I couldn't understand why he couldn't hear me. So I had to point. We asked suggestions for a shot and his statement was, "I'm not a mixologist in making shots, however tequila is what I know."   No duh, you-idiot-who-I-pay-to-make-drinks!  Me: Fine, just give us our drinks and a couple shots of tequila. Seriously, our buzz was already gone after staying in the long ass line outside. (30 minute wait) Along with the wait at the bar (30 minutes) So an hour has passed and we still haven't even gotten drinks yet, we just placed the order. As we waited patiently, finally our drinks came and the bartender says, "these are a bit strong so no tequila shots."   I was like, ok.........usually that means NO TIP! Someone telling me that I can't take a shot when we haven't even started drinking yet?! Oh heck no!!!!  This man had the nerve to say these drinks are really strong so just stick with the drinks. That's why you didn't get a tip!  Bad Service, No manners = No money for you!   The place is nice, alittle disneylandish/rainforest cafe. Crowd is alright. It would a be a nice starter bar if the wait line wasn't so long and the service wasn't so horribly slow or rude.  Would I come back? No, it's a one hit wonder bar.

SEJ5-w481HXDks33ezlP4Q.review_text: Great atmosphere. Perfect to bring out-of-towners for novelty or to stop by on the way to or from dinner for amazing hand-crafted cocktails.

me8NYDS2xE0wcQinnl-DfQ.review_text: Fantastic rum cocktails!!!  This place is hard to find, even if you have the exact address...maybe its one of those things where the fewer the people know about it....the better it is.   My friends were already there and I reached a little late. I parked my car and started looking for the place. There is no huge board lights nothing to say this is smugglers cove. Just a black glass door, with 650 gough street written on it and in really small letters "Smugglers Cove".  Have been here only once, so dont remember the specific names of the cocktails i had.... they just have too many to choose from....and i had too many too...lol.  amazing ambiance, great music and the bartenders are reeeaaaally good. Really know their stuff. Went up to the bar and said "its my first time here so what should I have?" and both of them replied in unison - "Forgot the name but it was just awesome!!!"   Later, we ordered a bowl rum punch...was some sort of a pineapple blend. At every corner of the bowl there was a small cup with a super strong rum which was set on fire. We then started talking to the bartender about the drink and he suggested we have one of the cocktails with the super strong rum in it. This was a rum from Guinea in africa... "f***ing" brilliant cocktail. Must have had atleast 6-7 different cocktails there.

RgDVC3ZUBqpEe6Y1kPhIpw.review_text: Quite possibly my favoritest bar in all of the bay area land. My pal and I swaggered in after an afternoon filled with Charlie's Pharmacy specials. I was instantly taken with the seafaring decor and one drink later, I was absolutely oozing with contentment.   I felt like I was basking in the inside of a rum barrel, or better yet, a true pirate ship. This 3 story shotgun bar isn't quite wide, but it's tall and the 3rd floor acts more like a loft to the 2nd (main) floor.   Just imagine Pirates of the Caribbean (without the hokeyness) plus a cocktail-forward menu and the swiftest bartender I've ever had the pleasure of witnessing.   Definitely don't miss out on the hot buttered rum this holiday season.

lFAy08NYQ-EmYWL9G1Q3JQ.review_text: My main reason to come hear was cause a friend highly recommended it.  I've been at better places.  The drinks were overpriced but OK.  The wait is long to get in, just to find it crowded..

0aJLwGXBVIe6a99f4lxOmA.review_text: This place was a lot of fun.  Get there early (we got there right at 5pm) to take full advantage of the 5-7 $2 off happy hour.  Otherwise the drinks can get pretty expensive at $9-$15.  Also, getting there early means you can grab a table close to the bar.  Once this place gets crowded, I bet it's not nearly as fun since each drink is pretty complicated and it would take a while.  I tried two different rum drinks that were both delicious (first was something with muddled pineapple and the second was more of an herby one).  And I don't even normally like rum.  It took me a while to pick my drinks because the menu is HUGE but really all six of us got different drinks and we all liked ours, so I bet you'd be safe with most of them.  The bartender was very knowledgeable and answered our questions and even let us taste some rums.  The decor is pretty kooky and fun.  Was a great way to spend a couple hours chilling and talking with friends downstairs as we sipped our fancy drinks.

EGvptPOz6SDKdxvbeqQ7Vw.review_text: I am not a big rum fan... haven't been since my early college days, but this place has not only an awesome environment but the drinks are very well made. A few of my college buddies and I were deciding between Smugglers and BnB, so we flipped a coin and Smugglers won.   The inside looks like Pirates of the Caribbean, and the blow fish lights, water pond, and tiki layout on the 3 floors added a nice touch.   Like I said, I don't like rum that much, but these rum drinks were very satisfying. Of the rum drinks, I tried the Zombie which is one of their strongest drinks and a train wreck waiting to happen if you pound 2 of these down. I also tried this other drink called the Naci something Hotel (Spanish Fail) and this was a good thirst quencher, even on a cold SF night.   I also ordered the Port Light, which was a whiskey drink mix. The taste was very palatable, and you could really feel the honey blending with the whiskey and egg whites.   The selection of rum was amazing for those who are rum connoisseurs. If you don't like rum, I still think you should give this place a try. I am a sucker for well made drinks, and this place has got it down.

-aT1RSHfHDgqE5lFK-S9MA.review_text: Best rum bar in SF. Every time I come here, I get totally drunk and have a pretty wild experience. It's crowded, so come early! Like 10pm early! Or wait outside in the cold.

3BHdcyBBHdJOGL-37bKtXw.review_text: Best and booziest tiki cocktails I've ever had! Very complex flavors and beautiful presentation. I was hoping to learn about and taste the different rums from their wide selection, unfortunately, the one bartender making all the cocktails for the entire upstairs area was so busy, there was no opportunity to talk about the rums and ask questions. The place is very dark and can get really loud.

yulXOMg9DEgPdnZVbb2zHg.review_text: Delicious, strong, and not outrageously priced drinks. No music for dancing, and not much seating or space, but I'd definitely go back for the yummy drinks.  The menu is VERY descriptive and expansive, so I'll give a few recommendations to help narrow down the numerous choices: - Kona cocktail (if you don't mind the flower in it clearly marking it as a "girly drink") - Tradewinds: coconut cream, apricot liqueur, and other delicious flavors - The Painkiller: also coconut-y; surprisingly delicious and great "bang for your buck" if you get the 4 oz for $14 vs. 3 oz for $13 or 2 oz for $12. Great option if you want an extra-strong drink. The Zombie seems to be a go-to strong drink here, but it does not taste good.  This place was PACKED on a Thursday night, with a line outside the unmarked door. Be prepared to stand around and swoop on the limited seating as soon as it frees up.

ssXAz7RahuYNDx7FeRe4Aw.review_text: Who knew rum could be so versatile?! Much more than fruity, oversweet island drinks SC elevates rum and showcases it in multiple ways. The mai tai isn't too sweet and is by far the best I've had. Blows Trader Vic's out of the water!   I love the pirate ship decor. They nailed the theme without being kitschy. Nice, efficient bartenders who do well in the always busy atmosphere.   Tip: Get there early to avoid the massive nightly line to get in.

JGdKYphlPcJTBhHBjCfdig.review_text: Pirate themed bar?! HELL YES!  It was a bit hard finding this place because the front door was all blacked out and there is no lit sign stating HERE IS SMUGGLER'S COVE! I like it, makes it more pirate-y... X marks the spot right?!  You come in and the best place (in my opinion) is downstairs next to the water....  My friends and I got the Volcano bowl that 4 ppl can drink for $40 (including tip). Man, was the drink strong and cool looking! If you want the whole pirate-y experience, really think about getting this drink! They put it on fire and shake some stuff on top to make it look like popping lava.  If you want a unique atmosphere and big bowls of alcohol, just come here and enjoy! The bartenders and friendly and make sure you grab a seat when you can cause this place get packed!

CMiAcA8s1oBQfSyqf45Uxw.review_text: As close to a speakeasy place I can get around here. Minus Bourbon & Branch - where I will try hopefully soon.  Two floors - we were downstairs. The mixologist is really fabulous. She made to die for drinks.  I had the Kona something, the Hibiscus something, and others had the Planters Punch or whatever it was called. The three dots and a dash, and another drink I had i cant remember, but was SO good. The mixologist made me a special drink on her own called the apricot something with pineapple, but it was strong and spectacular. Not too sweet. Fruity, but Strong.   Recommend coming here for great drinks - come early to snag the seats at the bottom. Gets crowded later on, but it's all worth it.

0gGcIkHOTDMl_6p5RGnuFw.review_text: Smugglers Cove was calling our name over the weekend. We wanted a quick and good drink in a fun environment. We arrived around 10PM and it wasn't too busy, made our way down stairs to grab some drinks.   We are slowly working our way through the menu checklist and they made us some yummy drinks, mine had a pretty pink umbrella, what's not to love about that?!  Around 10:20 the place really started to pick up but we managed to steel some seats at the bar downstairs, we people watched, ease-dropped and talked to one another until about midnight when we decided to head home.  Still love this place.

V1ra0vxOSalQADQKi1TCLg.review_text: Super cool place- vibe of Trader Sam's. Nice rum selection! Awesome Mai Tai :)

YApQEXLtWePvONPHXVSsVA.review_text: Two stars because I liked the decor and the drink was good; however getting a drink its like ordering a lasagne and waiting for them to make it from scratch.  I could see it being a cool bar on a Tuesday or other non busy night.

yrWJ4YZWvFj_NDOvTRaAqA.review_text: Fun! Got the Puka Punch as suggested by my friends. Definitely made me chatty. It was a very happy drunk I experienced so I can't say anything bad about this place! Smiles all night.

5vXqog3DHrRXADKUg78B2w.review_text: You will drink all of the rums and you will like it.

f9aIofvRra79gzbPf5ui4g.review_text: my new favorite bar spot in SF..  picture a speak easy for pirates and you've found your spot.. nestled across the streets from the projects this secret spot has three floors (not full prob the size of a small studio per floor.. with island/pirate decor...   make sure to try to scorpion bowl which is a drink they light on fire from you and is supposed to be death in a cup.. (we had 5 ppl drink it so it wasn't too deadly)

xObzTAC6gsFH6XKhc9yRYQ.review_text: Part Bar, Part Hide out, Part Swiss family Robinson.... With Rum galore decor to the nines, this place is and about as rare as finding a seat in the place. The place is cheeky, festive, and beautiful.  It's not very intimate but I put this on a place Bachelors should brings there dates and definitely a place you have to try once. I've been here before.  If you don't like Tiki bars, this place is not for you.... AND YOU NEED TO BE PUNCHED IN THE STOMACH!  Just saying'

9OXGWy6UWCxZFCAlezlg3A.review_text: Double bonus night as it was Darlene W's She's Closer To Thirty Bday bash and the one year anniversary of Smuggler's Cove -- all drinks at happy hour prices all night long including the Volcano (comes on fire and makes the perfect impromptu bday cake).   While I don't think I'll earn my fez hat here for having all 100 rums, I'm more than happy to come back and explore the menu, one drink at a time. Come hang out upstairs or go below and have some of the cities best rum drinks all above board.

9WzUerODzyYUkQO0u3Nyjg.review_text: Came here really for the Puka Punch since it's on the Big Eats list, I had to knock another one down the list.  11 different ingredients, 4 juices, 4 rums, and some other things that I can't remember.  The drink coming to $12 ($2 off during happy hour from the regular $14 price), it better be a strong one!  I knew this place was dark, but walking in with my sunglasses, I literally could not see anything.  The decor made me feel like I was in a scene of the Pirates and the Carribean.  I didn't realize that this place was a rum bar until the bouncer told me.  I guess it makes sense why the decor is the way it is.  That didn't stop me from ordering the Puka Punch, and it sure did not disappoint.  You can totally taste the mixtures of all the different juices, with a shot of rum in the middle and some fresh mints on top for you to stir in.    There were 4 of us, and we ordered 7.  Yup, it was pretty darn good, and it was the only drink we ordered the entire time.  The place is dim and gives out a good vibe for people who are here looking for a chillaxing time after work.  It gets packed really quick, so get here early if you want to grab a seat!

pauOTA3dvD944S6IhDAiBQ.review_text: Sampling of what happened the other night:  Random Stranger (speaking to his friend): Dude, there are so many choices on this menu, what do we get? I think I just want something hard.  Me: First of all, that's what she said. Second, dude! you need get the Grog! That'll totally get you hammered. I speak from experrrrrience.  RS: Dude, are you sure?  Me: Yeah man, wait....no wait! Get the NAVY Grog! Even better?  ::Half an hour later::  Me: hey man how's the drink going?  RS: dude, I'm totally hammered...  The bartenders do their very best to make the drinks quickly and keep the customers happy. Just remember, that they have to know 70 different location specific cocktails, so much respect! BTW this place used to be the old Jade Bar, but I think this bar concept is even better. It's still a little bit of a trip to get here, but it's worth it. I'd recommend taking the taxi or public transportation home if you can...

a0DwyYWrg4LbrSinWd1Beg.review_text: Kinda cheesy decor compared to forbidden island. Due to neighborhood restrictions they don't play music that u can actually hear.   A bit lame, but fun for one experience.   The drinks and menu were great though. Tiny place and not really worth the wait, though the doorman was funny and charming. Actually he was the best part!

H0kbUxaj45magcOXjHNi8w.review_text: Good place to check out.  Twice is enough for me.  First time in a group of 5 - person we were with knew his drinks and we enjoyed his suggestions.  Next time 2 of us - we felt a bit lost with the menu - both our drinks tasted similar and overly tart.  Would love to ask questions of the bartender to help get the right stuff but it is always so crowded that it is impossible to do that.  Do appreciate the care taken on crafting each drink.  Of course all the other drinks looked more delicious than ours...

nj3syiLs3lABLtPVyL0ivA.review_text: Tucked away behind an innocent looking door that looks sort of like an office building along any old street is a secret wonderland of tiki drinks and rum history.   Smuggler's Cove - what has to be one of the best bars possible if you want to try that pirate drink of choice - RUM!   They have a massive selection of rums that you probably never heard of and I'll personally make you walk the fucking plank if you dare mix those small batch bottles with coke.    When you're hear expect to get crunked, because there's really no drink that is for the weak at heart and inexperienced in the liver.   You can attempt to join their Rum drinkers club called the Rumbustion, which gives you a passport and once you channel those old Pokemon skills and apply them towards tossing back rum and you collect them all, you'll be apart of the elite group of alcoholics.   The only downside is there's, like, 200 to drink to fully master the kung-fu skills of getting wasted. So perhaps you should pace yourself. You can do so with their regular pinky up tiki drinks. And let me lay one thing out right here and right now. I will bare knuckle fight anyone who dares say that a tiki drink isn't "manly",   There ain't no shame to drinking with one pinky up, homie. And I damn sure can tell you that a couple of those classics and their own signature tiki drinks will easily knock you out faster and more efficiently than my empty threat of bare knuckle boxing you.   Price tag on the drinks for the potency they're packing is really well. The only down side is that this place can get pretty packed, even with the three levels they have. It's an extremely interesting bar and given that it always makes the top list of Tiki bars to go to before you sail off to the afterlife, you should be making this a destination whenever you're in S.F.   They also have their own Tiki mugs for sale. A true sign that a tiki bar isn't messing around. It's also helpful to get one simply to help you remember what exactly happened when you wake up hung over from that pinky up drink.   Consider it a medal of honor that you tore it up tiki style.

OJPU-VZn7jFSMvsuKU0ypw.review_text: We went on a Wednesday night a few weeks ago for my roommates birthday. It was perfect for this occasion.   Ambiance: it doesn't get much more detailed than this! We say downstairs and it truly does feel like you are in a pirate ship. Fabulous.   Service: a bit different than I'm used to, but good. No cocktail waiters...you go up to the bar and put your order in and they call your name out for you to pick it up when it's ready. Unless you get a bowl of some sort...then they deliver the fiery goodness to your table (I wouldn't trust a drinking person with a huge flaming bowl of booze to walk across the bar either lol). Each drink is so detailed and includes fresh ingredients...so it takes a bit longer than usual to receive your drink but not enough to bother you.   Drinks: delicious! They have a HUGE menu of rum drinks...and only like 2 each of vodka, tequila and whiskey. I'm allergic to pineapple so that held me back a bit...but my friends had a great time enjoying the huge bowls. We even got something that came in a flaming boat. Super cool. I had a rum old fashioned and it was 100% delicious. A good option if you don't usually drink sweet drinks. It's a big jump from a vodka martini with two olives to a goblet of sweet fresh tropical juices, sweet rum, and with a fruit garnish as big as your head.  Overall, we had a blast! We were very lucky to get a table...it was packed even during the week. Also...it's not really a local scene...a bit of a tourist destination.  Cheers!

4zC675ZBi0o0_kD6jY9gwQ.review_text: This place has fulfilled one of my fantasies...getting drunk in a Pirate's of the Caribbean like atmosphere.   Pros: - Drinks are awesome. I don't think I've ever had a bad one. - The scorpion bowl greatly amuses me. - Nice and knowledgeable bartenders. - Booze heavy drinks are indicated as such. It makes it much easier for me to find them. - Love the decor - The only reason I leave is because I don't want to spend anymore money.  Cons: - Fills up pretty quickly so get here early and establish a beach head. - Some drinks are complicated and can take a while to make. (not really a con) - I have a mysterious habit of losing all the cash I came here with. No wait, its because I keep ordering $13 drinks haha.

U9-QTVVewv-NB0sG9hy9-w.review_text: This place has great ambiance and I would love to come here again but not on the weekend bc I'm sure it will be super crowded. The drinks are good and unique. Make sure you have your phone for lighting bc the menu is like a novel.

38zhUVIh6t_-mpcmbWYmiw.review_text: Wow. Really impressive. Martin Cate has done it again. First, Forbidden Island in Alameda and now this.   A little cramped, but what a space! Attention to detail is nothing short of amazing.  And the cocktail list is incredible. The Port Royal is amazing, and the Wray & Nephew and Ting was refreshing.   I'll be back for sure!!

6Fo8xB96WFj8Bk0AK7fRpQ.review_text: I love this bar. Seriously. What could be better than a pirate themed bar that basically exclusively serves rum? It's like you're hanging out in Pirates of the Caribbean. They have an impressive list of straight rums, and the bartenders are awesome at recommending a mixed drink if you tell them what you like (ex: I like a somewhat sweet drink with NO pineapple - my drink was perfect!). I was only in San Francisco for a long weekend, and we went twice. That's how awesome this place is. The cocktails are a bit pricy, but this is San Francisco, and the bar has the awesome theme going for it.  That being said, there is a HUGE caveat, which is why this is only a 4 star review. I went on a Saturday and Sunday night, both around 8pm before going out elsewhere. Other reviewers have mentioned how incredibly crowded it can get, even having to wait outside, and I can definitely see that happening if you try to go here later in the evening. This place is SMALL. If you're looking for a place where you can sit down, talk, and enjoy a drink late in the evening, this probably isn't it.  If you're earlier, though, high recommend this place!

qjoZFgL9j4jdGgQXkEQW3g.review_text: Fun place! The punch bowls are so much fun! The mixed drinks are good too. This place definitely gets packed, so I suggest coming early.

z5foJeW2auljKeK-KIMTjA.review_text: Already suffering from popularity, I have to say something to people who complain about the line... would you rather everywhere be as huge as a warehouse?  Or craptastic enough to have nobody trying to get in?  What a tragedy that this place is fantastic!  Oh the horror....  I hate lines too but my patience was rewarded with incredible drinks, great recommendations from the bartender (I had aged rum on the rocks), and a cute, warm atmosphere.  Gripes:  Crowd is not the hippest thing on the planet... a bit bridge-n-tunnel so its not going to ever be a regular haunt.  That said, I'll go back from time to time and try NOT to go on a Saturday night.

WVo1BCPoIbF4U6JVBXDaew.review_text: this place rules. amazing drinks! friendly service. fun decor. the port royal with a chile tincture, AWESOME

O63nS08VVf5yn7SsEhYq5A.review_text: OMG!!!!  This place is a MUST!  It's a great place to wind down after a long day or just a place to chill and have a good drink.  My mom visit from the Chicago area, I took her there and she is still RAVING about this place.  The drinks are kinda pricey, but hey it's San Fran...  They are strong.  I highly recommend the Jamaican Milk!!!!

n17dxizQKL2KuLGqWA_bKg.review_text: My favorite watering hole in San Francisco. Great drinks, great vibe, great tiki times. Yes the place is small, yes it gets busy but a couple of those classic cocktails and it doesn't matter. Also if you are a rum fan, this is by far and wide the best selection of rum I've ever seen, it's rum paradise! Enjoy a night at Smuggler's Cove!

HToqdBghDzj5TdfqXuE1Rw.review_text: YESSSSS. This has got to be my favorite bar in SF! While it can get cramped inside, making it difficult to find seating, (you're basically looking for treasure ;) ) the drinks make it worth it! Honestly, everything on the menu is DELISHHHH. A favorite being the hot buttered rum! And be careful, cause even the tasty ones pack a punch. The only drink that I couldn't quite stomach was the Zombie (should have known by the descriptions, duhhhh) but it's literally 99% liquor!  The wait time to get a drink can sometimes be long, BUT TRUST ME WHEN I SAY THESE DRINKS ARE WORTH IT!

aSkapyboOyAqCRkNdof0Tg.review_text: Based on the outside appearance of this place, I would have never guessed anything that was open to the public lie within.  I was told this was a themed tiki bar, and oh boy, yes, it certainly was. A friend of mine had been here in the past, and thought I would like it because I'm all about themes.  Three stories tall, this thin narrow building has a true tiki bar theme. The majority of the menu is rum drinks and they have probably close to a hundred different alcohols (again, mostly rum) available to choose from. It seemed that the main draw for larger groups were the "fish bowl" style drinks, which the bartenders light on fire as part of their show.  There's a bar on the lower floor, as well as the main floor, and this place gets busy pretty early. It's a pretty cool ambiance, but definitely different than a typical bar, which made it difficult for me to figure out what I wanted to order. I settled for a $9 Hawaiian Sunset which look to have a million different things in it, but it had vodka, so I was all in! Prices are a little on the higher side, but they do take a lot of care in concocting their libations. They do a lot of things by hand which you don't see in most bars.  Fun, little place. I'd visit again.

TgDNtUDKLPLEiyL0xQBPSw.review_text: "There's naught no doubt so much the spirit calms as rum and true religion."  -Lord Byron  I don't know much about the guy that said that, but I do know that my spirits have been calmed by the luscious libations I've imbibed at Smuggler's Cove. Some of my favorites include the Rum Flip, which is a luminous, frothy concoction reminiscent of eggnog with a light dusting of nutmeg; the Mary Pickford, which I believe is a combo of light rum and maraschino liqueur (made from cherry pits, which gives off a nutty marzipan-like flavor); and the Kona cocktail, that has you diving through a pearly passion fruit foam to swim in an elixir of Jamaican rum and honey. The menu offers so many tantalizing options, it's hard to choose.  These cocktails are complicated and worth waiting for. The prices average around $9-10 a drink, which may seem steep, but each ingredient is carefully chosen for it's quality. Juices are fresh and hand-squeezed, and syrups are also made by hand. Also, you won't know it because the flavors meld so amazingly well, but many of these classic cocktails contain up to 3-4 different kinds of rum in one glass and will pack quite a punch. Don't worry, you will get your money's worth.  Although the bar is small, it is never over-crowded inside, which allows for a relaxed and friendly atmosphere. Here's a place where you can escape the banality of your humdrum life and feel like, for a brief moment, you've arrived in a mysterious and exotic locale. Which also means you may have to wait in line to experience all this amazement, but if you truly appreciate cocktails and rum lore, you will be duly rewarded for your patience.  -This review brought to you by Roget's Thesaurus

NlQOP6oMoIG5hddgDN37Bw.review_text: Great vibe in here- it's a little tiki bar.  Great selection of drinks, and I thought the people that worked there seemed to really enjoy what they were doing.

kk2oFTBSU9C2XshIVU7tXQ.review_text: What can I say about this that isn't already said? IT'S A DAMN PIRATE BAR! There's a lagoon on the lower level, boat decorations, tiki drinks and skulls everywhere. The drinks are scary dangerous juice-like, you will happily chug these down without realizing the sheer volume of alcohol you're imbibing. Fair warning, watch your intake or you'll be crawling home!  There's three levels, all of which are quite small. Since it's such a popular bar, be prepared to stand a lot and snatch up seats as you can find them. That is, if you can get in from the massive lineup that starts around 8 pm.  This place is highly recommended to at least check out and enjoy the amusement value. The drinks are also well worth the visit. I would love to visit again.

uSCYNal_CJDPGBYUAenyoA.review_text: There are some goods and bads about Smugglers Cove, but it's ultimately a very good bar.    The menu is impressive!  And I am exactly the kind of person who appreciates all the history and witty prose they put into making it.    In the end though it's not the awesome experience that it could be.  To sum up, it's like they said to each other, "Let's make a pirate bar, but you know...not tacky."  And what they should have said was, "Hey, LET'S MAKE A PIRATE BAR!"    There is a general lack of ruff and readiness that would have transformed it from a good place to get a drink...to a place that is just inherently fun!     To not confuse: I like this place.  I posted a picture of a giant cocktail served in a skull bowl to my Facebook wall.  I think you should come here and see it for yourself.    But there are some specific sticking points that have to be worked out:   1. You absolutely must get better music.  I don't know what you were playing, but it was dower.  I wanted Caribbean and rowdy New Orleans. I got Elevator and at best very tame New Orleans.    2. Unless you're a wine bar, it's important that glasses are served full (unless you're serving a cocktail in a champagne flute, in which case, you follow the same rules as for champagne).  That's just for your own ethos at stake.  A cocktail may be well worth $11 dollars at 2.5oz but if you hand it to me in a 4 or 5oz glass it certainly looks like a rip off.  And that makes me have less fun!  Fill the glass or get different glass wear.  And it's surprising that I would have to go over that!

kyG14FyCWmVW3Uefs_GE_Q.review_text: I have one thing to add to my reviews below.  One day I decided to give some strong recommendations to some friends looking for a place to buy some well crafted rum based drinks.  Later on I received a report that the drinks they had ordered were weak and poorly balanced.  Of course I couldn't believe my ears.  About a month later I met some fellow yelpers here for a powwow.  I had ordered a 3 oz painkiller and watched to my horror as the lady bartender downstairs quickly measured three 1 oz measures of rum by keeping the measure under the flowing rum and dumping out about half the measure in to the tumbler counting each time "One, two three" as if by uttering this incantation it was going to magically multiply the amount of rum in the tumbler like Jesus blessing fish and loaves of bread.  Needless to say the drink came out pale and sickly sweet.  My friend and fellow yelper Keane in the mean time had aquired a 3 oz painkiller from the upstairs bartender and his was several shades darker and the flavors were well balanced.  I can no longer recommend this place as somewhere to get well crafted drinks with this level of inconsistency.  After all, I have a reputation to uphold.  I will return, but I will very carefully choose my bartender.  You have been warned.  Despite the issue and the blow to my reputation I still think this place is A-OK.

mSCoQBKkYX7OwUsFhdqXnw.review_text: Loved it! Went last night with 3 other people. We got there somewhat early..prob 930ish...only a handful of people in the place so we got seats at the main bar. The door guy was crazy nice...explained the drink menu to us and introduced us to the  bartender. The music was very random though.  Extensive menu that is at least $10 a drink...but they are strong so you dont need many. The bartender (Mark i believe was his name) has some serious skills and was entertaining. He was even nice enough to to make my friend a new drink when she didn't like the one she ordered....she turned out not to be a fan of the allspice.   Overall good time and amazing drinks...definitly have to be in a rum mood :)

keXAEAqxwGZCQBxEMtxHPw.review_text: WITHOUT A DOUBT THE BEST tiki rum bar I've been to and I've been to most of them. It is a dark and exotic getaway from your every day life, which is what a tiki bar should be. There are so many drinks on the menu that I always have a hard time deciding what to try again/next.   I have FIVE go to drinks:  1. They make the best most refreshingly orangey Sidewinder's Fang ANYWHERE. I never leave there without getting at least one.  2. The Rum Barrel is a large drink for thirsty types and I HIGHLY recommend spending a bit more to get it in the souvenir barrel mug(definitely an ebay money item if you ever get tired of it).   3. The Rum Flip is a velvety concoction of eggnog type tastiness served in a coupe glass.   4. The Hibiscus Cooler- beautiful color, a little lighter on the rum, and of course refreshing. It is served with an edible cured hibiscus flower. Yes, eat the garnish!  5. Classic Mai Tai- This is not the overly sweet pineapple stuff you may have swilled at a luau in Hawaii. This drink is finely balanced with sweet and tart and packs a punch with two different types of rum. Refreshing and potent. Always reliably delicious.  Beyond the highly stylized interior and chill ambiance, what you get at Smuggler's Cove is an immense well researched menu of classic cocktails and innovative creations that are expertly crafted and mixed.  This is my favorite place to be.

-V4J9aFWYNgqICLwztX0Uw.review_text: Cuba libre is the best drink, silver rum cola and lemon juice makes me a happy camper:-)

Twywstt07eQ6Q5HpYcr3FQ.review_text: Smuggler's Cove is such a great bar. Great drinks, nice bartenders, cool decor (like you're drinking behind a waterfall at the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland.). They have a huge selection of rums and loads of exotic liquors to make some of the most delicious drinks I've ever had. Unfortunately the drinks are pretty expensive,  so I can only get a couple at a time to mark off on my rum passport, but I'm always happy to do so. This is, hands-down, my favorite bar.

YVNhgD9dtNbr9Ww-yxABdg.review_text: This place is tiny, and they did nothing to the outside to advertise.  If there was a sign, I didn't see it.  Once inside, we were greeted by the city's nicest doorman who gave us a little tour of the place...and I do mean little, and suggested some tasty cocktails!  From their drink selections, to their over-done island decor, this place was a hit!  The mellow vibe made for a chill night out.    Space was tight but drinks were good.  I'll be back!

fCfTM9atdzS8WkYD_VRX1Q.review_text: This place is awesome. You may have to wait to get in. You may have to wait for your drink. But the wait is well worth it. Delicious drinks made with care, served up in a fun, cozy atmosphere that makes you forget you're on some weird section of Gough street. Everyone who works here seems wonderful, so please be patient and enjoy this place which is a wonderful addition to our city.

1LFSJHvSErX-wjJ6Vtl9AQ.review_text: Can't say anything here that 700+ people haven't already mentioned - except that Smugglers Cove turned us on to the best rum I've ever had in my entire life! And of course it's incredibly hard to find, but when we're in SF we buy ron diplomatico by the box.   Always a good time, always recommended to visitors. Totally worth a visit!

DYSo6uOwPJ6jy479MLzf7A.review_text: The ADULT version of Disneyland's Pirates of the Caribbean ride.  Kick back atmosphere with cocktails that take themselves seriously. Naturally they have an archive of rum so definitely try some. It ranges from fruity with a flower to spiced biters. If you like it dark, give the Dark Prince. A rum version of a Manhattan. If you like the pinky yummy drinks pick one with a Hawaiian name.   For celebrations, they have a couple drinks that incorporate fire. Fire, drank, and booty. A pirate's life for me!

eV51cLnGnA2fx6hOsQecAw.review_text: I thought I would have liked this place more. There is no one Smuggler's Cove will be able to sustain itself with it's current limitations. 1. The decor is great. 2. There aren't enough bartenders 3. The drinks take too long to make. 4. The menu is like a book. 5. There are stupid rules about getting in. 6. They only let 49 people in at a time 7. The staff has no problem letting single girls stand outside in the cold while their friends are inside.   I wish I had something nice to say... but I don't.

76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg.review_text: Totally discreet location, so you have to pay attention to the address. Cute place with a pirate theme. Strong drinks! Not too much room to sit and each of the three levels is not that big, so it can get crowded fast.

jtXR2DdxyDqTrufLPV8gMw.review_text: oh smugglers cove .....I am in love with ALL your drinks and how friendly your staff is! Myself and my boyfriend have been coming here for our anniversary all the way from sacramento since we turned 21 to enjoy and drink nothing but the drinks that say "drink responsibly" lol and since we got really intoxicated , its nice to know that the bouncer Carlos stopped us and recommend us to get a cab and even a hotel to stay at so we wouldn't have to drive all the way back and get a DUI  and that shows not only are the staff at smugglers cove friendly but they care about their customers and their safety. WE will defiantly keep the tradition going !  Thanks Carlos for caring and telling us about an awesome hotel you are the best!

GwA7ywduQ0LOIjFOmAhGNg.review_text: This is by far my favorite bar in SF.  Such a great vibe...  Where else can you find a bar that looks like a pirate ship inside?  The drinks are strong and super yummy (and the volcano drink even comes with a fire show)!  If you haven't been here yet, you are missing out!

1kpMAKRZuAz3OzxBav3XTg.review_text: I've got a certain fondness for the well-crafted cocktail and was thus intrigued by the tremendous buzz around Smuggler's tome of a drink list. Having been birthed by the folks behind the kitschy Forbidden Island in Alameda, I was surprised to see a grown up version with all the fun stripped out. It's like the pirate's decorated after they scored their booty and hired a interior decorator from Pier One. Very well, though. I didn't come here to look around, I came here to drink blind.   We dove into the weeknight crowd, bellied up to the small bar and were met by the paradox of choice: the bottles gleamed on the endless shelves, every possible rum concoction with liquors we had to Wikipedia decorated the pages. Being that rum is straight crazy to my mainline, I opted for a gin-based drink from the festively-dressed barkeep and attempted a seat. Downstairs, a cozy seating area with a wallfountain from it's previous incarnation, Jade. Upstairs, who knows, I couldn't make my way through the crowd.  We waited, and waited. And finally received our delightful little coup glasses. Ready for the travesty? I've been twice and I don't remember a single drink I enjoyed. I know what you're thinking, I got blotto and forgot everything. Oh no, because you know how drunk recollections work, right? It all comes back when you're tipsy again. Well, in my inebriated states following, when people were touting its merits, I plumb had nothing to say. I know, I'm going to have to walk the plank for this one.

nXttVQRu86w-9BMhjT9tEg.review_text: As a rum bar this place boasts an impressive menu and many unique drinks. The prices were affording (in regards to San Francisco) and the drinks were strong.  This bar kills on the ambiance; picture Caribbean Pirate Ship meets Tiki Bar. The overall bar is dark an inside fountain and pufferfish lights along the ceiling. It's definitely on the smaller side, but they monitor the number of people they let inside. The only issue is that if you're not early you can count on finding yourself waiting in line - but it's worth the wait.  I'll definitely be a return customer.

l3ShcNqJyis2hQqH7LvehA.review_text: I know tiki bars, and I love tiki bars. Well, and tiki cocktails. Yeah, it helps if you like rum when drinking here. I'm steadily working my way through the menu, and have already been introduced to some new favorites. Love the atmosphere, hope they keep up the good work!

g-wssBxG2znpJVKZE2N-lA.review_text: first time I visited was late on a Sunday night so we walked right in and found a cozy little spot downstairs by the water. I loved my drink- I ordered something with hibiscus; it came with a flower which I loved. I've tried going back to this place a couple of times, but both times there was a huge line and so I decided to go elsewhere. Moral of the story: this is a cool place with cool yummy drinks, but since everyone thinks it's cool you will have to wait in line.

WF1o6AyXm6-NovD5dFnMOg.review_text: As promised, I wanted to update this review after a mid week visit.  *** Smugglers Cove is your best bet when that ticket to Bora Bora just isn't going to be a reality.  Now that the initial wave of lines have receded, the setting has calmed down considerably and you can actually settle into the dark cove for a well deserved drink.  The bartenders here are pure craftsman. Take a seat, pick a drink and watch the show.   A personal favorite: The Saturn. I can't pronounce half the ingredients that went into it, but I could drink it for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Enjoy Smuggler's mid week, when the weekend rush is kept at bay and the clock strikes 5.

psRJ0pMAKAufssK2t06a0w.review_text: Omg this place is so hidden you would never guess what was inside. From the outside it just looks like an old building with pitch black windows, but as soon as you open the door it's like you were transported to the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland. This pirate themed bar is super cool with a mini pond/lagoon, barrels and crates as tables, and two bars one upstairs and one on the lower level.   My friends and I came around 8pm on a Friday night and it was so crowded that the bouncer had us wait outside for a few minutes until people left because the bar had reached capacity. All the table seating was taken but we really wanted to try the volcano drink so we waited around until we were able to snatch a table in the back corner. Of course the table had no chairs because these other chicks took like ten chairs to put around one tiny ass table. So we ordered our volcano and the bartender presented it with cinnamon and a torch to make like a fireball out of the Flames coming out of the cup. The menu said it feeds four but I think two people could've killed it easily. The drink itself was really good. My boyfriend ordered the dirty bastard which tasted like alcoholic ginger ale (really good), and we also got the rum barrel and were able to take the cup home! Super cute souvineer.   This bar has an amazing atmosphere and delicious drinks, I would definitely come back.

1ZpFYS4VQJyDjnrqDdZZmA.review_text: I have fallen in love. With rum.  I used to like only holding hands with rum, but that's probably because until recently I had never really savored good rum.  If my then-roommates and I could afford it to mix with our egg nog at the Christmas parties we threw in our early 20's, it probably wasn't of the highest quality.  But GOOD rum?  Oh, my.  And what better place to enjoy good rum than Smuggler's Cove?  They do one thing at Smugglers Cove that normally annoys me to no end, but there it works.  I have been two times now... on a Friday about a week after they opened in December and just this past Saturday.  Being weekend nights both times, there was a line out front.  Now, I never, ever, EVER wait in line to get into a bar, but Smuggler's Cove is different.  For one thing, both times the guy at the door (perhaps it is was the same gentleman on both occasions) couldn't have been nicer.  He often thanked those of us in line for our patience and apologized for the wait.  He also handed out menus, should we want to pick our drinks before getting in.  The real reward, however, came when we walked into the bar.  I officially lost patience a few years ago for bars so crowded you can barely move or breathe, so I really appreciate the capacity control they do at Smugglers Cove.  Seriously.  The wait for drinks also can be long; it certainly has been on both occasions I've visited.  However, once again, the staff made up for the wait with excellent customer service.  The same bartender was working downstairs both times, and she... while working her ass off making complicated cocktails... took the time to look up and, again, thank me for my patience and apologize for the wait.  The same with the bar back on Saturday night.  They both easily could have stressed out and thrown a bunch of attitude at me and the other customers, but they didn't.  It was quite a different experience than I had at another trendy bar in the City that specializes in complicated cocktails.  This could have been a four-star review, but the staff kicked it up to five.  (By the way, I see from other reviews here that some people have had bad experiences with the staff at Smugglers Cove, but my interactions with them have been lovely.)  Now we get to the main event: the cocktails.  They are well worth the wait.  Like I said, I have developed a new appreciation for rum, and it's because I finally tasted really decent rum.  In December we were sipping rum straight, and it was just delicious.  The fancy cocktails also are yummy and up to the standards set (in my book) by Tiki Ti in Los Angeles, which I also have reviewed, and La Mariana Sailing Club in Honolulu.  I truly don't understand why I don't go to Smugglers Cove all the time, but I will have to rectify that.

TEyl8ytmy2KoiHLAZk4HDw.review_text: Just got home from my first trip to the Cove. Absolutely loved the ambiance and the drinks, was so much fun! My friends and i took over the top floor that comfortably seated about 14 people and we had a blast.  It was a rainy night and SF was dead so we seized the opportunity to check it out since it's new and normally too crowded. Yes the drinks take a couple of minutes to make, but they are well worth it. Average price was about $11 for a drink, but you only need 2 or 3. Will for sure go back, but won't wait in a line because if I can't get a seat, I probably wouldn't stay long.

1hzbPz7HV7myDX2HjAOX8Q.review_text: Awesome cocktail list!  I wish I lived in SF to try them all.  Really cool decor also.  Happy hour 5-6, $2 off cocktails!

K8oFqiivcSQNiHbYcQh0Rw.review_text: Went to Smugglers last Saturday as part of my wifes birthday celebration. The staff was very kind and did an extra fire show when we ordered several volcanos. People are generally excited to be in such a well thought out bar with great drinks. At one point the entire bar was singing happy birthday! I would highly recommend smugglers cove for any occasion on any night of the week! Thanks for making our party a success!

NQ0REATs1_MehrNtnCaV2Q.review_text: Another fantastic addition to my "SF Cocktails" list.  So excited to finally get here.  The place is owned by the same folks that brought you Forbidden Island in Alameda, which is mainly what had me so excited to go.  (In fact, Martin can often be seen hanging around in a Hawaiian shirt, & on the night I was there, was happy to chat about some of the cocktails & their odd ingredients.)  It was built into the old Jade Bar space, but the inside has been completely redone so that it now bears an eerie resemblance to the Tartuga set from Pirates of the Caribbean (think thick rope, aging wooden beams, Pirate chests, ship anchors, etc.).  The cocktail menu is gargantuan - there are probably over a 100, ranging from traditional favorites to intriguing new inventions.  In my few visits, I've had a ton of quite tasty drinks that pretty much run the gambit in terms of tiki-style cocktails, so I won't bore you with the details.  Read the menu, and if you like everything listed in a given drink, it'll probably be really good.  Sadly, the place is a little small and probably only holds around 100 people on three levels (a sizeable downstairs area with a bar and a good amount of seating, the smaller entry level with a bar and a few bar stools, and a tiny upstairs area overlooking the entry level with just seating).  On the up side, the doorman does a good job of keeping it from getting too crowded.  On the down side, this means that on a weekend, you might end up waiting for 10-20 minutes to get in.  I've read a few reviews complaining about slow service, which can be an issue of the place is crowded.  The entry-level bar is really only big enough for one tender, and the downstairs bar generally has one or two as well.  Add to that the size of the cocktail menu and the complexity of the drinks these folks are making, though, and it should be obvious why the wait can be a bit long at times.  However, I'd argue that a sophisticated, well-made cocktail is absolutely worth it; you're best served by gauging how busy things are when you get half to two thirds of the way through your drink and deciding whether it seems prudent to go ahead and get your next order in.  A little planning goes a long way in that respect.  On top of all that, they also do a kind of cocktail tasting club.  You can get a sheet from the bartender listing all the drinks & have the 'tender sign off each one as you have it, and there seem to be fancy prizes for those who fill up the sheet.  There's a similar club built around tasting all their rums, which are numerous & tasty.  (Did I mention that they do tasting flights as well?)  Great work, Martin!  Always worth a stop in.

yvutbGAYJdDNtziZJJvbuQ.review_text: This is a connoiseurs bar! Don't come here looking for club music. It feels like you're in the belly of a pirate ship. Join the mahalo club ( 10% off after $200) and start the rumbustion club (1 oz pours of 20 rums to start learning). A-may-zing! Awesome cocktail menu too!

RyWKKwLzLSWi_8bZd1QWYQ.review_text: As a friend said it so eloquently, welcome to Disneyland!!  If Smugglers Cove is good at one thing, that would be marketing.  From the beginning, with the months of PR around the clues to its secret location, to the custom mugs (yours for the taking with purchase of a $20 drink), to the check-off lists for going round-the-world and trying each of their rums or rum-based drinks - clearly they know how to market.   Could I easily bash this and say it sucks?  Sure. But truth be told, I had a good time.  The drinks weren't awful, the décor was nice, and the people running it sure care more about having a fun place to go than most of the trendy clubs in SF.  I'd much rather pay $10 for an interesting tiki drink than $10 for a gin and tonic. And the drinks were 200% better than the Tonga Room.   Will I make it my new hangout? I doubt it.  But I wouldn't discourage people to go and try it out - especially if you're into rum.   There is however one big complaint.  Most fine cocktail joints in the city are now using precise measuring for their drinks.  I'm generally OK with this when the cocktail needs to stick with some close measurements to keep its balance.   I do the same when I'm making many drink recipes at home. However, what I didn't like seeing was the bar tender getting rushed and under pouring the jigger in haste.  To make things worse they were using lots of small ice and then when the drink was short, just adding lots more ice.  I really felt as if I was getting ripped off on some pretty watered down cocktails.  What was worse, was the use of exact measurements, then the use of tons of soda water - why first measure everything, only to be totally inconsistent with the amount of watery ice and soda water?  They were also measuring when people simply got their rum neat - always a turnoff to me.

2t_dWhdm_ZDiseqtfv-p0w.review_text: Believe the hype.  Every positive thing you will read or hear about this place is true.  It's even better when you finally get to go and experience it yourself.  It's not just a bar it's an experience.  Nothing I can write will do this place justice. The bartenders were great and amazingly efficient considering the amount of people that were in there.  The cocktails were strong and the volcano bowl was a sight in itself. Start with that then go from there.  My friends and I can't wait to go back to try and start our rum tasting to join their Rumbiston Society.  If I could wish for anything more I just wish it was bigger because it's like a ride that ends to fast.  Best place to get drunk and stare at decor.

jTxVm8kdKBxdO3FpvFSM_w.review_text: Very fun place to take some buddies from out of town!!  Me and my friend had the "Puka Punch" which I'm guessing is one of their favorites.  STRONG drink, but very tasty -- it was literally gone in 15 minutes.  Atmosphere is laid back, mellow, very cool.  People are friendly, unpretentious -- you get the idea!  They have a pretty extensive drink menu and it took awhile to decide what to order.  It's definitely worth a trip back at sometime...  but only if I'm in the neighborhood.    It is a pretty small space, even though there are 3 floors.  The people beside us ordered the bowl of something that cost $36.  It's quite a show... the bartender comes and lights the thing on fire.  The bowl actually has holes on the side for 4 ppl to drink out of.  hehehe -- really gets you in the tiki mood.

irhyxVVykJAJsaozgXGN8w.review_text: I had an excellent mojito here, though it did cost $14. I spoke with a group sharing a bowl of a punch type drink. Seemed interesting, but I already had ordered a mojito. Pretty nice setup, with a rock wall fountain and nautical themed decor. Very cute stuff. The outside looks super sketchy, but don't let that deter you. I would definitely recommend it, but be prepared to spend some money.

RbWD2pFblRzsaWt1-6y4kA.review_text: This place is awesome. Took a long while to find the place considering that it does not look like a bar from the outside, but as I walked in, they carded me & explained what was upstairs & downstairs.  Right when you walk in, there is a bar. When you walk downstairs, there is another bar. The top floor is just a lounge area. So this place is packed with alcohol! Lots of rum. I was so hungry & asked for a food menu, but little did I know...they don't serve food at all. Just alcohol.   I ordered the kona drink. It was delicious! Staff was nice, and the place was creative.
