This is a bar for people who are into (or want to try) a little something different: beautiful Caribbean/South Seas/Shipwrecked decor, knowledgeable bartenders, excellent ingredients and a focus on social interaction and good conversation. You know, like bars USED to be. And yes, that means you can actually hear yourself talk there instead of just being drowned out by some overbearing bass beat. There is music playing ranging from exotica to lounge to other vintage styles, but it is meant as background atmosphere and not a replacement to conversation. This, I love! If I want to be drowned out by music, I'll go to a dance club.  This new bar specializes in rum drinks: Cuban, Caribbean and Tiki, but they also have a few other things on the menu too. The prices are not dirt cheap, but really no more than many other bars that can't make a cocktail half as good. The menu is fun to read and you can keep track of what drinks you've tried with a little "drink map" they will give you.  I preferred to avoid the peak hour lines and go early (around 5-7pm). Also, since it just opened and every hipster and their dog are trying it out, have some patience if you do come later as there can be a line or a wait for your well-crafted drink. But then again, this isn't a place that should induce you do be in a rush anyway.

pF7uEfsYCT_7AIKqBel2Xg.review_text: So I am a total sucker for Tiki or Barbary Coast themed bars.  This place is wonderful, the interior is simply decked out in piratical flair, but not in a ridiculous sense that it is kitschy...just fun.  Bartender was really nice and swift in pouring drinks.  I didn't go on opening night, so there wasn't a mad line, I went on Saturday at 12:30am, so I just walked on in and saddled up to the bar.  Bartender was nice, took our orders and quickly poured the drinks (without looking in an instruction book, as I've seen so many other complaints allude to).  Drink was good, high quality ingredients (as it should since most of the cocktails are in the $8-12 range).  Spent most of the time on the main floor, didn't really venture downstairs.  Rum list is epic.  Also had their house beer, a brown ale, which was quite good.  Will absolutely be coming back.  Great atmosphere, good drinks, wonderful service.  Very happy.  Just a note, there is no sign and no windows, so look for the red and green lights and black outside wall!

gji92ao5NAIrb3akKyqTZQ.review_text: Woohoo for a tiki bar that's not in the Richmond or Sunset. The drinks are fun and yummy. The decor is awesome. Been here several times now and have experienced a lite crowd to fairly packed but the service is always pretty good and the drink wait is never that bad.

-M6BLdr91MHtHxpSZjvAYQ.review_text: I seriously wanted to love this place! Anywhere that takes cocktail mixing seriously is totally OK in my book and I will wait patiently as you add the 11 different ingredients to make it a masterful combination.  However, Smuggler's Cove was SUCH a let down.  Once inside my friends and headed to the downstairs bar and stood obediently waiting to order our drinks.  I was totally cool waiting to order  - there was a big group at the other end of the bar getting flaming skull drinks and shots so I just waited my turn.  When I finally did get to order, I told the bartender we were going to step out of the way and we'd come back up to claim our drinks when they were ready.  I was trying to get out of the way of the big party AND understood that since my friends and I ordered 4 cocktails it might take a while.  I went up to the bar about every 5 minutes to check and I saw no sign of our drinks.  Finally after 15 minutes I decided to stay parked at the bar thinking maybe if she saw me there she would start making them. I realize she was busy but the bar didn't seem all that crowded and quite frankly, the bartender looked lost, confused, and overwhelmed - she was not gracious and didn't really interact with any of her clientele.   I very rarely write bad yelp reviews because i think its obnoxious but it took 45 minutes to get our drinks.  As someone who works in the service industry I was genuinely surprised that the bartender didn't offer some sort of apology for such a long wait.  As I said, I'm patient, but I'd like just a little acknowledgment of how ridiculous it is to wait 45 minutes for a cocktail.  The drink I had was delicious so I can't write this place off completely!  I think next time I'll go on a Monday...

Do7YdH7oWi9Ya8x1Tyrd-A.review_text: I want to love you, but there's no place for a wheelchair to party here.  Cocktail snobs, tiki fans, pirates and rum fans should absolutely check this place out. Unless you're in a wheelchair. Like too many SF venues, this is a tall narrow building with no elevator. The ground floor is almost all bar, and there's one tiny wheelie-height ledge (not a table, one of those kinda-bar shelves). If you wanted to hang out with friends here, forget it - you're gonna be sulking at the base of the stairs with your very tasty drink and maybe one or two other people crammed in next to you. If there's a bathroom on this floor, I didn't see it.   Everyone else: get there early or go on a weeknight as it gets crowded. Don't expect dancing or music, or food. Don't bring a huge group - this place is kinda tiny.   If you want a tiki bar, head for the Tonga Room, the Outers (Trad'r Sam) or Alameda's Forbidden Island, all of which are bigger and can handle a wheelchair that wants to be with some friends. Likewise, you can get awesome cocktails (tiki or not) elsewhere. If all you're doing is stopping in for a quick drink on your way somewhere else, it's worth a try. The drinks really were awesome, but if all I want is a great cocktail, I can go someplace with a table. Sorry, tiki pirates.

-wE8vpFmsvIwcbD9j-mUrQ.review_text: Amazing selection of drinks. I've been going here on/off for over a year and I think I've tried maybe 10 drinks out of a menu that is so large I don't know how people get through it all. But they do and they win prizes. The best part of the drinks is that all the juices are fresh squeezed here and the rum selection is insane. Ambiance is very old pirate ship, including a small lagoon on the bottom floor with netting. And the walls are planks. The only downside is that service can be very slow. I recommend going on an off-night like a Tuesday. Cheers!

5BLExC9OpFGkN7EvS2ICxg.review_text: Go on a weeknight (early). Sit at the bar downstairs where they have two bartenders (the one bartender on the main level looked really overwhelmed). If you're sitting at the bar, it's fairly simple to work a drink order in with the bartender.  I wish they still had the one way mirror in the Men's Room from Jade.

zXkOAUCk6s1PCzk_2nncXw.review_text: Love this place, but who doesn't love a good tiki bar?  Yes, the drinks are pricey, but they're potent as hell. They're a bit slow, but it's only because the drinks are crafted carefully and beautifully. All the ingredients are custom made, down to hand-crafted simple syrups, essences and bitters.   Hate mai-tais because they're too sweet? Go to SC to have one done properly, without any trace of that cheap gooey grenadine (I had a puka punch, and it was stellar). And with over 300 types of rum, a new adventure is just a top shelf away.

g6TmwkyUY4tquHreLluC2Q.review_text: 02.17.2010, Wednesday @ 6PM Four girl pirates invaded Smuggler's Cove for HAPPY HOUR. Did they make out with the booty? Not sure about that but they sure did have a merry time. This place is a treasure chest of strong delicious drinks from exotic faraway islands. (They seem to specialize in rum.)  Dark, dim and mysterious. (Imagine "Pirates of the Carribean.") This place is cute, clean, tasteful and cozy without the lecherous smelly pirates.  3 bars on 3 different floors -- we chose to stay in the bowels of the ship. (We didn't experience the slow-service that other people mentioned. And we had enough comfort space between us and the other "drinkers.") First Round: (By the time I arrived, my girlfriends already finished their first round.) Second Round: - AKU-AKU: Lighter and perfect for someone like me who can't really hold her alcohol. It was a delicious drink made with lime, pineapple, peach liqueur and Silver Reserve rum. - PORT AU PRINCE: Made with Haitian Rum, lime, pineapple, falernum, bitter and grenadine. Nice and strong. Third Round: yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0… yelp.com/biz_photos/15g0… -THE VOLCANO!: This definitely sealed our girlfriendship for the evening. Perfect because it serves 4. This drink could put one (or four) in a trance. Served to us in a blue skull with a burning fire in the middle. A strong concoction of pineapple, lime, passionfruit, maraschino liqueur and Private Reserve rum. The fire was created by soaking a marshmallow in alcohol. A fun drink with a price tag of $32! (Most drinks are in the $9 to $10 price range. Quite expensive but yummy and strong!) Smuggler's Cove spells fun and good times at a place that's decent and not bawdy! I want to go back with my girls to smuggle some more after-work girl-bonding moments over yummy drinks! Too bad, no food available and allowed. :(

2h1B3IUp1TejELkxfffEkg.review_text: Best Mai Tai's in SF hands down. The place is always packed so be prepared to wait. Door man is nice & friendly and is on top of his job to allow guests into the bar ASAP. Bartenders are very knowledgeable about international rums that they feature on their menu. Well worth the wait and price for cocktails.

ii7xNXQKCX2ziqByYcVTvg.review_text: This place was fun!  Never having been here before, me and a few friends stopped by for drinks.  First thing to note is that the only way to know you are at the right place is because a small glass door says "Smuggler's Cove" and there will probably be a small line.  Easy to pass this place up.  As soon as we walked in, we were kind of taken aback by the ambiance and atmosphere.  All the pirate themed decor and water falls and the like gave the place a really cool feel.  We went downstairs to get some drinks, and although it was semi-crowded, we were able to get our drinks and find a place to sit.  The drinks are definitely something else.  Many choices, and each one has its own little story in the menu.  Most creative drinks I've ever seen.  I watched the waitress as she was making mine and she had to have grabbed at least 6-7 different unlabeled concoctions of who knows what to make my beverage.  And it was delicious!  Strongly recommend checking out this place.

VtmfwoFZq1ApOkHB8LCVpw.review_text: We went here before seeing Xanadu The Musical, so all in all it was a deliciously kitsch night.  Started with the Three Dots And A Dash (named after the Morse code for "victory") and moved onto the tawny port-infused Dead Reckoning. I wanted to sample the Demerara Dry Float because the menu promised that it came with a "side of danger," but I was already hammered at this point.  Enter, if ye dare...

LPTq2-fZ9_TsG5o8lAWCGg.review_text: I love the Speakeasy type feel of this place, along with the artisan crafted drinks. We came here to meet up with a friend who was in town. Unfortunately the line was taking a really long time so we went down the block to Absinthe Bar. We came back later to have drinks and the ambiance decor was really unique. Love the fact that they carry every single type of rum known to man. The drinks are strong and everything is made from scratch. Can't get any better than that!

fwtwvFZdlykzQVMLcKE22g.review_text: Cute and strong drinks, awesome! Loved the decor, I've always been a fan of pirate themes. Met up with a guy there and was actually able to have a conversation, not loud at all, could use SOME music at least for a cool piratey vibe. Definitely going again soon. (Con: Hardly any ventilation downstairs, so muggy)

WJnEifJRkI6bCH2iw8brFg.review_text: I liked it!  Drinks were good, REALLY good! I was in the mood for a fun tiki bar and they delivered. The deco was perfect, a bit over the top but it's a pirate-themed bar. They even had pirate music playing, did you know there was such a thing as pirate music? I didn't!  I went after work on a Friday... got there around 5:45 and can imagine how CROWDED that tight little space can be on the weekends. The downstairs section seemed hot and I agree with another reviewer they could improve their ventilation down there.   Also, the drinks took FOREVER. I completely understand that the drinks are complicated and require a lot of ingredients but good GRIEF I spent more time in line waiting for a drink than actually enjoying my drink. I only had 2 drinks (this is really shocking if you knew me) as the bartenders seemed stressed/frazzled and I felt bad for them. Not sure what they can do to improve that, the bar is so teeny and there isn't enough room for 2 bartenders.   BUT- - - it's a PIRATE BAR, I will def be back!! (just not on a Fri or Sat).

zr1jj4D1Wj32qVBu18cKDQ.review_text: First of all I want to correct several misstatements by other reviewers:  - This is not a "pirate" bar! There's not a Jolly Roger, tricorne hat, eye patch, or stuffed parrot to be found! It's a "Nautical Rum Bar" people!  - Several reviewers mentioned the lack of music. There is music, but it's kept at a reasonable level so that the patrons can have actual conversations. And the music is appropriate for the tiki/nautical/lounge vibe.  - There really are drinks on the menu that don't contain rum. A whole page of them, in fact.  - When there's a line outside, it is because the bar has reached its legal maximum capacity and the staff wants to keep the inside of the bar pleasant for those inside. The last thing I want when sitting at a bar is a bunch of sweaty people standing behind me pushing to get to the bar to order a drink. The line at the door has nothing to do with trying to be chic, exclusive, or snobby. It's just about capacity control for the comfort of the customers.  - There is a Happy Hour. I usually get there later and drink just neat rums, so I don't know all the details, but get there early and ask the bartender.   Now on to my thoughts of "The Cove" as my friends and I know it.   The things I love about Smuggler's Cove:  - The drinks are the perfect example of what fine mixology can and should be. They are balanced, they are pretty, they are little sips of heaven. I don't care that they take a while to make. Good things come to those who wait and if you're not willing to wait for a good drink then there are lots of other bars in the city where you can get a mediocre beverage with a shorter wait and less money. But why sacrifice quality for quantity? Drinking alcoholic beverages should be about enjoying the experience, not about drinking so many drinks so fast you can't even remember them the next day.  - The decor takes me away from my every day life into a fantastical hideaway where I can relax and pretend that the two-story waterfall really empties into the Caribbean.  - The staff are meticulous about mixology and customer service. They are friendly, and even when they're busy, they acknowledge you when you're waiting for a drink. Most of the bartenders have been there for a while now and have most of the huge drink menu memorized, so things move a bit quicker than in the first weeks after the Cove opened. If that was your only gripe when you first reviewed the bar in December, I encourage you to go back and give it another try.  - The cocktail menu and rum list are educational. I drank a lot of rum at Forbidden Island in Alameda over the past 4 years, but I didn't really learn much about the distillation, the different regions and styles, etc until I joined the Rumbustion Society at The Cove. Sure it's a bit challenging to answer all the questions on the quiz after you've just downed seven ounces of rum in one sitting, but it's also nice to realize how much information you've picked up by following along on the assignments that come with the first 20 rums on the list.  - The "Mahalo Club" is an awesome way to repay the loyal patrons. If you don't know about it already, the Mahalo Club is a card you can get and each time you pay your bill and give them the card to run through, you get credit for the amount you've spent in that visit. When you get to a certain amount, you actually get a savings on your next check! It's not a credit card, more like a frequent-drinker card. Ask the bartender about it next time you're there. Every bar should have a loyalty card!  - I love that there is super easy Muni bus access from my FiDi office, and easy street parking when I drive in from the East Bay on a weekend.  - This bar knows what it is (even when a lot of the patrons clearly don't) and it sticks to that vision. Every detail is an expression of Martin's vision of the perfect rum bar.   The things I don't love about Smuggler's Cove:  - The lack of food. I understand why there is no food. There's no place for a kitchen, and bar snacks can get kinda nasty with everybody putting their grubby paws in a communal nut bowl. I just wish I didn't have to squeeze in an early dinner before heading over for an early drink after work. I understand it, I just don't like it.  - The lack of servers. Again, I totally understand why having servers would be a logistical nightmare. I just wish I could find a comfy spot on the mezzanine level and not have to go downstairs and wait at the bar for every drink.   Overall, I am a huge fan of Smuggler's Cove. If I ever move away from the Bay Area, I will miss it dearly. If you understand what Smuggler's Cove is all about, and don't go in expecting it to be something else, and if drink quality and atmosphere are important to you, then you too will love this bar! If you want a quick, cheap drink, with two ingredients and a bartender who doesn't know what Orgeat is, then this is probably not your kind of place. Great! More rum for me!

8Rkg8enfLbTe6ifWzeEREg.review_text: Great points for the quirky decor and the fun atmosphere. Drinks were good but I wouldn't say that they were very memorable. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing off their huge menu.   It's kinda small, so I wouldn't recommend going here if you're trying to have a quiet mellow night to catch up with friends. It's worth going for a quick drink to check it off your list that you've been here and move on.   Interesting bit: the drink they light on fire smells like cinnabon! You decide if that's a good or bad thing ;)

xUdatc17gX7Kd3G4h2n3MA.review_text: It took me over a year, but I finally made it back here. Rum is my second favorite drink. I want to love this place, but it's still a like. I can't stand having to leave my company who's holding our precious seats for an easy 15 minutes every time you want more drinks. On the up side everybody crowding around the bar were all very happy drinking their delicious drinks. It's a very friendly vibe. I'm definitely coming back on a week night.

wyoHFnfGRdN86Dh4AzjKrA.review_text: Smuggler's Cove is everything its name leads you to believe.  There are smugglers there.  Mostly of the mp3 and avi variety.  It's also a cove.  Well, a man made cove.  But at least there is a waterfall there!  All humor aside, it's a nice place to hang out if you already have a friends group with you.  There are tables, it's not TOO loud, the drinks are meant to be shared, and in the large scheme of upscale bar type things, Smuggler's Cove isn't terribly expensive.  Just don't try to come here alone, it's not that sort of bar, and the groups of yuppies celebrating their mid life crisis will not appreciate you trying to pick up their trophy wives!

NJOspTE_Ms-b8ACPKY73Ww.review_text: Awesome atmosphere and great cocktails, but be ready to wait both outside and at the bar.  Smuggler's Cove is a really cool place, but like a lot of popular places in the city it gets a bit too crowded to be worth it on a regular basis. You might have to wait in line outside, but at least inside, it is not too crowded. There are only a couple of bartenders and that is the main reason why it takes quite some time to get your drinks. All of the cocktails I tried were tasty and fit well with the whimsical pirate theme. The drink menu is extensive, but luckily the bartenders are super nice and will gladly recommend a drink to you. The bouncer was less nice, as seems to be the norm in the city. Nothing gets you in the partying mood like feeling like some kind of herd.   I think it is worth checking out, but again, it might be tough to become a regular because of the wait.

QI6Hh7M68LQfMw68vLlhmw.review_text: I went there for my birthday party. It was pretty crowded on Saturday evening. All the drinks we ordered were pretty strong. I really liked the ambience. However we got the table after almost hour.

yqqiCdmqCQCfna1IvAbpJA.review_text: We literally got there at 5:15pm on a saturday and the doors open at 5 and we had trouble finding seats! I can't remember which drinks we had but we had 3 drinks. The drinks were really good and the bartenders where real knowledgeable about the drinks. I would definitely come here again. I docked 1 star because this place gets really crowd and it took about 20 minutes to get our delicious drinks.

UtebnDNIh0GZC01kSpYTDA.review_text: You would never know this was a bar from the outside.  The interior is wonderfully decorated to be like a pirate's liar/ship. It was a bit warm downstairs but the drink options are fantastic.   Try the tiki bowls and watch your hair because they're all on fire! The bartenders are super quick and knowledgeable - they must be to keep this 8 page menu of one-of-a-kind drinks flowing! I hear some have their PhD in Mixology but that is yet to be proven.  A great stop for any local or tourist!

f0a_qmkJGRQZFZzXzssziA.review_text: $32 for a Scorpian Bowl, huh? One that is supposed to serve 4 but was made up of a huge pile of ice and about one person's worth of actual booze/liquid? Too well-lit, slow service, an f'ing line outside even when it was not crowded inside, much smaller than I thought it would be. A little bit of a fucking disappointment. To say the least.

9ho6UZdAr4KeLmSKYq90mw.review_text: Do you like Tiki drinks? check Do you like Pirates? check Do you like delicious car-a-melly, spicey, sweet and smoky rum?  check Do you like drinks that will knock you on your Bootie until you yell Arrrr!?  check Do you like reading through 17 ingredients per drink, in case 3 or 4 just weren't quite enough?  check  If all of the above are true, you will enjoy relaxing with friends at Smuggler's Cove.  It's difficult to not drink too much here, be YE WARNED!  The drinks taste like candy.  The service is great.  There is enough space to move and you don't have to overdress because there is some monotonously retarded hipster herd occupying the space making you uncomfortable to think of things other than appearance.  Hooray.

bW3HC_sBuEHRvE5FYTYO0A.review_text: Really crowded for such a random location (and a weekday), however the extensive drink menu makes up for it - I heart fancy drinks.  Every drink is described in detail in their novel like menu. Gracious bartenders will also help you if you're overwhelmed by the abundance of choices (I was).  +: It's a miniature Pirates of the Caribbean in SF.   +: Drinks are tasty and you get what you pay for (in a good way).   +: They light big punch bowl drinks on fire = a few seconds of amusement.  -: Limited elbow room.  There are 3 small levels, but it feels tight, especially when crowded.    Notes: Best with a small group. Not necessarily a place to get wasted at (if you're looking for that), but be careful, you easily can as many of the drinks have unpronounceable ingredients.   I'd go back when a guest is in town and is looking for something different.

UwRHhT1iP94QioH5TwFGvg.review_text: I will describe my experience with a series of words:  Unique. Fun. Crowded. Expensive. Pyrogenic. MUAHAHAHAHAHAH.

wSufVW03qQTQr1kSZ5pdFA.review_text: Awesome bar for rum lovers- delicious drinks, uber-friendly staff, and fun atmosphere.  You may have to wait for your drinks, as the bar gets super busy, but I adored the drink I was recommended - Sidewinder's Fang. Not too sweet, citrusy, strong enough, and damn good.   I also love how they don't use any artificial ingredients - juices are fresh, and I could taste the difference.

yJgW6cnzijxgWunnJzhxKA.review_text: Great location and decor but sugary sweet drinks. If you're looking for good drinks- go somewhere else

aJhKW-YPN7hjI4QNMgxfvQ.review_text: Been back several times since the official launch, usually on Tuesdays so as to beat back the weekend crowds that "R l00kin' 2 get thar DRINK on!". Great service,  and the cocktails excel with such scrumptious precision I am tempted to drink until blacking out (an unheard of thing for me - I'm good about not overdoing it). Last night, I was witnessed to the induction of the third "Guardian of the Cove" (tally up the purchase/tasting of 20 introductory rums in the Rumbustion Society" menu and you become a Disciple; another 80 and you become a Guardian). The guy received and official certificate AND a custom-designed red velvet Fez-O-Rama [fez-o-rama.com/index.php ] fez w/ the SmugCo logo embroidered on it in gold. Pretty Sweet!

rqtbkWcpREx9hv3X0jGRBg.review_text: This is a really great find. It's a pirate themed bar serving classic rum cocktails. They have hundreds of different types of rum and use quality ingredients to make delicious drinks which, if you're not careful, could make this place your first and last stop of the night.

BY1c2pa75jYrQDkNsaHGNw.review_text: The wait at the bar is ridiculous! It took me 30 minutes to order my drink, which is somewhat understandable because each drink takes about a million different ingredients. HOWEVER, what is inexcusable is that once I get to the bar and order my drink the bartender say "Sorry we're not serving that yet... waiting on the bowls." Did it not dawn on any of these people to maybe just maybe they should place a little note on the menu/bar reflecting that? Either fuck me over with the wait or with the menu, not both.   Oh just to add some salt to the wound the bartender was basically picking and choosing who would order next. So what if you waited 20, 30, minutes! All around a horrible experience.

N_ejwIpUiQBzWzh_LlNBXw.review_text: I really like this place. If you like pirates and treasures then this is the place to be. There's decors everywhere for a mini adventure feel. Awesome for group hang outs. They have amazing tiki cocktails and volcano bowls. Great environment for a fun night out. If you're going on the weekends, make sure you come early cuz it can get pack.

tXUniX2zQFZooeK2kc87Tg.review_text: Okay this was neat. I don't normally like places like this because they remind me of disneyland kitsch/rainforest cafe novelties - the kind of thing you find cool when you are little but then they all start to look the same. I don't know if it was because I don't normally go out on Mondays so that in itself was so novel, but I had a great time at the cove on Tax Day Monday and I can't wait to go back with a bigger group of friends. Part of the coolness is that you could live on the same block and never know it exists - it's entirely unmarked from the outside and just looks like some generic blackened windows (...if that's a generic thing).  It's more Hayes Valley than Western Addition, and stepping in from the cold, windy, pretty empty street into this pirates haven is never something you'd expect. Someone with a real passion for pirates decorated this place and got the vibe just right - the downstairs area actually feels like the inside of a pirates ship. I probably shouldn't comment on the drinks because the one I had was their regular "painkiller" served up in a special tax day pineapple -  but their menu is extensive, and with a bar upstairs and down, you shouldn't have to wait long for a drink. I'd imagine it's a great place to grab a drink before heading out, or make a post-work weekday night of it like we did.

PQPk3yifh1O0C7tYAmGfLg.review_text: +3 stars for the service - these guys are *always* in the weeds with orders, and *always* professional and gracious.  +3 starts for the drinks - classy, tasty artisan rum and other call brands, always tasty. *Always* - like for days.  Like Kanye - Ima rhyme alla time, now...  PS - Yes, I know it adds up to 6. Whut?  Whut?

djWl0HKJwEwWlY-0vo7oRA.review_text: Walking in, you'll be transformed to another place because of the decor. At first I thought it was a bit tacky looking like a cross between a tiki lounge and pirate ship, but the bar has kept the whole theme going with the menu, furniture and drinks, so it's actually kind of cool. They should have more bars that are themed like this in the city. I don't know if we'll ever get to the point of say, Japan, where they have toilet themed ones, but I think the Maid one will fly in the U.S. ;-)  Great variety of cocktails and even some to share among 4 people, which was what we got.  - Top Notch Volcano: excellent, fruity, sweet, great show with the cinnamon to light the drink on fire and make it look like a volcano erupting, good to share with friends - Punch Bowl: strong, light tea aftertaste, comes lighted in a skull bowl just like all large drinks served for 4 people

LTWUnGE5dCVGFsKuwuWV9A.review_text: This is currently my favorite bar in San Francisco. No bar has held the distinction for more than six months, but Smuggler's Cove has recently surpassed Blackbird for the title. Blackbird is still my go-to in the Duboce/Castro area, but if I'm meeting folks I'll push hard for Smuggler's Cove.   For background, SC is a rum-based bar in Hayes Valley. Parking is easy, but the drinks are strong enough to give you some pause as to whether or not you should be driving at all. The outside is nondescript. They seem to be trying to keep it all secret a la Bourbon and Branch, but the enormous line outside the bar on weekends will give it away.   The ambiance is awesome. Two levels, both with extremely kitschy pirate-themed decorations. If you don't go too far with kitschy, it's just cheesy. This goes all the way, and turns kitschy into cool.   The drinks. Oh, be still my soul. They say they focus on "traditional drinks of the Caribbean islands, classic libations of Prohibition-era Havana, exotic cocktails from legendary Tiki bars." I've had classic libations in Havana, and these are way, way better. From the complex, spicy "Three Dots and a Dash" to the sweet Jamaican Milk Punch, everything I've had there has been excellent. The bartenders are accommodating, and will answer reasonable questions about the drinks. And there is, of course, the party favorite, the flaming four-person drink. I can't remember the name, but ask for the flaming four-person drink. They'll know. It'll set you back $36 plus a $4 tip, but that's not too terrible. And it's memorable. Tasty, but more of an experience than anything. They have plenty of non rum-based drinks for those who prefer other alcohols.   If there's one con, it's that the place is too popular. There's a line and it's crowded. You might have to wait 15-20 mins to find a table for a group at peak hours. But go at a non-peak time, and you'll love the place.   Oh, and they take credit cards. DO YOU HEAR THAT, BLACKBIRD?

W3RgzbhOHuYx0OP4TUJ46Q.review_text: Always crowded up the wazoo. Oh, but it is so much fun! Come to Smuggler's Cove for some great rum, and a divey vibe. How can you pass up when the place is decorated like a pirate ship?   My only complaint was that we had to wait in line outside in the cold for a solid 15 minutes. I've never had to do that for a bar. Clubs, yes, but a bar? Yikes. It really does get that crowded.

bs0Nt1SUQSRjLm6j3N3CNA.review_text: I am crazy about Mai Tai's. This place DOES NOT make a good mai tai. It is waterdowned and tasteless. Instead, if you go, get a drink that's towards the back of the drink menu that is served with 4 shots. I don't remember what it's called, but is labeled strong (which is not TOO strong), and is topped with shaved nutmeg. The decor here is fun! It reminds me of pirates of the carribean.

mW8fvDQ3JAtzeLjU--CjTg.review_text: Loved this place! Came by with friends on Thursday night and went straight to the underground level. We had to wait for about five minutes or so, but then found a corner spot. They strictly control how many people are inside at any one time, so it was crowded but you were still able to talk. The bartender was super nice and quick and the drinks were good. Really loved my Painkiller, definitely down to come back at another time.

zBc9PS0G00vGpYuQwLueiw.review_text: It seems rather unfair to judge a book by its cover. Whew! Now that that unpleasant beginning has been properly dispensed with, allow me to jubilantly eviscerate this pretty little tiki palace that's sprouted like a poisonous fungus on the rotten corpse that was once called Jade. (Note: Even though I never in this evening actually was privileged enough to receive one of the acclaimed rum cocktails, I fully intend to visit this establishment early in an afternoon to try one of their libations.) Long story short.  1) Pulled up on my heel-toe express and gained entry to said establishment 2) Was pleasantly surprised by the fact that said establishment wasn't too busy, nor was it too dead 3) Was handed a menu by a friendly manager who somewhat resembled Chris Eliot from 'Cabin Boy' 4) Read said menu at one of the tables downstairs. Was mightily impressed with what they did with Jade's trouble-prone and stinky waterfall -- it now looks like an awesome tidal pool that is sorely missing some poisonous tropical fish 5) Last complement -- Frankly, I'm a fan of tiki decor, and Smug Cove (which I'm now going to call said establishment) has pulled no punches. It's authentically awesome. Upstairs is a series of rattan (I think) chairs with empty rum crates for tables. The staircase itself has been transformed into a literal tiki chute of palm fronds and bamboo. Maybe they have Bob Denver on their payroll; it's something the Professor could've come up with. I'm not being ironic. I quite like the look; I mean it when I say it's awesome 6) Here's where the complements end. So anyway, I finish reading the menu, and I've decided on the drink I'd like to enjoy. The bar upstairs is only one person deep, so I join the queue, visions of El Draque in my mind (a Smug Cove version of the mojito). I'll try to be polite here, because I realize new bars have growing pains. But here lies a niggling problem that even Jade suffered from: Poor layout. You essentially enter the bar through the door and are immediately put into a quagmire. It's a cattle grind on the best of evenings; a channel that requires moving only forward, or to the right, which takes you down a set of stairs. Not a good design. Yet it wasn't all that busy when I made my visit. Somebody ahead of me had ordered some cocktails, and wanted a separate check, or something. The bartender was having some problems with the computer. This took several minutes, whilst the bar-back was essentially standing there, doing nothing. And then the bartender was finished with the problem, and proceeded to work on the next exclusive cocktail, which looked literally exhausting to make. There were EYEDROPPERS of some liquid which were essential to making some elixir whose taste I do not know of. Yep, EYEDROPPERS. There were about three little bottles with EYEDROPPERS, which she painstakingly pulled from their little plugs and gently dropped three or four little drops into a glass. Then she pulled out an old-school seltzer bottle and squeezed certain amounts of seltzer into a jigger. Twice. I know I'm sounding like a dick, but here's what bugged me the most: She hadn't learned the drinks yet. She was still reading from the cheat-sheet, and doing everything whilst staring at a sheaf of stapled paper. Such complicated drinks (maybe purposely so, considering the price of said drinks), such woefully under-prepared bartenders. I'd waited roughly twenty minutes for a drink at this point, and I had a friend of mine coming to meet me: I thought I'd go outside and have a smoke. 7) So I head outside. The bar didn't really get too much busier while I was there, but for some reason there was a queue outside the pleather rope in front of the door. Yay. I had my smoke in the effing freezing cold, and my friend showed up. She was keen on checking out the joint, and I was pretty sick of the cold. Went back to the front (I like that sentence) door, and was surprised that the doorman wouldn't let me in with my friend, because, and I'm quoting directly, "It wouldn't be fair to the people in line to let you guys in ahead of them." Seriously.  So that's my review. I would have enjoyed the pleasure of reviewing the drinks, but sadly, that just wasn't in my cards this evening. Like I said earlier, I'll be happy to go back to have one of those blessed drinks, if only to have one and maybe taste a lovely 10$ El Draque, or a 12$ Rum Barrel. Fuck, I'll even have a Zombie. Give me something!  Another thing: I'm seeing a shitload of 5-star reviews. I'm not naive; those reviews are from friends of the owners and employees. There were like -- what, 5 -- days before the opening, with private parties. You can bet anything that the people who showed up at the bar on those evenings didn't have to wait twenty minutes for a drink. Nor did the bartender have to hurry trying to manufacture a libation requiring EYE-DROPS of some archaic liquid indigenous to some soil trodden on by pirates in 17th century Caribbean times.

LHsCa_aVta4UbbrcL4hE5A.review_text: While I thought the bar itself was really cool and unique, and the bartender was awesome and knew his stuff, I couldn't give this bar over 3 stars. It's tiny, so there was a line to get in. The menu is huge and a little overwhelming. My group got 2 rounds (10 drinks total), and after trying all of them, I would only order 1 of them again (unfortunately it wasn't one of the two I ordered). The majority of these were rum drinks and a few were recommendations from the bartender/bouncer, so I really was lost after trying them all.   Anyway, it's a cool switch from any other bar, but the mediocre drinks, lack of music and lack of space (and the location) all detract from the overall experience

Q2C3S9PctXPFIC82Qzsn2Q.review_text: 4 solid stars. this place is a rollicking good time and once inside, i'm grateful that they control the line. HOWEVER, it's still not easy to get group seating, so beware of coming here with a large party. i waited almost 2 hours for a table (friends were drifting in so it wasn't a chore), and only after i stationed myself near a table pretending to flip through their extensive menu and waiting for them to GTFO. i've gotta say, it sure felt satisfying sitting down.  as for drinks, i had the banana daiquiri (light with a tart kick to it) and the non-flaming mystery bowl (also delicious). if i still lived in SF, i would try to make this a regular hangout on weekdays.

_eaRP9qdB04g-QwCqtpJjg.review_text: I love this bar!  You walk in and immediately feel like you're on vacation.  Frou-frou drinks galore and the most unbelievable collection of rum on the planet.  And with the famed Marcovaldo Dionysos behind the bar, it's pretty hard to go wrong.  I plan to go back soon and share a Scorpion with some pals.

Wom5ss-owNYkxSy_j4s39A.review_text: I was pumped up about coming to this place and I was let down and I partially let my self down.   As previously read, you would never know this placed existed when walking by. A sign nailed to a tree is all that hints theres something near. Friday and Saturday nights the line around the corner also lets you know you've arrived at your destination.   The door guy was pretty cool, a bit arrogant, calling the line "my line", you're watching the door guy, relax. The group behind us was openly drinking beers and passing around a bottle,I thought it was the thing to do until he walked up to them and gave them the, "I think its pretty rude of you to be doing this in, my line". Comical nonetheless before even stepping foot in this place. The group in front of us had a bottle also, which they hid immediately. The girl was pretty dam snobby herself and this door guy laid into her, in front of her dude, it was hilarious. He made her wait til last to check her I.D. and walk in the place. He did it in such a cool way though, I was a fan of him by now.   Finally, upon entering this place, it was instantly like a scene from, the Goonies, one of my favorites tip this day. Anyways, it was almost too much to take-in in one stay, especially knowing you're gonna have tikis in your system real soon-ish. I walked upstairs and it was super hot and jam-packed, no seats, no bar, just places to sit. It had a plank though, pretty cool. Back downstairs at the bar, tick... tick...tick... tick..., if I had a mirror I could have watched my freshly lined up to perfection beard grow. I made my way downstairs, I knew there had to be another bar in this place, you can't have a bar with three floors and only one bar!!!  Downstairs there was a bar and it was less crowded, still a good 15-20 minute wait for my drink"s". Yes, I double fisted tikis after seeing how long the wait was, glad I did too because the drink I was going to get first, had a pretty flower in it. Kona Kuna I believe it was called. It was complimented quite nice with the Zombie, which is the strongest drink in the bar, which they are required to tell you. I heard it 70 times. These bartenders were on top of their shit though, they knew what was going on at all times, kept their cool dealing with the crowd, stayed polite and efficient. Its cool watching them make the drinks, I bought a souvenir mug and kept my swizzle stick. I knew I was not going to remember shit, that Zombie is quite potent. A group behind us ordered the Scorpion which they put in a huge mug, give you two-foot long straws and set a flaming rum-dipped sugar cube in the center and make it a flame-thrower before leaving it to you. It was a cool show, we smashed and left. By the time I got to the door I was basically out. Blacked out on the BART. Good times!!!! Good BAAARRGGHHHH!

WB_BwBAZlipXu1RTUMrUlw.review_text: I'm pretty easily amused, which is probably why I find the whole tiki-bar scene wildly entertaining. Smuggler's Cove is like a tiki bar on steroids (the subtle, pro-level legit kind) that has literally been shipped out to sea.   My experience was a little atypical because I went during non-peak hours--around 5:30pm on a Tuesday. I didn't even have to wait for my bucket of rum, which was SWEET. My girlfriends and I had a blast sipping on our tropical extravaganza whilst taking in the tri-level scenery.   Definitely a destination bar (not much else around) and 100% worth checking out. I know some people like to snidely compare it to drinking inside of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride--but how is that a bad thing??? It's like taking the best part of Disneyland, transporting it into the middle of San Francisco, and dousing it in rum! I'M ON BOARD, HATERS.  Smuggler's is simply awesome and I can't wait to go back for a more raucous experience.

wIs7BiEcGzb2Z7eXWvk1pA.review_text: Back in the day... when Jade bar was located in Smuggler's Cove's current location, I could throw a $20 bill on the bar and be puking around the corner within 3 hours after drinking half a dozen $2 wells, and leaving a generous tip.  Today, I can be puking around the corner after 3 Rum-based cocktails and throwing down two $20 bills.    I'm not saying that puking is my goal.  I'm just illustrating the expense.    I like Smuggler's Cove, but it's too expensive to be my local spot, or a happy hour bar.  It's definitely a treat.   I love the concept of a rum bar and it'd be a great group activity place, however the size doesn't lend itself to groups.  So, Smuggler's Cove...I'm still trying to find a place for you in my life.

bNpy0uzbh7BT2Wnd5eReTw.review_text: ARRRRRRRRRRR Matey! Ship's ahoy!  Ok, now that I've got that out of the way...I happened to stumble upon this place finally on my way back from a guitar performance up the street and saw this long line outside this place so decided to check it out. I also realized that this place is on my list of 100 things to do in SF and it's definitely a surprise once you walk into the place.  There are 3 floors of pirating to be done here. The day we came the upper floor...which is also the middle floor was cash only but the downstairs accepted both cash and card. This apparently slowed the line down a bit...hence the line outside and the strict bouncer who kept us all in check. It was nice having him handle the crowd control because there was plenty of space to walk around and explore.   We ended up on the upper deck and sipped on our rather expensive rum drinks. We didn't have enough cash for a 2nd round of drinks so we carefully stretched out our drinks. Everything here's got some sort of rum in it and the most popular drink of the night seemed to be the volcano, fire, cinnamon explosion thing (I don't know what it was called) but I'm pretty sure the bartender is missing some eyebrows from serving that drink so often.  Anyway, cool decor, good crowd control, and great selection of rum but broken credit card machine, long 30 minute wait outside in the cold and not-so-cheap drinks. Still, it was a fun experience. Maybe I'll come bar hop here again during a future bachelor party or something.

MDsO-PrVw7GqB6cN9ye4zQ.review_text: Love this place. So many fun drinks and such a cool, quirky vibe. Great place to take a group of friends for a night out. Bring your drinking pants, you'll need them.

Rm1dH8jqMUZ9io4JduZrnA.review_text: Three times now in the past three weeks, all for weekday happy hour at the 5pm opening time. I can understand how Smuggler's Cove provokes such passionate (both negative and positive) reviews. Yes, there is often a line outside and it takes a while to get a drink. However, if you like your drinks made to order, your patience will pay off. Then again, I practically live at the Orbit Room and I am willing to wait a while for a well crafted drink.  Big fans of the Mai Tai done in the style of Trader Vic's as well as the Dark and Stormy. The Planters Punch was delightful. Get here early and grab a seat on the balcony level overlooking all the action on the main floor. The decor is fantastic! It's also great to see the owner hanging around.

AQ_gtLkm7UPeTFNNShW-Vw.review_text: Great bartender, could hear my friends talking, only needed one drink all night - Zombie.  It's the morning after and I feel reasonable.  It does get a bit crowded, but after 12:30pm it mostly cleared out.  Loses one star because there are no food options.

Suw8tiW7EHWpt7HhuB7SDw.review_text: Ahoy matey!  Blame the night's earlier libation or the mere fact that there are ropes on the ceiling and I like to monkey around. Here I am, perched at the bar, both mesmerized and impressed by the bartender. At the same time, envisioning myself pulling on the 20,000 Leagues diving helmet and swinging from the rafters. or maybe the cannon.  It was one of those nights.  No, not like *that*, just of good vibes and deceivingly strong drinks.  Between the whirlwind of pineapple leaves, floating orchids and flames shooting up towards the palm-strewn, fire hazard of a ceiling, it's no gimmick. What sounds like a "girly" drink is, in fact, a well balanced cocktail.   Feeling less than tiki? Viva Havana! El Presidente was outstanding.   Another winner: Three Dots and a Dash. V for Victory.  First timers: Rum Barrel. Why? Because your friend could finish their drink before you read the whole menu, so start here. It's equivalent to nearly two drinks and will give you time to ponder the next.  Mixed crowd here, albeit on the younger side, but a solid mix of SF: good vibes, quality drinks and a pirate-wannabe on deck.  Next time you want to brush up on your Morse Code and Caribbean spirits, you know where to go. Walking the plank not required.

BS3pbtZJAAa3_q5g1oD6Yg.review_text: basically if i hear the words "coconut milk" and "cocktail" together in a sentence, i'm all ears...and pirates of the caribbean-worthy atmosphere, you say? i'm there! my nautically-obsessed friends have been talking up smuggler's cove for the past few months, so i've been dying to head over.   this sunday, it finally all came together -- myself, friends, the coconut milk cocktail (i had the tradewinds), an indoor waterfall and all the awesome maritime decor a gal could ask for! i love that they play music quietly at smuggler's cove so you can enjoy conversation with your friends while you sip from a truly en fuego concoction created in a ceramic skull. and did i mention they make a lot of their own juice here? and have zillions of different kinds of rum from every island imaginable (and tennessee too)? if you can't afford the trip to the islands, or even the blue bayou, this place'll do the trick and then some!

8LwK0MS-s5N282VfVszB6w.review_text: Love this place. They will set your rum on fire. Also,, had the best bartender- ask for Melissa! :-)

G96eAh4n0ksknavhExYr6A.review_text: So my Guy Took me here a few years back and i fell in love with the drinks and the way its set up.. i love that it look like a private club its small but the people are cool the drinks are great i love them.  So i took my best friend here for girls night out and she loved it i want to make this my spot but i live in the east bay .

kDk5Sun6adcCkcMdslBJIg.review_text: didnt get a drink here... waited a while but didnt get acknowledged and it didnt seem busy. the tiki theme seemed pretty cool. hopefully when i go to hayes valley again i will check it out.

KivTl6k7urUMhPqPj-MDaQ.review_text: I brought some out-of-towners here last week and was satisfied.  The layout is fun with the three-story setup, multilevel waterfall, and authentic-yet-Disneyland kitschy pirate/Caribbean interior.   The drink menu was informative yet overwhelming, and after settling on a glass of grog we set up shop down below.  The second bar downstairs is convenient, especially given the time it takes the bartenders to craft these intricate double-digit priced fructose-filled masterpieces.    I liken Smuggler's Cove to Bourbon and Branch: Theme-y, fun for a drink or two but not a destination bar per se.  Worth checking out.

_V9caOx_BhRz_zpXzxnZQQ.review_text: Came here for a friend's birthday. Was quick to get in because we came early on  Saturday night (around 8 or 9). I'm sure if we came later it would have taken longer if we had come later.  It was also very difficult to initially get a table & seats downstairs, but we managed to make some friends and get one. We couldn't get the Volcano drink without a table, so we were excited to finally be able to get it! It was delicious, as well as the other drinks. The bartenders are incredibly friendly and very helpful!  Protip: the Hot Buttered Rum is a MUST!

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: They have the best bartenders in town. If you're a rummy then this is your bar. Great selection, great menu, interesting decor and a great setting to blow you paycheck on some amazing drinks. All that being said.....   I miss Jade. I miss the cheap pre-made punches and happy hour pints. I miss the small bites, the crowded happy hours and the empty late nights.   The problem with this place is that you took a small bar that served a lot of pre-made punches and you turned it into a handmade cocktail bar, but you didn't expand the place. I've been here twice and probably won't go back.   The idea is great, the execution left we waiting for attention in a really crowded place.

I-02Mz45H7siHsjjgVxPgQ.review_text: Smuggler's cove is just AWESOME!!! I arrived for a family members birthday pre game warm up and at 6pm they had a line down the street. REALLY!?Once inside the theme of this bar is living as a pirate. they even have a moat in the bottom floor.  If you are a fan of Rum drinks well this is your place to go. The drinks are pricey and I fully agree BUT you get what you pay for. The bartenders here are not bartenders, but instead Mixologists....All the drinks are made with all natural ingredients and from what I observed any drink you order from the menu has at least 6 or more ingredients in the drink. Another thing that sticks out in my mind and is the obvious, you can't tell from the outside that this place is a pirate ship themed bar. The decor is so detailed and even in the bathroom they have the Yo ho Pirates Theme song lyrics on the wall.... I highly suggest just checking this place out yourself and get there early to avoid the line!

iKjjUcksCUFII1V8f1yV4Q.review_text: WTF, San Francisco?  How can so many people have so many positive reviews about this dive bar?  The doorman is rude with an air of self-importance that you might expect from a hot night club in NY or LA; not one befitting of a man working the door at this lowly bar.  It just gets worse from there on out, but OMG was the doorman a prick.

WL7RlmPlDRu30ApCbVcc2w.review_text: great atmosphere + amazing staff + delicious drinks = 5 stars! the staff was knowledgeable, the drinks were very flavorful, and the scenery was very cool. i felt like i was in a bar in the caribbean. get the kona cocktail, it's just as delicious to drink as it is pretty to look at :)

eFmMHYI869hc80BmpdYZ1Q.review_text: Guaranteed to get a nice buzz going if you order a drink here.  Cocktails are $9 and up, but well made and very tropical indeed.  Worth checking out for fun, or on a random night.

8KMdDFleZUmFeqHofKhIfg.review_text: I'm one of those people who used to take the mystery train out to Alameda to visit Martin Cate's original tiki-time-machine, "Forbidden Island."  When I heard he left, I was practically in tears. He literally changed my entire attitude toward creativity and spirits.   Therefore, I was very excited to hear Smuggler's opened up in SF, right in Hayes Valley, but I knew the crowds, at least at first, might make me pout. I had been spoiled walking into F.I. and having ALL the attention! ;-)  So anyway, I decided to check out the Cove on a rainy Monday night and it couldn't have been better. The recipes are divine, it's cozy and you feel like you could hang out with your friends for hours. The rum-nerd aspect gets me where I live; I love to read all the menus and background and I'm ready for MY QUIZ, baby!  I'm sure you could just walk in here without a clue and be pleased to be served a great drink with such warm hospitality... but if you care about the chemistry and art of fine spirits, this is REALLY A TREAT. Martin has gone above and beyond... long may he wave three dots!

yY77W4CAgbA45er1oIFpbw.review_text: Really fun, cozy, and friendly bar - great bartenders and chill people. The only reason I hesitate to give it a full 5 is the long line that forms at night (for good reason). Definitely a place I'd come to earlier in the evening when it's less packed.

oWa0GAB8Nz525sp1gs2m1Q.review_text: I have been to Forbidden Island several times, used to live near the Tiki Ti, had drinks in Hawaii, the Bali Hai, "virgin" drinks at the Luau and Don's when I was a kid,  and had drinks served to me by Beachbum Berry, but Martin Cate's Smuggler's Cove is different, and dare I say... better?  Spicy drinks that aren't just well blended syrups.  There's a lot of thought and work in these drinks. (Not that there isn't in the afore mentioned! they're great too! -uh..except Hawaii) Tonight was a "soft opening".  The bartenders did great considering the complex drinks they were making -using ingredients you would be hard pressed to find anywhere else in the city.  Chocolate mole bitters?  Come on! What makes Smuggler's Cove rise above is that they use stuff that even Tiki diehards won't have stocked at home (at least not yet), and as much as we've all tried to make our tiki bars awesome, we don't have a 10 foot anchor, 2 story waterfall, and a three story building to dedicate to our cause. (at least not yet). Anyways, this is the tiki bar to beat.  And it's in my city.  And a 10 minute walk away.  Dear god...  edited to say: Try the Pampanito!  Also the Chadburn is a unique and awesome experience.  Edit: to Thomas B., being on a mailing list and granted an invite to a soft opening because you are on the mailing list does not make everyone friends of the owner.  I have talked with the owner a few times from the other side of the bar, but my 5 star review is due to the fact that some of the drinks DO require a few droppers of something.  (an original Zombie has a tiny bit of Absinthe for example).  When the opening rush is over, I hope you get your drink.  Me, I ignored the opening issues, and focused on the drinks and decor.

TyEhVoNi3DHqGsOC7_RG5g.review_text: I love this bar and only wish I lived closer so I could go more often and be familiar enough to be a regular. Happy to know that this place keeps their standards high so that no matter how infrequently I go, I am never disappointed. So, I have nothing to say but want to tell a story that shows how much they really care that you enjoy your time at this little sanctuary!  I went here a couple of weeks ago with a friend. By the time we got there, seven or so, the it was packed from basement to tippy top. We sat on the stools near the wall and the bouncer and studied the menu and chatted while we waited patiently for a spot at the bar on the main floor.   Patrons came to our aid, telling us that there was space in the corner if the guy in spot would move over (he was in the bathroom), and they were sure he would because he was a nice, friendly guy. So, we sat down and sure enough, this guy was a nice guy and had no problem with this at all.   My friend ordered our drinks and the bartender didn't hear her so I ended up with the wrong drink. When he set it down, he said, "here's your **whatever***(I even forgot what I meant to order). I said, "Oh, I thought I ordered blah blah." He said, "I can make you another." And I, not wanting to waste and going with the flow, said, "Oh, that's ok, I'm sure anything from this bar is good."   So I drank it. And, it was good.   When I was ready for the next drink, I decided to order what I initially wanted. And the bartender said, "Since this is what you ordered, this one is on the house, but I promise you the first one was better." So, I got my initial drink, on the house. It was delicious. But, dammit, he was right...I DID like the first drink better.   I always rely on the kindness of a really awesome bartender. Thanks, Dude!

3MMTwPtpiMlBDe-p07XK9A.review_text: Maybe it says a lot for my maturity level, but the name of this places makes me snigger. It makes me think of men walking around in unflattering "budgie smugglers" at the beach.  Beyond the entertainment that the name brings me, there's lots more. Behind a fairly inconspicuous doorway, Smuggler's Cove is a three story tiki treasure trove.  Offering varied places to sit, two bars and well dressed bartenders making delicious (mostly rum-based) cocktails with all sorts of fruit, paper umbrellas and swizzle sticks poking out the top. The decor features fishing nets, sailing maps and other funky details that really play to the whole tiki/pirate/sailing theme. Arrghhh me-hearties!!  I loved it and simply asked the bartender to make me "the most extravagant and over the top drink you know how to make". What I got was the Smuggler's Rum Barrel, a drink that is described on the menu as being a "secret blend of fresh juices, authentic Caribbean spices and several rums " - the recipe apparently known by the bar owner.  It came complete with a swizzle stick (which I stole), an orchid and a sprig of mint. It was as refreshing as it was boozy and had I had an appropriate bag with me, I could have paid an extra $8 to have it served in a barrel mug that I could take home.

r30XfaJ66IKISg2fuzjtTg.review_text: Rod the bouncer made me feel very uncomfortable about my service dog and wouldn't let me show my cousins this once friendly and cute spot because I had a service dog and it was busy. He asked me what my dog serviced exactly. Very aggressive and not welcoming.  There are too many BETTER establishments that respect a service animal and it's owner.   Will be sending visiting friends and family elsewhere.

e8vBrfCDWjLl3I-okJu0gw.review_text: Update:  Apparently  I'm "the reason why Yelp is inherently inaccurate."   LOL!  The following note was sent to me after my Truthful review of my experience at Smuggler's cove.  Below the note is my rebuttal.   This Justin guy doesn't help change my opinion of S.C. one bit. If anything, it tells me to stay completely away from the place.  I hope you do the same if you miss Jade Bar. Case closed.  Take a pass on S.C. --- From Justin O. --- yelp.com/user_details?us… For your review of: Smuggler's Cove A select few? There are throngs of people willing to wait in line to get in on a Sunday, in the sun, during pride. You are the reason why Yelp is inherently inaccurate. --- My response ---- LOLHAHA!  Why did You take offense to my story about what became of Jade Bar?  We clearly  are not on the same page.  I don't take offense that you feel I'm not accurate with my review, though I'll say that I am biased because Jade Bar is greater than Smugglers Cove, IMHO. But I'll just say this...my review is for the neighborhood soulful folks who used to come to Jade.  The new place is strictly for a different clientele.   Have a good one, and good luck with your solo review of the place.  Also, You're either a business partner/employee hiding behide a new account as not to attract negative attention, or a new patron.  Either way, thanks for the note. -----------------------------------

GFoPL0oIOZxyByRIXGZ6ng.review_text: I think this bar would be way more awesome if it wasn't stuffed to the gills with people. The atmosphere is laid back and all, kind of surprising considering how many people there are, but there were just too many people for me to feel comfortable. Plus some of the people were super obnoxious, but I know that's not really the bar's fault...  Decor was pretty fun, and I thought it was neat how they had three levels. The menu is, as everyone has already said, HUGE. It was pretty hard to pick, and then it started to all blur together, like, pretty much every combination of rum, lime juice, pineapple, orgeat, falernum... etc. etc. But that's okay.  It was also a bit tough to order, and we probably waited at the bar 10-15 minutes before the bartender finished what he was doing, but so few bartenders for so many people, it's understandable. I got the Three Dots and a Dash, and it was very tasty. Not cheap, but good. We'll probably go back.

vbVLncmspzyyDrr7BViE8Q.review_text: I thought I knew what pretentiousness was.  I knew nothing until I arrived at Smuggler's Cove.  I don't mind lines.  They aren't my favorite and they kill buzzes but whatever, they come with the territory.  What I do mind is Shia Labeouf and his man-bun harping on how his bar is the 16th best bar in the world.  Thanks buddy, you just gave me 15 reasons not to come back.  I'll sum up our dealings with him with the following back-and-forth:  Us: *talking normally*  Him: If I have to tell you for a 3rd time to quiet down, you're outta here.  Us: That was the first time you've talked to us.  Him: You should have seen me and understood.  Us: *puzzled*  We waited outside for about 20 minutes while Shia continually reminded us to have our drink orders ready because, at the 16th best bar in the world, some drinks have over 20 ingredients.  Fantastic.  Wonderful.  I can't wait.  We eventually get in and are immediately met with another bouncer (bar back? manager? server?) who told us not to follow our friends downstairs because they'd be right back up as it was so packed.  We should go to the upstairs bar, order a drink and wait there.  He then proceeded to give us detailed instructions on how to order a drink at the bar (because apparently we didn't know the proper technique for asking, "May I have this alcohol, please? Here is money for it".  We followed our friends downstairs anyway because F that S and found it to be not crowded in the slightest.  In a downstairs area with approximately 45 people, they had one bartender and one bar back who was occasionally taking orders from guests.  Why he couldn't bang out the vodka-sodas was beyond me because the bartender barely kept her head above water with the magical, life-changing, 16th best 20-ingredient cocktail in the world.  I ordered a vodka-soda in the hopes that I'd get it quicker.  How wrong I was.  Twenty-five minutes later I had no such relief, and I left.  I work in the restaurant and hospitality industry.  That doesn't necessarily validate my opinion, but it frustrates me to see places that are putting tangible items (liquor selection, cocktail list, etc.) above their clientele and their clientele's experience.  That is not sustainable as a business.  A winning smile and quick drink wins over style any day in my book. Style over substance does not a successful business make.  They weren't the 16th best bar on that block. I'd never go back.

GbyToEhmPY8vl1CwwIFBTw.review_text: Got a chance to visit Smugglers Cove. A beautiful and fun  shrine to rum and drinks that it is mixed into.   Great location. Seems to get plenty of peeps. Better get there on a weeknight else get there at opening time. They do get a queue and waiting out in the cold is not fun.  The bartenders here really exceptional. They know what you want even if you don't. This is a trait I have experienced from Martin himself back when he was co-owner of Forbidden Island.  Just as good, maybe better than Forbidden Island. Let's just say they are sisters.  Five Stars. I say, check it out.

50cvRsElSKXAHoAEbncDDQ.review_text: The best rum drinks hand down! Martin is a genus.

MA1l0CfI42GPe2afAPLRnQ.review_text: Nice place! Worth waiting 30-45min (freezing) outside. Great drinks, the bartender in the lowest floor is really good. Don't miss the Smugglers Cove drink, fruity but sour... so good. Ask them to prepare it with Santa Teresa Rum, it will leverage the drink since it's an amazing rum, so thrilled to find it in this place!

XUFwhyeb8-cKV1v707DAlg.review_text: What can I say?  Martin Cate has done it again.  I no longer have to drive across the 'dangerous' bay bridge to get my tiki fix!  For within the Smuggler's Cove all dreams tiki and nautical are fulfilled.    More to the point:  The drinks are extraordinary!  I had a Navy Grog and a Jamaican Milk Punch and tasted an El Presidente, a Dark Prince, and the special reserve rum made especially for Smuggler's Cove.  All were incredibly well-made and the flavor profiles were spot-on.    The transformation from the worn-out, wannabe sleek, Jade, is nothing short of remarkable.  The upper level has been turned into a thatched hut, akin to something you would find at some swanky Polynesian resort.  Instead of looking down into the turquoise waters of the Pacific, one sees a beautifully reconfigured bar and an impressive anchor suspended from the ceiling.  The waterfall remains, but it has been enclosed and as you descend into the lowest level, you really do get the feeling that you're descending into a pirate's lair.  The remodeling of this level is absolutely beautiful, giving the impression that you're about to divvy up the loot within the hull of an abandoned pirate ship....Or, you've just given up your last E-ticket and are about to ride Pirates of the Caribbean for the 17th time.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

hvjhcPOG8zuqqLOohDKBmA.review_text: First time coming here, the outside does the business no justice. Yet, the moment you walk in, prepare to be awe-inspired by the decorations. Opening directly into a walkway facing the bar, there is a stairway leading upstairs to additional seating area. As you walk downstairs, there is a blue gleaming pond under the stairway leading to another room with a small bar. The waiter was extremely friendly and helpful. Like most bars, its self-seating. The moment a table was free, he notified us to quickly grab the seats. Thanks!    I ordered the banana daiquiri and we shared the volcano bowl amongst three people. That is 8 oz of alcohol. Both were delicious! The banana daiquiri is not a blended drink. It has a small hint of banana. It reminds me of the banana flavored Runts candy. The volcano bowl is sweet with a little tart flavor aftertaste. Highly recommended!

w1hbc2RJychGWMWg493DXw.review_text: Found this place by searching "punch bowl" on yelp, hehe..   This place is so cute! There are three floors. The floor you enter into has the main bar and a couple seats/places to stand across from it. The basement has another bar and gets a bit crowded/stuffy. The upstairs is my favorite as it's just seating -- easiest place to stake out in hopes of getting a spot to sit -- and there was the freshest air, I thought.   My friends and I got a volcano punch bowl, which we split among the three of us. The drink itself was great, especially the cinnamon on the surface. I liked the long straws that go directly into the bowl, but this method means it's hard to keep track of how much you've had (and it is surprisingly strong!). One of my friends wasn't aware of just how much she drank until she stood up, went to the bathroom and thought her reflection in the mirror by the door was another person.   Advice if you come: come early, so you can get a seat! Once people settle in with their drinks, they are not giving up their seats. Also, it takes awhile to get drinks, even water, so be patient!

euDJtZe0DkPOvKK-MVsHGw.review_text: Went here for my birthday, it definitely gets crowded so you have to fight for your spot at the bar to try and get a drink and seats.  I had a rum barrel, of course I wanted the mug for my collection, it was good. Pretty much got snockered off the one drink. The decor is pretty awesome though.

kfbHWVkENcHOA4lso8LtpA.review_text: Smuggler's Cove is a cozy tavern that truly brings out the pirate in you, externally via the decor, and internally via the ample and tasty booze. This can be a good or bad thing for some--note that the words "irate" and "rat" are both parts of "pirate"--but I usually embrace my inner buccaneer, and my times at Smuggler's Cove have been no exception.  As other reviews attest, San Francisco rum fans would be quite foolish to pass up this spot, as almost all items on their extensive menu of cocktails features quality rum.  Did I mention these cocktails are all really delicious?  It's actually a blessing they're rather pricey, because the size of your buried treasure chest is going to be the only deterrent to getting disastrously trashed on beverages that surely vie for the tastiest rum drinks you've ever had.  I was also impressed with the speed and disposition of the bartenders, who must memorize and regularly serve the large swath of cocktail options to jolly rogers and pissy privateers alike.  Be careful: the exterior is absolutely unassuming, so if you're not mindful of the address, you will walk right by this place unaware (I surmise pirates would favor discretion in hideouts, fittingly).  Bottom line: if you like pirates and especially rum, check out Smuggler's Cove.

fN6uTILlEltal3-x8HKUtA.review_text: I've been on a weeknight and it was a cool one-time experience. Cool decor, huge cocktail menu, not a bad time.  Last night, though, I tried to go with a few friends. One of my friends kept warning us that it was going to suck on a Saturday and that they were really weird about letting people in. So we got in line prepared to wait, no big deal. A few of the guys left for 60 seconds to put their jackets in my car and when they got back the bouncer made them go to the end of the line instead of rejoining us. Kind of annoying, but whatever. My friend who had been telling us not to go said to me (not to the bouncer) "See, this is what I mean." And then the bouncer started yelling at him about how if he didn't like it he shouldn't go to the bar. My friend said "No, I understand" and the bouncer shot back "It's clear to me you DON'T understand!" and gave him this (really ironic) lecture about being courteous. So we left.  I'm sure this guy has to deal with a lot of annoying customers but this was crazy. Reading some of the other reviews it sounds like it wasn't an isolated incident. We get it, you're popular, you don't need us as customers, but there's no need to go out of your way to pick fights with customers. I hope this guy can chill out and have a little sense of humor about his job. It's a novelty pirate bar, not the white house.

U6PGMWYyV1GpNfgS_4OiVA.review_text: When my friend asked me to vote on a pirate-themed bar or just about every other bar for her birthday event, I texted back "PIRATE BAR" right away.   I love everything that has to do with Pirates, and all things tiki and Caribbean (get it?) so this place was right up my alley.   We ended up going for my friend's quarter century, and it was a rockin' good time!   The venue is small, so we had to wait a bit in the cold, but we enjoyed talking and catching up with each other and met some of the nice bouncers (friendly bouncers?! shocking) and bride-to-be's waiting out front. This place is actually quite popular for bachelorette parties. Not sure why.   Some of my guy friends were even targeted by bachelorettes to cross things off their list (such as sit on a guy's lap for the last time, get a piggyback from a guy, etc.) so GUYS...you might get lucky here haha!  When we were finally let in, being a Saturday night, the place was packed to the door. There was literally no place to sit so my girlfriends and I got drinks at the bar first.   First of all, reading the menu to choose a drink was a pain. It was like a storybook novel, no joke, complete with the bar's history and a paragraph's length of description for each drink. Seriously!? We did not need that much information.   It was also hard to distinguish between drink names because they were not bolded. There was just text upon text in their book-like menu and it was very confusing.   After we finally settled on a couple of drinks, we proceeded upstairs to join the rest of our friends. Some friends smartly went up to the third level to reserve seating in the tiki room, and eventually we all made it up there and got seating for all 11 of us.   After trying a few more drinks, I have to say the best drinks here are the Pain Killer, one with coconut water in it (I forget the name) and the standout of the night has to be the VOLCANO BOWL!!  We saw a few people get it, looked cool so we decided to get one for the birthday girl. It's a huge bowl made up of rum and other liqueurs, comes with a light show (they light it ON FIRE in front of your face!!), and it feeds four or more people, all for the measly price of $36... haha.  Yeah, it is pricey, but it's kind of worth it if you're sharing with a bunch of people. It wasn't strong or bitter, actually kinda sweet but a definite creeper. We all got a nice, strong buzz from the volcano bowl..  In the end, this bar is great if you want to experience a tiki bar in the city, have a good time without dancing (no room and the jungle music isn't really for dancing) and don't need to sit down. And if you're with a large group, this venue isn't ideal because you're most likely going to split up.   But if you don't care about all of that, they make great drinks (for the most part) and the vibe and atmosphere are unlike any other bar in San Francisco! It's a unique gem among duds, my only other favorite tiki bar being Trad'r Sam's.   Four stars for Smuggler's Cove...Drink up, ME HEARTIES, YOHO!

2OzT8NIKcP4bUgolp6MI6Q.review_text: I love that you can pass right by this place and not even know that there are 3 stories of perfectly kitchy tiki-ness right inside.  The staff was super friendly from the bouncer to the bartenders.  Even the crowd was chill and not all in a drunken stupor.  I was in the mood for something tropical but not too sweet.  I described to the bartender this amazing drink I had when I was in Hawaii (minty - pineapple without the sweetness) and he recommended the something- Fang.  It was perfect.  *Just* what I wanted.   I would definitely recommend this place as something fun and different than your typical neighborhood hangout.

r9-HdNseh-ixxpBf5n9EIw.review_text: I gotta be honest, I almost walked past this well hidden bar named Smugglers Cove. I think the place can hold up to 40 customers.   Con: it gets really noisy no matter where you sit. You practically have to yell at your friends so they can hear you. Then your throat gets sore. Then you soothe your throat with delicious rum drink. And repeat. If you're looking for a place to catch up and talk, this might not be the best venue.   Pro: delicious drinks infused with specialized rums. I ordered the Tradewinds, which had lemon, coconut creme, and a hint of Jamaican rum which made the drink taste tart, less alcoholic. Also, our bartender seemed swamped with orders, but she did a great job getting our drinks to us in 15 minutes.

u586kkVWvU7XvlVg-CuP-Q.review_text: Wide range of amazing rum cocktails.. And the divine like cocktail is Smuggler's rum barrel. Its exotic, sweet and dreamy all at the same time. Been here more often than any other place in SF and yet not bored of it. Only thing that can make this place better is bigger space. The bar is kinda cramped up into the wall and during busy times it may take forever to get  drink!

O6ApD55L5dasJ45HQ75BkA.review_text: The secret of smugglers cove is the "yellow card", if you can work your way through one of those, hats off, but pace yourself. Seriously give your self time to enjoy.  Then step-up to the "blue card (pages)" for some of the finest rum you'll fine anywhere.

y3HFVx8nbNmomSc-PWOy-g.review_text: What's a pirate's favorite letter of the alphabet?  RRRRRRRR  After having so much fun at Hula's in Santa Cruz over the weekend, I just had to check on Yelp for something tiki and local.  As always, Yelp didn't disappoint and came through with something amazing.  Surprisingly, although my friends have gone, I had never been to Smuggler's Cove before until last night.  Upon walking in, I immediately loved the charming pirate bar theme. Just what I always wanted...an alcoholic Disneyland!  Before ordering my first drink, I went upstairs and downstairs to check it out before settling on the main floor which I liked best due to the decor and airy feel.  The floor below also had a bar and was cool and intimate, compared to the two other floors.  The top floor was actually more of a table area with no bar.  The downstairs bar looked like it could be a lot of fun too, but last night, there seemed to be some group or party going on down there.  As always, service makes such a difference and I had the most fantastic bartender.  Dane was quite the artisan and takes great care and pride in each and every drink he makes.  He turned a nice evening into a really fun evening...this guy makes some incredible drinks!  Later in the night, I met the other bartender, Patrick, and he was most excellent as well.
