Hanging at the bar, flying high on high octane, well-crafted concoctions of quality rum, I was in bar-mode and struck up conversations with the patrons next to me.  We all became good friends and after introducing new friends to other new friends, we suddenly had a fun group of five.  Everyone was having the most incredible time and we were all like old friends.  One of them, Zack, got us a flaming Volcano bowl with four loooong straws and we killed it fast.  I loved those big skull bowls, each with a slightly different glazing and personality.  Was surprised at how big the flame was as well as how long it burned...so cool!  It was the perfect end to a really fun evening...or so I thought until my new friends talked me into ordering one more drink.  During my time there last night, I had the following:  Zombie Sidewinder's Fang Volcano Bowl (for 4) Dot Dot Dot Dash Dash Dash  I loved them all and the key to ordering drinks here is to look for little icons next to the drink names on the menu.  One icon denotes favorites and the other one, a small barrel, means that the drink is strong.  Naturally, I started with the Zombie which had that icon next to it.  The Zombie turned out to be a great choice and was really strong...the perfect beginning!  Ever notice how when Adam Richman tackles his food challenges in Man v. Food, he almost always says in the beginning that there's a lot of food, but wow, it's all really good.  Well, this Zombie was the same way...it was really strong, exactly the way I wanted it, and yet it had all the individual flavors of the different ingredients.  It was really good!  Truly well-made and the best Zombie I've ever had.  The next drink I had was the Sidewinder's Fang.  As I mentioned in my Hula's Island Grill review just the other day, I used to go to a place called The Lanai where their specialty was the Sidewinder Fang.  Their version didn't have an " 's", but I think perhaps that was a cultural or island thing.  Their double Sidewinder Fang was always a favorite of mine and to this day I think back on it fondly.  As such, I was delighted to see it on the menu here.  Although not as deadly as the Zombie, it was delicious and came with a long orange peel which represents the snake.  After the flaming Volcano bowl which I described above, I then had one final drink which was the Dot Dot Dot Dash Dash Dash (think morse code) which was also rum-based.  At this point, I was way too happy to remember what was in it, but recall being impressed with how it tasted.  I gave one of my new friends a taste and they really liked it too.   I've seen some reviews that mention how long it takes to get a drink and this is true especially when it's crowded, but I believe that it is because a lot of these recipes are very involved and the bartenders take great care in making them.  It is definitely worth the wait.  Last night was a Wednesday though so I imagine it must get crazy busy on weekends.    While I was there, a lot of people there saw pictures of my bird Sonny on my phone and said that I had the perfect bird for this setting.  Had some hilarious reactions to the bird porn videos on my phone of my lovebirds Julie and Jamie too.  Some of them just couldn't stop laughing.    Among all the wonderful people I met last night, one of them was a Yelper...Josh N.  Much thanks to his friend Zack for getting us all a Volcano bowl and to Elenor (her spelling) for turning me on to the Smuggler's Cove drink sheet where bartender's sign off on every drink you have there.  I already had a great start on completing my list last night.  Lots of amazing drinks, good people...fun times!  Long live Smuggler's Cove!

8qHjTWbhe7B1G6o4DQlu_A.review_text: I was so excited to finally make it to this bar. I was really hoping this was going to be a bar that I would come back to multiple times.  As soon as I walked in I was impressed by the environment. I could believe how much stuff was up on the walls.    I headed downstairs immediately because of the huge crowd.  From what I remembered of Jade, most people stayed upstairs.  But this is not the same for Smuggler's Cove.  According to the bartender, the downstairs area was enlarged but from what I could see there was no extra room. Maybe that was because of all the people.  We quickly got acquainted with the drink ordering procedure. First you are handed a book with all the drinks.  This is a great idea but way too much info for someone only concerned about how quickly they can get me a cocktail.  There should be annotated version.  So after deciphering the menu we ordered.  15 minutes late we finally got our drinks.  All the drinks average about $8/9 and are a little bit on the small side.  Later we decided to get one of the large drinking bowls that serves 4 people.  In order to do this you must have a table. And on a  busy Saturday night that took a little waiting.  Once the drink came we  finished that thing pretty quickly.  Definitely doesn't serve a group of four experienced drinkers.  All and all I had a pretty good experience of Smuggler's Cove. The drinks are rather tasty but a little overpriced.  I would highly recommend not going during the weekend unless you want to wait a long time for drinks.

idJ35gltZ90eFFCm2YvtXQ.review_text: After a long ass day from walking to Japan town, back to union station, and walking the whole Golden Gate bridge, then from union station to Smuggler's Cove, we see that it wasn't open till 5:00. We came at 2:30. Bf and I weren't the happiest of people at that moment. Feet were sore..beyond sore..so what did we do? Walk up more hills to Japan town to pass the time.   Came back at 5:00. We were determined to come here. Go inside, the I guess bouncer you would say? was very nice and informative. Since it was our first time, he kind of gave us a little tour around the place..and it was pretty nifty! 3 floors. 1st floor was like a little ship area. All 3 floors are very small. It isn't a big bar..but all pirate themed with some of that spongebob hawaiian esque music. Pretty soothing. Basically all of the drinks were of rum, and they had some that weren't..but only a few options.  Over 80 or so drinks..STRONG DRINKS might I add!   Bf and I saw from people's pictures on yelp that there is this Volcano drink that serves up to 4, and is lit on fire. We wanted. The bartenders (only 2) on the first floor actually take their time to make the drinks. The female bartender tries it with unused straws before she hands them to you to make sure it's perfect. Our volcano drink took about 10 minutes before it came out. The bartender dude did a little act with his evil laugh and blew that thang on FIYA! I loved it. Drink itself was pretty damn good! We killed it. Went for round 2! Anddddd round 3 :] ..of different drinks of course.   Within of 5 minutes of being in there, we see the crowd just run in. It gets busyyy. BUT, I definitely recommend this place for everyone to try. It isn't your typical kind of bar with your typical kind of drinks.   Get out your comfort zone and try this place. It shouldn't disappoint!   But there isn't a giant sign that says SMUGGLER'S COVE. So open up them eyes and peep for it.

O91sRO4-zLBpXZT5VrklOg.review_text: can i recall all the drinks i had celebrating my birthday? NO  but i can tell you it's a great little hidden spot with some cool pirate decor for all you matey's and the drinks will shiver your timbers even just a couple. oh and the volcano drink is super cool ( the guy who lights it is bald, irony?) did i mention it's a really cool birthday, festive bar? ohh btw bring the benji's cause drinking in style with pirates isn't cheap!

vRR_o7LOr7qOsmlGvp0cGg.review_text: This is easily the best interior decorating of any bar in the city. Its so good I swore they up and shipped the whole place from the Pirates of the Caribbean at Disneyland. The quality of its design is that good. Now, design aside, I loved the Banana Daiquiri. Not served frozen but in a martini glass, it was just the right sweetness, not overpowered by fake banana flavor, and topped with a lime slice which gave it a little bit of tang. We had other drinks that were great also, but I swear I have never had a better tropical drink anywhere else.  Love it!

z1aE5EXdEIY2MyO25NoIPQ.review_text: What a great place. Though, I was a castaway on hangover Island the day after I visited this tiki-ed enclave last year

xysbzkW9EZeKWt9EaqaSRg.review_text: This place is soooo over-rated! I went here with a large group, so I was able to sample many different drinks. The drinks were either too sweet or too tart - yuck! It was also crowded and hot, and there was no music!

BLrrlNdaU3fOXpcbcbE4Aw.review_text: Fun times. The only reason this isn't 5 stars is because of the price. Granted, we were there on a Tuesday night and it wasn't overly busy, so I can't really say how it would have been on a weekend. We were eventually able to get seats for all 8 of us who were in the group last night.  The bartenders downstairs knew what they were doing. They were slow and methodical. This sometimes meant waiting a few minutes for your drink, but the drinks were consistent, and consistently good at that!  This place is cozy, so if you're claustrophobic or don't like small spaces in general, it may not be for you.

6TrHhqsu8nlzOBew137AnQ.review_text: Never a dull moment whenever my friends and i decide to go to Smuggler's. Drinks to try:  Zombie Daisy De Santiago Pooka Punch Sidewinder  It can get really crowded and warm but the drinks are perfectly iced to keep you cool.

hpE1j_Vv-Isy2w5zAVWQOg.review_text: Having been raised in a Chinese restaurant family, I know my way around a scorpion bowl and Polynesian themed decor. We have kitsch out in Western Mass too (hello, Hu Ke Lau!).   That said, I think Smuggler's Cove is quite possibly the first true "tiki bar" that I've been to. From the outside, it looks like a nondescript lounge/club. And it's actually fairly understated (as far as Polynesian decor goes) on the inside as well if you don't count the multi-colored fountain in the corner....no explosion of leis or grass skirts anywhere. And nary a Hawaiian shirt. Actually, I'm a bit disappointed about that.   Anyway, what they DO have is an exceptionally detailed cocktail list and a wealth of rum concoctions that would do Jack Sparrow proud! The flaming volcano drinks are quite the crowd pleaser. I highly recommend trying one, but be sure to share with a couple friends. And having extra straws on hand will quickly make you some new friends as well ;)  As for the ambiance...it's lit enough so that you can easily read the drink menu and not so loud that you couldn't carry on a conversation amongst friends. I do wish they played some Polynesian themed music, but oh well...At least they have lots of seating downstairs and friendly bartenders! Good for groups and a more mellow night out :)

VfQ-770xKPgktBKRkCelpQ.review_text: I came here with a couple friends on a Friday night and really enjoyed the experience!   The atmosphere is great and this is the perfect place to have a chill night talking with friends.  They have a large selection of tropical cocktails. The bartenders are friendly and fascinating to watch. Most are rum-based, but they also offer a few vodka and tequila based cocktails. I found the drinks to be overly sweet and not very strong, but then again I'm not a huge rum fan...   If you enjoy themed bars or want a change from the more traditional bar scene, check this place out.

jkiinjUy8RUZKzW5gBpXNg.review_text: Rum is not my spirit of choice and Tiki is not a theme in which I revel, but damn, they make fine drinks at SmugCo.  Reza in particular has always taken great care of us, and the man shakes a mean cocktail, so if you have the option belly up to the bar where he's working, do so.

jy_RGAeAvNeCv5BxZsUWFA.review_text: This pirate themed bar is a funny place! It feels like drinking at Disneyland. It's three floors with two bars and a fountain in the basement.   The beer selection is weak so I wont be making this a regular stop but everyone should come check this out this at least once.

ctckUdFYY_ECdarz-eWrew.review_text: Great fun, awesome tiki cocktails!..Went once with friends and the next time with some work buddies. Had a great time both visits!...but the bar tenders are at most times douchey. Nevertheless a better place to hang out than the usual yuppie or hipster bars.

WKPTh4UmEqXR8TRAp1g2CA.review_text: A co-worker brought me here after work by saying the magic words, "I'm paying". Had a hot buttered rum that was delicious and loved the Disney-esque pirates decor.

Dhl0d-8Tgp4ihCtVc6LYSA.review_text: Pirate themed bar with tons of rum. I had the two strongest drinks (Puka Punch and Zombie) and they were good. The tradewind was tasteful and easy to drink. Warning, warning, drinks are expensive so don't be surprised. You would only come here to have a couple of drinks and hang out. If you go too late, there WILL be a line because they do crowd control which is AWESOME!

j3uBJBdn7U1RPrQzNrOVnQ.review_text: - I could spent 30 minutes READING the menu, with all the caveats associated with exotic rums from centuries ago.  Most of the drinks have some anecdotes from their origins that span the globe.  Drinks are strong, well-made, and unique.  - The bartender was mixing several drinks, and one concoction apparently required a certain high temperature for serving.  The bar tender apparently missed the timing and after a taste, he dumped the drink to start all over.  My cynical side says it's possible he was putting on an act, but even that at least shows he won't be sloppy in front of a customer.  Pretty far removed from bar tenders at other establishments who will hand you a cup dribbling all over with beer foam without wiping down.  - The location is far removed from anything else, which makes it hard to bar hop.  If I was to come here, I would plan to stay for a very long time.  It helps that there's a small lounge area in the second floor with chairs and tables.  They do enforce the maximum occupancy, and there is a doorman.  The rotation is not that bad, but don't come here with a party of 10 at 11pm on a Friday night and expect instant access.  - The atmosphere and decor fits the theme, with pirate-looking paraphernalia strewn about and different colored blowfish lanterns.  Definitely helps sell the exotic feel of the drinks offered.  - Crowd tends to be a bit older, it's not a kind of place where older people will look silly in the crowd.  It is also not a place for frat party drink-fests.  Overall, a great place to bring your friends again and again for refreshing drinks served with high attention to quality.

0N5TQe9OwA-6X9sP35ljdg.review_text: Tip:  If you order a fruity rum drink, be prepared for a martini glass --and that means less volume.  One of my favorite bars in San Francisco.  Get there right at 5:00 p.m., because it gets crowded.  By 6:00 p.m. it's tough to get a seat at the bar.  Their bartenders are cool, the ambiance is great (if not just a tad cheesy), and the happy hour drinks are downright cheap.  The bar seems to have several regulars, and most people are quite well-dressed (probably relates to its location between Civic Center and the prosperous Hayes Valley).  This is not a great venue for large groups.  Their menu is fantastic, but the hot buttered rum and the rum flights are highlights for me.

88Es01sQHe5ZOiu3lUXUKQ.review_text: It looks like a dark, unused building from the outside but you enter a pirate ship world! We've been here a few times and loved it every time. Bartenders are friendly, first visit the power went out three times and they just kept pouring drinks without flinching! We ended up using our phone lights to help out haha. Good ambiance, delicious drinks, definitely going back for more tiki time.

IiUq9nBKR5bhLZzjbfnFpw.review_text: Worst fucking place ever. Beside the bouncer is a mayor dick. Never come here. The line is too fucking long to be worth. You should just not deal with this kind of stuff. Just look for an other bar int town, you will be way batter off

zY9AjblV326erru4kAJkCQ.review_text: I Love pirates and if I were a pirate, I would be at home here. the bartender is a mix master to boot! He made me my first fernet cocktail. I have no idea how but it was so gooood!!

-k9QDE5E8WAitSzFmfVJPA.review_text: Me loves the tiki drinks and whole tiki vibe, and frequent the Conga Lounge in Oakland, but I was very disappointed in Smuggler's Cove. The drink menu was amazing and the decor was cool, but the portions were very small for the price. I mean, $9-12 for a martini glass size? You get larger drinks and just as much ambiance at Conga or Forbidden Island.  Worst of all, the female bartender we had in the downstairs bar was so blatantly ignoring me every time I went up to order drinks. I don't know if she did this to all women that night, but my first time up to the bar she asked what I wanted, then proceeded to ask and make drinks for some guy who came up after me, before she finished my drinks. The next time I went up, I patiently waited because the bar was getting crowded by this time. When it came my turn, she looked over my shoulder and asked the guy behind me what he wanted! It just so happens he was my friend. He had to tell her that I was waiting to order before she'd even LOOK AT ME. What a BEOTCH!  It seriously ruined my night. I'm sure the owners and other bartenders are just fine, but I doubt I'll ever go back just because of her. She should be fired.

1y2dLZg2l3dtLc1nzU2qzg.review_text: One of the more elaborately themed bars I've ever been to, drinking at Smuggler's Cove is kinda like stepping off Disneyland's classic Pirates of the Caribbean ride and knocking back a few strong Rum drinks (though there unfortunately no animatronic pirates in the bar). A two story-waterfall, pirate paraphernalia crowding the walls and ceiling, pirate shanties scrawled onto the bathroom mirrors, a "crow's nest" for drinking upstairs, and an epic menu where each of the numerous Tiki drinks is explained in detail.   I enjoyed a very Pineappley yet very strong Fogcutter (because is there a better choice when you're in San Francisco?), and would have tried the supposedly delicious Hot Buttered Rum had my brother and I not gotten to the bar so close to last call. The drinks are pretty expensive, but that's to be expected when it comes to a bar that serves elaborate Tiki drinks that utilize many ingredients and take time to make.  A really fun place with a good crowd, strong drinks, and super fun theme, Smuggler's Cove is one of those places you should definitely visit if you're in SF for a weekend.

F5LhbsLPALA0B_yUBG2n9A.review_text: ARRGGHH. That's right. It's time to channel your inner pirate.  It's hard to believe this was the old Jade bar, because the owners redecorated all three floors to resemble a pirate ship (right down to the "crates" of rum that serve as tables).  Upon entering you find yourself on the main deck. Go upstairs to enjoy a private nook, or down the stairs "under deck" where a waterfall trickles into a pool.  The bartenders put a lot of work into the drinks.  The customer favorite seems to be a drink for four people, served in a ceramic skull, with fire and spice.  I tried a daiquiri, which was served up in a martini glass- a nice twist, but I missed the crushed ice.   If you like rum, this is the place for you. If not, I would still recommend visiting at least once.  It may take awhile to find a drink that suits you, but it's definitely an interesting bar experience worth a tall tale at the water cooler on Monday.

K5SsHErNj99BU44sW_DmtQ.review_text: This place actually knows how to make good cocktails that you can feel good about forking over $10+ for. All of the bartenders I've encountered here are knowledgable and have a good attitude.   There's a little bit of a mystique about Smuggler's Cove since it's easy to miss if you're just walking past. I'm a fan of the ambience of the bar as well with the chill vibe and pirate theme. It's a place that appeals to most and I've found myself here with both a couple of girlfriends as well as a large gaggle of coworkers.   I suggest coming here on a weekday to get the full experience since it still manages to attract a decent (but manageable) crowd and bartenders are not rushed to make the artisinal cocktails. If you're looking to get a bit rowdy with a group, they also offer scorpion bowls and "volcanoes."

84zb2CKMFtLlis0Uja_-vw.review_text: Awesome ambience. Delicious affordable drinks ($8). Pleasant and helpful bartender. Can't wait to come back for a big night out. Love it. A lot.

Bp-TQEtc6Vs6ldnLgjqglg.review_text: I like the kitschy pirate ship decor, but the mixed rum cocktails are not spectacular.  Do try the rum flights, though, as you get a great variety of different types of rum in a flight of 4. They have rum from all over the Americas as well as some from the Philippines.   I'm not a rum fanatic, but did appreciate the good stuff they had on their menu.

NTRktHjkhDlCf406L6YaFQ.review_text: This place is kitschy as hell, but that's sort of the point. The drinks are not cheap, but they have more rum drinks than you can possibly imagine. If you want a place to sit, though, come early. I was there at 6pm on a Friday and it was hard to get a table.

TpZN51jtAZTu7BjYxTfpjA.review_text: It feels like you are on a pirate ship!! Cozy places to sit, multiple levels, rum tasting flights and a huge menu of rum drinks. Its so much fun. Its really neat to read the descriptions of the old rum drinks from different time periods.

wniYt25H5iteZ4uDmxgsOA.review_text: One of my friends from New Hampshire came to visit, and he's a huge rum connoisseur. As a result, he found this bar on the internet and insisted we go.  I'm so glad we did.  The ambience was fabulous and the drinks excellent.  I can't wait to go back and bring more friends.

updNAUcQkI9wm2yNoRNubQ.review_text: This one's kind of a no-brainer: delicious, creative (and strong) tiki drinks in a piratey/polynesian setting. If not for the crowds, I'd be here every weekend.   While I can't remember each and every concoction I've tried here (a fact I blame on the first few rum-soaked rounds), I've yet to find one I don't like. And at least one of the punch bowls comes served on fire, which is pretty much the most baller way to have a drink served.  As mentioned, this place can get pretty packed, especially in the after-dinner hours, so if you just want the experience plan to go early. But even if you have to go late, wait a bit for your drinks and hover for a table, its still worth it.

SVRTJMfqXv4y7WVvyKs4Ag.review_text: It's a great bar with a piratey ambiance. The bartenders are very friendly and most importantly make great drinks! I saw most of them sipping on the volcano ball which is a huge bowl of alcohol with a fire burning in the center. Looked real good! It can get really packed and make it there a little early if you don't want to stand outside in line as it's a very small place and they make sure not to overcrowd the place.   I will definitely go back here a lot more often. It's a little expensive though.

mI7qhszlDChPNbaQy9AHIw.review_text: Arrrrrrr matey!  5 stars. No debate, just thoughts.  1.) The hard part is finding the entrance. Literally, there is a sign on the door and that's it. Not even a fancy sign at best. But if you find it, be prepare to be amazed. 2.) The bar features 3 floors. The upstairs features more lounge seating with little room to stand. The 2nd floor is more standing and is where the entrance is. The bottom floor is the most crowded but also the largest. Bars are available on the 2nd and bottom floor. 3.) Rum de dum! Rum themed bar, no doubt. So good. 3a.) the menu is extensive,but don't be overwhelmed! Everythingis pretty legit, but ask the bartender. The puka punch was delish, ditto with the hot buttered rum. If you like something strong, go with the zombie or painkiller. 4.) if you order a bowl, be prepared to be amazed. They'll light that shit on fire. Literally. 5.) not too crowded, not too loud. Perfect on so many levels!  Love love love, adore. Did I mention love?

RAYirmqUmLiSHImwPiA39g.review_text: OK I have to admit, I think Smuggler's Cove looks pretty cool inside. Based on some pirate theme, it's a cross between a Rainforest Cafe and some shit you would see at a Disneyland restaurant (minus cool animatronics).  They made some best bars in the US list that was released. I have no idea what the source is, but check Google and you'll definitely find it.  I have to say I've never been to Smuggler's on a non Friday or Saturday.  With that said, I always have to deal with crowds.  Since the bar is so small, they have to throttle the line outside for fire code reasons. I have never really dealt with a ridiculous line here (around 10 people) so the wait isn't that painful.  Luckily the times I went, the bouncers were pretty friendly and talkative.    Seating on the weekends is hard to come by, especially if you have a decent sized group.  If you have a few people, you can likely find some corner or nook where you guys can stand or sit.  Once ya'll find somewhere to post up at, it's time to order drinks.  The drinks here are definitely interesting and exotic.  Since there are  so many ingredients involved in each drink, the bartenders have to spend time mixing and creating each drink.  If you're the type who wants to get your drink and quickly get back to your seat, this is not the place.  There is a generally a glut of people near the bar who are waiting for their drinks.  You will probably have to wait at least a few minutes to get your drink.    Drinks are in the 12-15 dollar range, so plan accordingly.  They do have beer here and your normal bar but what fun is that ? You  might as well try one of their concoctions right?  Other than the crowds and the length of time to get a drink, this place is worth coming back to I'd say. Many bars are so blah and all look the same.  I think the Smuggler's Cove is pretty cool and different.  I'd definitely come back here.

ZCf_RjsWNXxS61WXhNj29Q.review_text: It is truely the McDonalds of tiki bars.   Ok so it's a sunday night and we've heard amazing things about this place. We were told not to go on weekend night because we will get lost in a sea of drunk people. So sunday night it is. Can't go wrong, right? WRONG! There were MAYBE 3 people in this bar and i think those people worked there...  The drinks were tasty (hence my 1 star). That's where the positiveness ended. Our drinks were only half full when served to us AND my drink was also LOADED with ice which can only do one thing - water down the already weak drink.   The two of walked out into the ghetto neighborhood with over $30 gone from our pockets and a slight fruity taste in our mouths.

VgtcRwMPiAEeuPsayXB4kA.review_text: Delicious cocktails. Had one called The Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch, served in a hollowed-out pineapple. While I felt silly walking around holding it (including the "lid"), it was quite delicious. Next time I'm leaving the "lid" at the bar. Warning: this place is tiny and can get super-cramped, which also means service can get slow.

07191dQwiRtPAmBvPYdwew.review_text: what's not to love about this place, I ask you? Drinks are beautiful... tasty n strong. I had a Painkiler, a Dead Reckoning and some straight rum... I recommend siting at the bar if you are with one other. Better service. It takes awhile getting a drink because it is made with loving care. Strange location, but nice inside. Great place to whack a few back and then go out.

fzwx-6P-uGbowzFWycjPbw.review_text: I've been twice.  Once, soon after Smugglers Cove opened, and once again recently.  Both times were mid-week.  I shudder to imagine how long I'd wait to a) get in, and b) take my first sip of a drink on the weekend.  The interior is nicely done.  I particularly like the puffer-fish lamps.  Very cool.  And the upstairs lounge, above the bar.  Comfy and connected to the rest of the space, but buffered from the madness of the bar.  And speaking of the bar... what a fine place it is to ... not get a drink.  I think I waited for 20 minutes to order.  Not that I was being ignored, or that the bartender had some kind of attitude -- far from it!  The staff here seem totally cool, friendly, knowledgeable, and down to make some extremely tasty drinks.    Just one problem.  There aren't enough of them.  For the whole 20 minutes I waited, the bartender (singular) was working his ass off making drinks.  And let me say:  the worst thing to do after spending 10 minutes studying the menu is to stand there looking at all of those tasty drinks coming to life, knowing that none of them is mine.  The big wait threw off the whole momentum of the night.  It turned excitement into restlessness and made me want to leave after the first drink was done, mostly avoid the pain of getting a second.  I need to give Smugglers Cove another shot.  The plan: get there at 6pm, and leave if I can't sit at the bar.  Also, be prepared for the place to be full of rum snobs.  You know who you are.

jOZheuOkUGKp4htT0xHIlA.review_text: How does anyone find this place?? The sign on the door is ridiculously small & the windows are tinted black. I guess most nights you just look for the line outside. But on a Monday, there was no line. Luckily one in our group knew the place or we would've walked right past it.   Once inside, you are greeted by friendly bartenders in a cave-like, Pirates of the Caribbean atmosphere. There's even a trickling waterfall that cascades down the front wall down to the bottom floor. The music selection was something like Caribbean/ska/reggae/Star Wars/Irish/pirate?   There was plenty of room & we took our time perusing the vast menu. I was overwhelmed so we went with the Top Notch Volcano to share between 4 of us. I mean, you really can't go to a tiki-type bar & NOT order a strong, flaming rum drink served in an oversized skull with 4 extra long straws, can you? This wasn't anything like those watered down Scorpion Bowls at the Tonga room. This was good & had some serious alcohol in it. (*Note, you need to put down a credit card when you order the Volcano so you don't run off with the skull. Yea I'm sure they learned quick on that one.)  We tried quite a few other drinks among our group & I found that I did not like the ones notated with a barrel on the menu. The barrel insignia means the drinks are strong. And when you taste them, they are STRONG. I had trouble breathing after a sip of one of them. I think I could have lit my breath on fire.  Not for me. But I'm sure there are plenty of other folks who love these drinks. That's what is great about Smuggler's Cove...something for everyone!

_4ivf3hN0FnofSmGLjOT7w.review_text: Imagine the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland but with some awesome rum cocktails. That's basically how epic Smuggler's Cove is!   Located in what appears to be the most obscure location near Hayes Valley, Smuggler's Cove has an incredibly impressive list of rum-filled drinks that will be sure to please any rum fan. Each drink description comes with its own mini- anecdote that details how some of the drink names came to be. The options are endless! My friends and I tried three out of the four shareable bowl-sized drinks, all of which were lit on fire, which was legit! Our favorite was the Volcano, which is named after the cool flame-igniting ritual that the bartender performs upon delivering the drink to the table. For the most part, each of the shared drinks had a ton of flavor mixed in with the distinct taste of a signature rum.  Another one of my favorite drinks from my first time here was the Hot Buttered Rum, which was deliciously comforting and definitely an epic win in my book! It's good as it sounds. Trust me.  Moreover, the limited capacity (capped at 40 people at a time) at this place ensures that you and your company will be able to enjoy each other's company with the usual crowded and obnoxiously loud atmosphere that can often happen after 7 PM or so. In conclusion: an exceptional list of cocktails, a great atmosphere, and eerily mysterious  props/decorations make this place a quality concoction winner in my book.

G_Lo-G258N4hfHg_WbTAxw.review_text: This place is damn cute--  the decor, the drinks, the workers and patrons; the atmosphere is funky. Don't let the "cute" label discourage you from coming! Drinks are interesting, tasty and strong. You should come here if you want to experience something novel (just like San Francisco; everything and every place is small yet interesting).    Seating is limited and so is standing space, the music is mellow (downstairs), and the workers are nice. The crowd you'd typically see there are between 21 - 60s. Please bring your friend who likes fruity drinks to this bar, he or she will thank you and you might become a fan too.

2PVQwZMYVeWKPX4ehcK-cw.review_text: Heard a lot of good things about this bar and the drinks online. I had done my research before coming here and thought this would be a good place to bring my husband for his bday. There was a long line outside already when we got there but I was hoping it would be worth the wait. When we finally got inside we realized the place looked NOTHING like it did on their website. It was small, crowded, stuffy, and absolutely no music. We decided to be optimistic and give it a try anyways. Bartender wasn't the friendliest and the drinks were strong but not really worth $12 each.   Online it says they offer 60 different exotic rums but when I asked about a few that my husband and I were looking forward to trying they didn't have any of them. This should be noted on their website or they should update it every so often and make changes as items become unavailable.   I was disappointed and would never come back. Definitely not worth the drive from the east bay and you can't expect much here. Most people we saw walked in and ordered one drink and then left since there wasn't much room to even stand.

43qFDY7Fi_RRlKxIONGpQw.review_text: Yo ho ho ho and a glass of rum cocktail! Maybe it's just my desire to conform to my environments, but boarding upon this ship truly made me want to don an eyepatch, carry a sword, fight crocodiles (Er, ATTEMPT to fight em) and be merry! Smuggler's Cove is truly a hidden treasure - no huge sign to advertise its presence in an overlooked spot in the Western Addition, three small stories flowing with fabulosity, and a rich selection of rum drinks, exotic cocktails, and more!  Never have I seen a bar with an interior so immaculate. With its lighting and decor, it really does feel like being in a pirate ship- fun and zany yet authentic. I was almost wishing there would be a Treasure Island in Vegas type of show with cannons and all, but that would have taken away from its actual purpose as a bar. ;) Two metal staircases lead up to one level and another one down a bottom floor, though my date and I could only find two empty seats right up the bar in the main area. It gave us somewhat of an advantage by getting our drinks first as well as the opportunity to see up close how the bartenders handcraft and mix the beverages. It's pretty crazy! Love it when they light the bowls' sugar cubes on fire!  The menu is extensive and descriptive and I was warned to stay away from the drinks with the "Very Strong" icon (Shouldn't have told the boy about my unfortunate experience at another bar I reviewed on Yelp, WHOOPS), but the two that I ordered delivered a really good buzz: The Aku Aku (tropical cocktail) and the Chadburn (Nutty rum cocktail with pear liqueur). Looking forward to trying out some of the more signature drinks next time.  The place is really small and we were lucky we came when we did because when we got out at around 9:30, the line stretched to about the end of the block! Plan accordingly. If you first-timers are lucky enough to get in, be prepared to relish in some boozy gold!

vLO8DpTi2tz42elavajORA.review_text: I love this bar!  I love the atmosphere ( looks like pirates of the caribbean) and all the rum drinks. It is a little expensive and sometimes crowed but I think it is worth it. I would definetly recommed stopping by!

IRM1eRvJVTBrOUHNXqHpMg.review_text: I tipped the bartender, Marco, a dollar on my first drink. When I went back for my second drink he said he wasn't going to serve me because I was such a bad tipper. I find commenting on someone tipping habits to be pretty tacky, but in a divey bar a little rough talk comes with the territory. But to get denied service for tipping a buck on a drink?   I feel like a buck is not the worst tip in the world for a drink. He had messed up the order too, actually, but I had just shrugged and accepted it and tipped anyway because who cares.  Maybe he was showing off for this rather elderly gay man that had been tipping him with 20s in what seemed an embarrassing, misguided romantic advance toward the sexy bartender Marco, his abs rippling with each fruity drink he blended, his hands wet with condensation from the frosty wet flagons. Whatever the actual issue of which Marco had been struggling, the fact was that I had just gotten off a very long day at work and had come to Pirates Cove to relax and meet up with close friends I rarely get to enjoy. Being suddenly in the middle of a preternatural, transactional May/December gay mating ritual was not what I had signed up for.   My girlfriend was there and we thought he was kidding at first. Then we stood at the bar for 10 minutes and realized he wasn't kidding. My girlfriend spoke up and he got full on aggressive with us, angrily making a comment about my girlfriends medical conditions that she just happens to be rather self-conscious about. When he crossed that line, a lot of people around us at the bar stopped talking and that made the whole weird attack on her even worse. She ran out crying in tears.   I hesitated for a moment kind of stunned at the whole surreal series of events. To break the sudden silence of the encounter, Marco shrugged, looked me in the eye and said 'that fat C*** can go F*** herself before I would serve her NI**** A**"  The whole encounter was really awkward and we went home for the night really upset about having my girlfriends race, handicap, and genitals insulted so loudly in public. I just don't know why one human being would say the things he said to another human being over only getting a one dollar tip on a drink.   I had been to the Pirates Cove many times and always had a good time. The rest of the staff has always been pleasant enough. I imagine this bartender Marco must have some personal issues. When I worked in a bar, if I had pulled what he pulled I would have been fired instantly.  but who knows of The Pirates Cove is run. Maybe proclaiming racial epitaphs toward handicapped black women is encouraged.

VpREWOjt5Pna6OIgXI9Jcg.review_text: I wanted to love this place. And I did love some things, but not all.  Love: RUM, baby! I'm a descendant of West Indies, rum-loving peeps. I'm definitely a dark-liquor gal myself, so the wide range of choices and knowledgeable bartenders were great. The atmosphere is fun: think Adventureland/Pirates of the Caribbean in Disneyland, which I also love, if only out of nostalgia.  I had a Guyana-rum based drink that I really enjoyed. Friends had an interesting take on the mojito. All was good, definitely.  They also have some kind of rum-tasting club, which I'd love to join and somehow afford. That said...  Eh: I (i.e. my wallet) can't handle more than a drink or two at this place. You're looking at $10-plus cocktails, many of which are filled pretty good with ice. It lost points in my book for that.  So, yes, I'll probably come back, but the noteworthy negatives will probably keep my visits to payday.

ZZm0MoJcwKgMSJH02oTSGA.review_text: This place is reminds me of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride in Disneyland. I actually don't think I've experienced a bar with a cooler environment.  That being said, I did encounter a bar tender that was a little rude when I asked him if one drink had pineapple. Given that the menu didn't list the ingredients and a friend was allergic to pineapple, you'd think that'd be a reasonable question.   That aside, this is not the type of bar you go to because the service is great. This is somewhere you must enjoy the ambiance and thoughtfully planned drink menu.

VYXuyWUvDyHVZIXbgeq2-w.review_text: If someone asked me to pick one place for the best cocktails in the city I would pick Smuggler's Cove I normally don't like to drink cocktails but in this place they can sell me on that. All of their cocktails are amazing in a different way!  I have to give credit to the owner who came up with an awesome concept and recipes.  I also love how detailed the menu is: it tells you all about the ingredients, the story and everything behind each cocktail. Some of my favorites are the Puka Punch, the Kona Cocktail and of course, their little barrel thing (forgot the name!)  I love how cool and patient the bartenders are when making a cocktail (a lot of in gradients in one drink)  I love the pirate theme inside Yeah, I have a lot of love for this place :)

sk8kZW3Nht6TCe35VD3qrg.review_text: Argg ! This place is so neat ! Pirate atmosphere, pretty original. The drinks menu is extensive with all sorts of Rum.  Just love this place !

KDewJBJknfWvQyHHFNbfdg.review_text: I don't often call out servers or bartenders in reviews, but Steven is too good of a chap to not say something about, and it seems he's a staple here. Charming, kind, patient, jolly, a joy for the drink, I can't think of a better thatch-hat wearing, floral-pattern shirt wearing man to greet us at the downstairs bar, where we pulled two seats up at.   Wait, pulled two seats up at the bar downstairs at Smuggler's Cove? Yes. 530pm on a Sunday there was plenty of people in the place but no one sitting at the bar, and not so loud you can't hold a normal conversation. Unbelievable gift of some normal space.   When the punch bowls say "serves four," what that says to me is "hey that serves two, twice." Ordered. Served. Sipped for an hour. This is one of the best bars in America so to be able to relax & linger in this establishment is a true treat.

ZvC5l-_x5c6bUK2TZNtRfw.review_text: This is by far a great bar. Very Polynesian and authentic.  I love the intimate feel to this place.  They have a very extensive cocktail list.  There is a definite signature unique feel to this place.  I could totally see them opening more Smuggler's Cove around the bay area.  I highly recommend this place to tourist visiting the City.  Really great bar.

4jPsIgMZT4_Ks5-myaW9Bg.review_text: WHERE'S THE RUM?!!?!?  Drinks are so weak--Jack Sparrow would not approve.  I even went to the point of asking the bartender for their strongest drink.  Perhaps they would've taken me seriously had I spoken in Pirate?  When he issued a warning, avast!  I thought I had hope, but it was only okay.  Arrg, these be lightweight pirates... or perhaps the management is savvy in avoiding people to get too drunk and paying a visit to Davy Jones' locker.  Ethanol strength aside, I'm still not a fan of their drinks, which generally taste like odd king's cup concoctions.  I think the mango one was the best, and it's basically a slightly alcoholic version of Jamba Juice.    Their specialty is the bowls that come with an impressive flame-boyant (haha bad pun) show.  The fire indeed makes excellent Instagram videos, and it's fun for everyone to share the drink from the long plastic straws in an unspoken race of sorts.  The ambiance is probably my favorite--complete with a mysteriously lit pool, crates as chairs, and a collection of various weapons complete enough to be booty raided from a pirate ship, it's a swashbuckling fun place.    It gets crowded on Friday nights and seating is limited, so I suggest going to the lesser-known top floor (well actually everyone finds out eventually, but it's not immediately obvious), because you need a table to get the bowl drinks--especially important if your objective is to get that Instagram video of catching fire.    The lighting is dark as expected, but there are random purple spotlights.  If possible, I would avoid grabbing a seat in one of these places because it's a bit awkward and you literally look like you're glowing if you're wearing white.  Just a tip, mate.  Afterthought: if they had food, Pirate's Booty would have been hilarious.

XHvfw3UU2YtvvKMLV_oWSg.review_text: Super-cool-Tiki-like pirate bar.I have heard this place has a long line to get in so we got there right at 5PM when they open. We were the first ones to get in-which was cool because it filled up real quick after that. It was happy hour too, so the drinks were 2 dollars off. There was a guy sitting at the bar with us that had a bingo -like card that the bar gives you with all the names of the drinks on it-that the bartenders sign off on when u order a drink- He must have been a regular because he was about to finish his scorecard that night! I think you must get some sorta prize if you drink them all. I ordered the Zombie. SO GOOD. And Strong too. Man, 2 of those and thats pretty much all you need. Which is good, becuse theyre not inexpensive- $12, but well worth it. The doorman was super chill too-He introduced himself as "Justin" and I asked him if his last name was "Case" ---Ha Ha Ha. Gotta good chuckle from that one. All in all a laid back chill bar with wicked awesome drinks. Highly, recommended.

p_hZ_KQS9Y0Gq637A3YbNw.review_text: I tend to get a little nervous when one bar I like closes and another pops up in its place.  I mean, you never know if the new bar is going to be Douchebag Central.    I discovered that was not the case with Smuggler's Cove, for reasons stated below:  They removed the waterfall in front window, which is awesome, as I wasn't a fan of the humidity that came with it.  (Who wants to be all sweaty and frizzy after work?  Not me).  The door people and the bartender were cheerful and provided drink suggestions/explanations, which was very helpful.  I know nothing about rum and my past experience with it involves Rum & Coke (which is gross) or Bacardi 151, which is basically liquid suicide.  Yes, the drinks are on the pricey side (the one I ordered was $13), but I guess that makes sense since they take awhile to make and typically have several ingredients in them.  It got me pretty buzzed too (and I can drink!).  I think it was probably equivalent to about two drinks.    It wasn't crowded on a Wednesday night after 6:30 pm.  There were only a few people upstairs, so it was a great spot for my friend and I to put our feet up and catch up on the latest gossip.  I didn't check out the downstairs "grotto", but will do next time :)  All in all, pretty solid for a newbie :)

qC50T_ldJ96wPBNDD6vtEA.review_text: This place is definitely unique - in the best way possible.  One of my friends introduced me to this bar.  It's easy to walk by and not realize that there is a highly decorated bar inside, because the front is pretty nonchalant.   We spent most of our time on the basement floor, but there is also a level above the ground floor that I haven't been to yet.  The drink list is massive and consists of mostly rum based drinks.  I ordered two different drinks while there - a mai tai and mojito.  Both were amazing!  The bartenders were super friendly and offered us recommendations on drinks.  The drinks are reasonably priced and come in all different shaped glasses.  If you're looking for something out of the ordinary, this is your place.

E9v9M_-JQy42lQ0ntsrj4w.review_text: This bar has great ambiance.  A cute little place with tons of different rum drinks.  The bar tender was nice and even took a picture with me as a souviner.  He suggested some nice places for dinner as well.

WhSfLeqWgRMH4mvPfJ96FA.review_text: On my continued tour of Tiki Bars (although the guys here don't consider this a Tiki bar, but instead an 'Aged Rum Bar'), it was recommended that I visit this bar by a Tiki bar fanatic while at Tiki Ti in Los Angeles.  As you approach the entry, it looked like a business front for those shady mob 'office' because of the blacked out modern glazing with a usual commercial door, but upon walking in for the first time, the stark contrast of the exterior and interior really take you to a different location a different mind set - a place that just makes you happy. The tri-level bar has an upper mezzanine for groups wanting a table, a main floor bar and a bar at the basement level. I'm amazed at how much they crammed in this palace because of the spiral stair reminiscent of an actual pirate ship, the water fall that is right next to it, and the three levels! Even though it's very cozy inside, I never felt crammed in or anything because it's nicely laid out.  As for the drinks, I'll need to come by and try some more, but all the drinks I tasted were stellar. The menu, although classic, is inventive and the descriptions on the menu are priceless. I mean who else puts they have 'brains' as an ingredient in their 'Zombie!?'  Check this place out... you will NOT regret it.

7kT9NskpDXdMC20dnEeqzQ.review_text: Super cute location that specializes in its variety of rum drinks. It incorporates the pirates theme through the mini ponds with treasure chests surrounding the walls. Location has both an upstairs and downstairs with minimal seating. Variety of cute cocktails with hibiscus and pineapple added to glasses.

ccQvyiUeqsXhweY2hHrHAw.review_text: Two and a half stars. We came there on a Wednesday night, and had no trouble getting in at all.  I really like the interior of the place -- it's very unique to have three small levels, and the interior decoration is cool. Even the drink menu is a great and informative read.  However, the drinks were disappointing. I love good rum -- I love Barbancourt, and I'll drink a "Dark and Stomy" by the pint. I started with the "Grog" which was shockingly sweet. The sugar overwhelmed the other ingredients. I moved on to their special house drink, the "Smuggler's Cover Barrel, " was was sweet combined with spicy. Everything was far too sweet, and the flavors of these presumably excellent rums were completely lost.  Also, the music, which was kitschy 60s kind of lounge music, including one featuring a theremin, got tiresome pretty quickly.  Strangely, we basically all agreed that we really liked the place, except for the drinks!

EXqRybkIKj2b3YpAVq91_w.review_text: My friend and I were in visiting from Wisconsin and based on the Yelp reviews, we tried out this place.  The website said they only let in 49 people to keep it an inviting atmosphere, but there were clearly right around 100 people inside.  I was pressed up against a wall waiting to attempt to order a drink.  You could not even move inside.  Admittedly, this could be chalked up to personal preference I guess, but I just don't like a crowded bar.  Drinks were great and I can see why this place get's such great reviews.

kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA.review_text: Close to the War memorial theater for a pre show drink.  I am not a big rum drinker but this place could change my preferences. It was not busy, but from what I hear when San Francisco is in season this place is ridick crazy.  Got a seat at the bar asap and was greeted by a nice bartender in a Hawaiian shirt....I was skeptical.....but man can that guy mix drinks.  P.S. from the outside you can not tell that this a Caribbean themed bar.  I would highly recommend if you are in the neighborhood.

NnSczz_889Ejm3hXrquy-Q.review_text: This is definitely a fun and unique place. If you're in the mood for something different than your standard bar, I would definitely check this out.  Drinks are good. Very good. There are countless options, most of them rum based. What are you in the mood for? Fruity, exotic, acidic, or just plain strong-as-hell? They have them all.  Other things to consider: It's very easy to pass this place up. Very modest sign on a single door. It was also extremely, uncomfortably hot in here when we came. The bartenders were very friendly, the crowd diverse, and prices reasonable.

lLptGOYUfQ-Ir47UYJv0dw.review_text: Smugglers Cove is a step into a different reality from the hustle and bustle of busy city life. The entrance is a simple door, we arrived thinking this would be your typical city bar, liquor on the wall, beer taps, small tables and alcohol advertisements as decor. The first step into the bar it's like walking into a Peter Pan or Pirates of the Caribbean Ship.   There are two floors with two bars, which allows plenty of room to meet with a group of friends. The bar focuses on their Rum a selection with minimal tequila, vodka, and whiskey selection. The menu is extensive, and the bartenders can find a drink that will fixate any palate. Requests for dry, sour, sweet, bitter drinks can be fulfilled. I had the trade winds drink, coconut creme, lime. And two kinds of rum blended in a pool of ice. My initial thought was it would be a light drink but it packed a punch as was very Rum forward. It was delicious and satisfied my palate for a tiki drink. Smugglers Cove is a great step away from reality, even with just a drink or two.

1nWwwKZ3dBKdyH0V2weWOw.review_text: I was visiting friends and they took me here; said there wasn't really a place quite like it. The pirate decor was so interesting and quirky. We only stayed for a drink - the Volcano bowl. This thing is awesome - not only is it a bit of show because they serve it to your seat and torch the everclear-soaked sugar cube making some exciting fire balls. AND it's delicious.

Lsk_eYFxS3X5j1yvTF64Uw.review_text: So as a native San Franciscan who does not have any Christmas Eve family traditions I think that I may have found one: hanging out with other SF locals (i.e. born and bread in the city) and have a few cocktails. Smuggler's Cove is a new bar. I asked the bartender who informed me that they have their one year anniversary on December 6th. With their friendly employees, great regulars, and one of the largest drink menus that I have ever seen, I hope that this baby of a bar will be around for years. Walking through the tiny  nondescript door and walking into the multilevel sea shanty themed bar was like walking into Willy Wanka's Chocolate factory (yes, they even have a waterfall). I was able to try three different drinks and each one was tasty. Rum never tasted as good as it did this Christmas Eve.

_D25AL2bbVQNOJLOrdk0uQ.review_text: Great bartenders, friendly staff, a good variety of drinks, not too loud or too quiet, and always a good time.  Only thing I dislike, the line.  Enjoy your drink and get the hell out people! Others want to enjoy this place!

f0nx8nuotNpFYRbqfTV1lA.review_text: Would've given 5 stars if it weren't for the lack of space but hands down one of THE best places I've been! The painkiller is a great first choice just be sure to choose your "level". The person that was with me ordered level 4 and I was definitely two sheets to the wind!!  Kind of a piratey theme but totally sigges the ambience! Want to go there again and try something new.

HvdgGKbv1OHmKBPKQm-xNg.review_text: I've hesitated to visit Smuggler's Cove since its takeover from the old days of Jade, namely because I'd heard about the over-the-top prices and decor.  Well, that about sums it up. Smuggler's Cove (or "The Pirate Bar" as a friend fondly refers to it) is a novelty sort of place, which is one part awesome and about five parts kitschy. It's what you might expect a Pirates of the Caribbean type bar to be - that is, if alcohol were allowed within the confines of Disneyland.  The drink list is extensive and expensive, full of both hits and misses. I had the Navy Grog (strong, but relatively flavourless) and decided to hit up the bartender for a suggestion on the next round, preferring something strong and borderline sweet. He recommended the self-titled signature drink and definitely hit the nail right on the head. So much so, that I had two. I tried my friends' Aku Aku (delicious, super fruity) and Pirates? Paradise? Punch (I forget the name but it was strong and not as sweet) and they were both pretty good.  Myself and my companions arrived shortly after 6 p.m. and secured a spot upstairs - I'd imagine if we'd showed up just an hour later, we'd be hard-pressed to find available seating for all three of us. That's definitely one of the secrets to the place: show up early. Although, as far as I can tell, there weren't any happy hour specials, which is slightly bad form (Hook reference dudes).  In the end, I left the bar quite buzzed and with a fairly significant dent in my wallet (considering the dollar-to-drink ratio) but I also had enjoyed myself, so that has got to count for something. Overall, Smuggler's Cove is a fun place to hang out or check out every once in awhile, but I wouldn't ever count it among my regular hot spots. In other words, yes, take your friends from out of town here, but don't blow your wad here nearly every night.

Djk49JjpKl9HQNpmiX669Q.review_text: Very cozy spot to lounge with some friends and drink the night away!!   This place is sooo hard to find! It was raining pretty hard outside when I was walking to smuggler's cove and even when I was actively looking for it, I couldn't find it! I walked by it a couple of times before I realized that the inconspicuous blackened doors and windows lead to the bar I've been looking for!   Once you finally find it and go inside, you feel like you've discovered a hidden treasure! The bar is pretty dim with heavy pirate-esk decor. You do indeed feel like you are in a cove in the tropics!   I had a couple of drinks here... 1) Bomba: Really strong but that's because I'm a lightweight and I drink really fruity/sugary drinks.  2) La Floridita: Fruity and sugary! Can't really taste the alcohol at all! Loved it!  3) Kona Cocktail: Comes with a tropical purple/maroon colored flower in the drink! Tasted just as good as it looked! YUM!  Loved the friendly staff! Great place to enjoy some good drinks with some good company!

LFppbsX544qTQuhE1PyCxQ.review_text: A tiki bar with multiple levels, an anchor, a fountain on the walls????  YES PLEASE.  I love the theme in here and it's not over done, everything works.  Do yourself a favor and try the Hot Buttered Rum.  They have a special hand made butter that is made into a hot drink, it's the most delicious drink I've ever had in my life. I'm not exaggerating either. Have it on a warm night too, it's sweet.

8aDdLd9WOlclDrn6U52VGQ.review_text: Ok so the Crow flies in from 300 miles+ away, then crosses the Bay Bridge to have a drink at this new rum bar in town. The drinks were yummy, and the bartender even accommodated the Crow's sensitivities by creating a new drink! Delicious! I Cawwwed! But wait! It's 4th of July weekend, we are hanging out, ordering the second round, relaxed in the upper Tiki level and we are told they are closing early because the owner called in & can't afford the bartender's minimum wage for so few patrons. You know what? That's BS!!  There was a bouncer, a manager, a bartender and some other person I believe.  Don't kick out your customers. Their bottom bar was closed as well, so we didn't get the full effect of the ambiance all lit up downstairs. So here we are with a "Batida" from Brasil-( which I recommend) and my unknown Crow beverage that had a passion fruit twist, and we are having to chug because they want to leave. You know what , the manager was doing nothing but giving us his lame ass excuses why they have to leave. Send him home instead!! Decor is great, menu is stunningly thorough, but tourists beware! Don't go on a holiday. Hard core Tiki & Pirate fans will probably forgive any imperfections just to drink in this place, but other places are better and have better service.

bSKzxR8zT9dmO_uo0yGPqw.review_text: arrrgh matey...this place shivers my timbers!! cant get enough of the drinks here...ask for the bingo sheet that the bartenders can sign off on every time you order one of their drinks. and bring it with you everytime. it's like bingo...but the only thing you win is a jacked up liver. pretty worth it tho, if i do say so myself.

NcoiM_90N8LxrPnjpmiWig.review_text: Wow! Batida, hot butter rum, rum barrel...best drinks I've ever had, I kid you not. Cool atmosphere chill bartenders and a great mixed crowd. Pricey, yes but so worth it. I use to go to bourbon and branch and rickhouse quite a bit but this is now my spot. Far superior in every way. Do get there early as it does get packed.
